hits.name: Mount Lafayette and Franconia Ridge Trail Loop
hits.description:
This extremely popular hike in the White Mountains of New Hampshire is one of the best day hikes in the area for a variety of reasons. Beginning near the Lafayette Campground in Franconia Notch State Park, this great hike offers some of the best views in New England! As a bonus, you will ascend three peaks including the highest mountain outside the Presidential Range - Mount Lafayette.

You’ll start along the Falling Waters Trail and walk by Stairs Falls and then the larger Cloudland Falls. After winding your way upwards for a while longer, you’ll reach Little Haystack Mountain. This peak marks the intersection of the Franconia Ridge Trail and features beautiful views of the region.

Next, you’ll come to Mount Lincoln. After crossing this peak, you’ll walk along a narrow ridge to the final summit of the trip - Mt Lafayette. After reaching the summit of Mt Lafayette, feel free to spend some time enjoying the incredible views. On a clear day, you’ll have views of Mount Washington and the rest of the Presidential Range.

After all that climbing, you’ve earned your steady descent down the Greenleaf Trail that leads to the Greenleaf Hut (the hut closes during the wintertime) and Eagle Lake. From here, complete the loop by following the Old Bridal Path back to the Lafayette Place East parking lot.

Due to the unpredictable weather and tough conditions in the area, the park highly recommends that you come prepared with a water bottle, hiking boots, and trekking poles. Visitors hiking in the winter will most likely need to bring microspikes and check weather conditions ahead of time. Some sections are not marked well so you may want to download the offline map before you go.

hits.name: Mount Willard Trail
hits.description:
Mount Willard Trail is a relatively steep day hike in the White Mountains that rewards with incredible views of Crawford Notch and the surrounding range. 

Starting at Saco Lake, you won’t travel far before a small waterfall cascade and then the centennial pool. The summit offers views and a perfect spot to stop and have a snack before the trek down!

Expect a few small water crossings, some rocky terrain and snow/ice near the top during the colder months. 

The trail markers on this trail are reportedly far between so you may want to download the offline map before you go.

hits.name: Welch-Dickey Loop Trail
hits.description:
The Welsh-Dickey is one the most popular hikes in White Mountain National Forest, and for good reason. The challenging route offers beautiful views of Waterville Valley, and the surrounding area.

You’ll start at the Welsh-Dickey Trailhead off Orris Road. There is a $5 parking fee at the trailhead. This route can be done in either direction, but an overwhelming majority of people choose the counter-clockwise route on this page.

The first section gradually climbs, with some short steep sections over slabs. You’ll reach Welch Mountain first. Continue northward and you’ll eventually reach Dickey Mountain. After taking in the views, the trail veers westward, and there is a gradual decline back down to the parking area.

As with all the trails in the area, this hike is entirely different during winter. If you’re visiting from November - May, you’ll likely need traction devices, hiking poles, and experience with winter hiking.

hits.name: Mount Monadnock via White Dot and White Cross Trails
hits.description:
There is a $15 fee per vehicle to park and hike in Monadnock State Park.

This hike is a well-marked, steep scramble up a nice peak in Southern New Hampshire. 
Monadnock Mountain is reputed to be one of the most hiked mountains in the world with over 125,000 people climbing it every year. 

This is a challenging hike along the side of the mountain rewarding views from the summit.
The trails are very steep in places but can be completed in a half-day. Older kids will have a ton of fun rock-hopping their way to the summit on the steep trail and this hike is also a great place to see the changing leaves in fall. 

As one of the most climbed mountains, Monadnock is a very popular New England hike just north of very populated cities in Vermont and Massachusetts so you most likely won't be alone on the trail. Parking in the lot off of Poole Road can be a challenge, and the summit can be windy, so you may want to bring an additional layer for the top. Other trails in the area include the White Cross Trail, Birchtoft Trail, Cascade Link Trail, and Pumpelly Trail.

hits.name: Mount Major via Brook and Main Trail Loop
hits.description:
This route up Mount Major includes the Brook and Main Trail to make a moderate day hike that’s great for all ages! This trail is entirely forested until the summit, quite rocky throughout and has lots of glacial erratic rocks along the way. After starting off relatively flat, the trail gets fairly steep midway through and up to the summit. There are amazing views of Lake Winnipesaukee and the White Mountains along the way. When you reach the summit you will find remnants of Mr. Phippen’s Hut and views of the Major Mountain Range. This is a great spot for a break and a picnic before heading back down.

This is a year round trail but expect muddy conditions in the spring and microspikes are suggested in the winter months.

hits.name: Mount Moosilauke and South Peak Loop
hits.description:
Mount Moosilauke and South Peak Loop is an excellent year round adventure! This route takes you up the Gorge Brook Trail from the Ravine Lodge Trailhead to the summit of the massive Mt. Moosilauke. The summit of Moosilauke used to be home to the historic Moosilauke Ravine Lodge, the foundation of which is still visible today. This is also an excellent viewpoint of the surrounding White Mountains!

In the winter this is an excellent ski trail! Visitors can descend/ski to the South Peak to check it out before skiing powder and heading down a wide carriage road and ski connector path to the bottom. If you aren’t skiing, it is suggested to use microspikes and crampons on this trail in snowy months.

hits.name: Mount Washington via Tuckerman Ravine and Lion Head Trail
hits.description:
Mount Washington is the highest point in New England and the highest peak in the White Mountains of New Hampshire. Often called the most dangerous small mountain in the world, Mount Washington is recommended for experienced hikers and climbers who can handle significant elevation gain. 

Tuckerman's Ravine Trail from Pinkham Notch is the most popular route to the summit. It is important to properly research this trail and bring proper gear as conditions can quickly turn dangerous as a result of bad weather in the form of severe storms, snow and wind. There are no markings on Tuckerman's Ravine, so it's easy to take a wrong turn. Keep left after the last yellow arrow and follow the cairns once you crest the wall.

It is recommended that hikers contact the Mount Washington Observatory forecast (mountwashington.org/weather) and the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center prior to their trip.

Those who hike the Tuckerman Ravine Trail will pass the Hermit Lake Shelters with great views of the ravine and a waterfall.  Visitors can also reach the top via the Mount Washington Auto Road and the Cog Railway.

hits.name: The Flume Gorge Trail
hits.description:
Advanced Tickets and reservations via the website are required for this trail.

The gorge is open from late May to late October. Opening times may vary, so please check the park page for details: https://www.nhstateparks.org/visit/state-parks/flume-gorge

The Flume Gorge trail is New Hampshire beauty, up close and personal.  Waterfalls, mosses, wild flowers, and trees line this beautiful boardwalk.  This is a relaxing must-see while hiking the more difficult trails around New Hampshire's White Mountains.

The Flume is a natural gorge extending 800 feet at the base of Mount Liberty. The walls of Conway granite rise to a height of 70 to 90 feet and are 12 to 20 feet apart. A trip into the Flume begins and ends at the Flume Visitor's Center. Guests can choose to walk through just the Gorge or do a two mile loop. The walk includes uphill walking and lots of stairs. The boardwalk allows you to look closely at the growth of flowers, ferns and mosses found here. 

Framed by a spectacular vista of Mount Liberty and Mount Flume, the Visitor Center houses the Flume ticket office, information center, cafeteria, gift shop, and the state park system's historic Concord Coach. A 20-minute movie showcasing beautiful Franconia Notch State Park is available for viewing.

The Flume was discovered in 1808 by 93-year-old Aunt Jess Guernsey when she accidentally came upon it while fishing. She had trouble convincing her family of the marvelous discovery, but eventually persuaded others to come and see for themselves. At that time, a huge egg-shaped boulder hung suspended between the walls. The rock was 10 feet (3m) high and 12 feet (3.6m) long. A heavy rainstorm in June of 1883 started a landslide that swept the boulder from its place. It has never been found. The same storm deepened the gorge and formed Avalanche Falls.

hits.name: Lonesome Lake Trail
hits.description:
Lonesome Lake Trail is a steady incline hike, but worth it to see the beautiful Lonesome Lake. Follow the well-marked yellow blazes from the parking lot. There are several steep sections up Cannon Mountain and hiking poles could come in handy. Views of the Franconia Ridge can be seen on the way to the lake and most of the way is shaded. Feel free to take your shoes off and dip your feet in the lake! Along the lake, the trail is grassy and easy-going. 

Be sure to check out the nearby Lonesome Lake Hut where you can reserve a room and have a nice meal. There are also snacks to purchase and restrooms for public use.

During the winter months, hikers recommend bringing a pair of microspikes for snow. Franconia Notch State Park has some guidelines to follow so check out their park page if you have any questions.

hits.name: Mount Tecumseh Trail via Waterville Trailhead
hits.description:
The smallest of New Hampshire's official 4,000 footers (standing at 4,003 feet tall) sits adjacent to the Waterville Valley Ski area and there is a large parking lot off of Ski Area Road. A lovely hike to do during any season!

Follow the Mount Tecumseh Trail 1.2 miles to a viewpoint, then go another 1 (steep) mile to the cross trail between the Tecumseh Trail and the Sosman trail. From there, the summit is 0.3 miles away. There are no switchbacks as you are essentially climbing up a ski run. The loop around the summit is a narrow monorail. There are limited views, but it is still beautiful!

hits.name: Mount Pemigewasset Trail (Indian Head)
hits.description:
This is a great trail if you're looking for a relatively short hike with beautiful views of the White Mountains. Although steep, the payoff at the end makes the trip worth it. 

This trail can get busy during peak seasons so be sure to get an early start.
Begin from the Flume Gorge parking area (Exit 34A off I-93) and starts out along a bike path. Shortly, you will branching be off of the Franconia Notch State Park Recreational Trail and see a Mount Pemi Trail sign - begin following the blue blazes. 

The route has great views of Franconia Ridge and out towards Lincoln. The trail is uphill to the junction with the Indian Head Trail.Watch your feet as there are steep ledges and these may be icy.

hits.name: Artist Bluff Trail
hits.description: Please note that parking on the road is not permitted.

hits.name: Mount Morgan and Mount Percival Loop
hits.description: Hikers should be comfortable with heights and rock scrambling before trying this trail.

hits.name: Diana's Baths
Mount Pierce via Crawford Path
hits.description:
Mount Pierce via the Crawford Path is a steady climb from the trailhead to the summit. The grade hikers encounter shortly after departing the trailhead is the level of steepness they will experience for the majority of the hike to the top.

This is a popular choice as a first New Hampshire 4k peak.

hits.name: Mount Waumbek and Mount Starr King via Starr King and Kilkenny Ridge Trail
hits.description:
The trail starts off through a beautiful hardwood forest. The grade begins as a steady, gentle incline and never gets very steep. At 3,000 feet the hardwoods are replaced by evergreens, creating a cozy feel as you approach the summit of Starr King. 

The best views are from Starr King to the south overlooking a vast plain and the entire Presidential Range.  The trail continues on at the large stone fireplace left from a former shelter. The summit of Waumbek is wooded, but the walk over from Starr King is beautiful. Waumbek is the shortest of the NH 4K peaks at 4,006 feet.

Winter parking is in two expansion lots just to the east and west of Starr King Road on Rt 2. https://goo.gl/maps/Qjf7RvwDb7R2TGCv5  The parking area is not plowed and you should not block Starr King Rd.

hits.name: Champney Brook Trail to Mount Chocorua
hits.description:
There is a fee for parking.

Long cascading waterfall with many small pools - best in spring and early summer.

Easy trail ascends through hardwoods and along a brook. You will have some small steep sections but overall this trail is easy - an excellent hike with kids and dogs.  

The waterfall is very beautiful but is best seen in the spring and early summer when the water is running best. It tends to dry up in the late summer and fall. This might be a good winter hike.

hits.name: Presidential Traverse Trail
hits.description:
The Presidential Traverse is an excellent and well-traveled hike of some of New Hampshire's highest peaks all located in the White Mountains- almost all at maximum exposure. This trip is not for the faint of heart and not to be attempted in just one day, but it can be done with the right preparation.  Many choose to complete this trail as a multi-day backpacking trip (2-3 days).

The official Presidential range begins north to south at Madison peak and then onwards to Adams peak. Hikers will reach Jefferson and Washington summit next, then continue on to the last half at mount Monroe, Eisenhower, Pierce, and finally Jackson. There are AMC huts to stop along the way, such as the lakes of the clouds hut, where one may stop and get a bite to eat.

The cabins take credit cards. Sometimes they'll have food or coffee and allow you to fill up water. They are also a nice refuge from the imminent surprise bad weather of the summertime.

Parking is $5 a day at the center (South). Dropping people off at the North trailhead, driving to the center/parking, and then taking the shuttle to regroup is highly recommended. This will allow you to come out of the trail right beside the parking lot on your last day. You cannot reserve a shuttle seat the day of and must book in advance or wait around in line to ensure a spot. Do not rely on taxi services as they are far and few. Check out the shuttle schedule at https://www.outdoors.org/lodging-camping/lodging-shuttle

It's recommended to bring an extra pair of socks and band-aids in case of blisters. This hike is mostly completely exposed with little tree coverage. Bad weather can have a huge effect on the hiking day so checking the forecast a few days prior is recommended.

hits.name: Champney Falls Trail
hits.description:
Cell reception can be tricky in this area. Downloading the off-line map before you go is recommended. 

There is a small parking area at the north end of the trail off of Kancamagus Highway. Champney Falls is a series of cascades about 70 feet long. While spectacular during high water, the falls are quite meager during dry periods. The falls are named for Benjamin Champney, a noted White Mountain artist (1817-1907). 

Walking time to the falls and back takes about 2.5 hours. If you want a longer hiker, you can continue further south, you can reach Mount Chocorua.

hits.name: Hancock Trail
hits.description:
This trail is primarily moderate however it does get tough the last mile to the top of North Hancock. At this portion hikers will have to trek on rocks and scrambles, this portion is also difficult to descend so please be aware.

This is a fun loop trail to two 4,000 foot peaks (Hancock and South Hancock) in New Hampshire. There aren't any crazy great views but you'll get glimpses towards the Tripyramids, Carrigain of each mountain from the others summit.

Users have reported that there is no cell service in the area - be sure to download the map before heading to the trailhead to avoid getting lost.

hits.name: Mount Garfield Trail
hits.description:
The Mt. Garfield Trail is fairly level for the majority of the way before some steep climbing the last 1/4 of the way to the summit.

The Mt. Garfield Trail meets with the Garfield Ridge/Appalachian Trail for the final .2 miles to the summit.

hits.name: Little Haystack via Falling Waters Trail
hits.description:
Falling Waters Trail follows the rocky, rushing Dry Brook upstream to meet the Franconia Notch Trail. 

0.5 miles below the summit is a 0.1 mile spur trail for "Shining Rock".  This is an exposed slab of granite 200 ft tall by 800 ft wide.

hits.name: Mount Osceola Summit
hits.description:
Mt. Osceola is a popular New Hampshire 4K peak. The trail leading to the summit is quite rocky so hikers are encouraged to swear good footwear.

The summit of Mount Osceola is made up of several rocky ledges with great views of the surrounding area.

The hike is often done well into late fall and early winter with the assistance of traction devices or snowshoes.

hits.name: Mount Osceola and East Osceola
hits.description:
This is a popular route to summit two New Hampshire 4k peaks in one trip.

The trail has some switchbacks towards the summit of Mount Osceola which is a welcomed sight after the straight uphill sections of the trail.

The views from the top of Osceola and East peak are stunning on a clear day!

hits.name: Cannon Mountain via Kinsman Ridge Trail
Mount Whiteface and Passaconway Loop
hits.description:
As of October 2020, the only legal parking is in the parking lot and a section of the access road to the parking lot. There is now no parking allowed on Ferncroft Road. Hikers have reported getting tickets and having their car towed when illegally parked. Please be careful about parking. 

This is a fun loop hike deep in the White Mountains to two wooded summits but with ledges and various viewpoints along the route the hike is well worth it. The trailhead is beautiful and the trails are pretty well maintained.  

Climb Whiteface through the Blueberry Ledges Trail (you can take the Blue Berry Ledges Cutoff as well, it merges into the Blueberry Ledges anyway). Up until the last half mile you will be immersed in deep forest. Beautiful brooks and small falls next to the trail. Not too many ledges or blueberries until you get close to Mt. Whiteface.

The last half a mile climbing Mt. Whiteface is rather steep but short. You will be rewarded by beautiful views to the west.  

Continue northeast into the Rollins Trail which will hit the intersection with the Dicey's Mill Trail. If you take this trail north (left) you will hit Mt. Passaconway. Although that is the mountain top, you may want to walk a quarter of a mile north to the view point.  Turn back through the Dicey's Mill Trail which lead you down to the trailhead where you started.

hits.name: Mount Kearsarge North
hits.description:
The Kearsarge North trail is a consistent climb up to the summit with 360-degree views and a fire tower.

The Fire tower was built in 1913 and was in use by the U.S. Forest Service until the 1960s. It is not a part of the National Historic Lookout Register. 

Visitors are encouraged to sweep the fire tower after visiting to help keep the structure in good shape.

hits.name: Mount Chocorua Loop Trail
hits.description:
Although dogs are allowed in this area, users have reported that most dogs will have trouble with the scrambling portions of this route.
 
A popular rocky traverse over a series of mountains in the Whites with terrific 360 degree views. This is one of the most popular and beautiful hikes in the White Mountains of New Hampshire. Mt. Chocorua looks like the summit of a peak you may find in the Colorado Rockies! 
 
From the parking lot off of Route 16 begin up the Piper Trail as it follows the Chocorua River up valley. After just over a mile you’ll head up to the ridge by joining Nickerson and Carter Ledge Trail. Carters Ledge is a very exposed and steep section of trail with lots of scrambling but also many impressive views. Continue to Middle Sister Trail where the ridge hiking continues across multiple summits until culminating in a rocky summit experience on Mt Chocorua. From the Chocorua Summit you will have great views towards Mount Washington and the rest of the White Mountain National Forest before heading back to the parking area utilizing Liberty Trail.

hits.name: Mount Cardigan Loop Trail
hits.description: Cardigan Mountain State Park spans 5,655 acres and is a popular destination with numerous hiking trails. The Mount Cardigan Summit at 3,121 feet offers beautiful panoramic views of Mount Monadnock, the White Mountains, Camel’s Hump and Pleasant Mountain. Visitors hiking the Mount Cardigan Loop will start from the main parking lot at the end of Cardigan Mountain Road. Take the West Ridge Trail to Clark Trail and return on the South Ridge Trail. The Loop will hit the Mount Cardigan Fire Tower, Cardigan South peak and Cardigan Rimrock. Camping is available at AMC’s Cardigan Lodge.

hits.name: Mount Carrigain via Signal Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Though this peak is heavily wooded, there is a great section of exposed ridge near the top and an observation tower that offers a 360 degree view.

Trekking poles and spikes are recommended during the winter and shoulder season months.

hits.name: Boulder Loop Trail
hits.description:
There is a fee to park at the trailhead.

This loop passes by several large and peculiarly placed boulders. The trail winds up a series of ledges that lead to wide-open views of the surrounding area. 

This trail has less elevation gain than many of the White Mountain's other popular trails but still rewards visitors with beautiful scenery.

hits.name: Mt. Washington via Jewell Trail, Gulfside Trail and Crawford Path
Black Cap Trail
hits.description:
One of the most popular short hikes in the White Mountains, this relatively easy hike is blazed in red and offers excellent views of the White Mountains and the Presidential Range.  

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire. It is an excellent place for walking, hunting, and observing wildlife. Camping, fires or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve, and all dogs must be on a leash.

hits.name: Sabbaday Falls
Basin Cascade Trail
hits.description:
This family-friendly, partially-paved trail goes by multiple cascading waterfalls and deep pools that are popular for wading and swimming.

The Basin pothole is the deepest pothole in the White Mountains.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of I-93 at the east end of the trail. It is unclear if they are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or a natural (dirt, rock, and root) surface. It is typically 2 to 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the moderately steep grade category (8% or less) and the steepest sections are after about 0.5 miles when going west. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance along this entire route due to the consistent sections above a 5% grade. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the wide and paved section in the first 0.3 miles along the paved path with its own trail page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/franconia-notch-path

hits.name: Mount Tom, Mount Field, Mount Willey and Mount Avalon Trail
hits.description: A loop trail hitting three 4,000' peaks. From AMC Highland Center, head west on A-Z Trail to Mt. Tom summit, then southwest on Willey Range Trail to Mts. Field and Willey summits. Return north to Mt. Field, then northeast on Avalon Trail to Mt. Avalon and returning to Highland Center.

hits.name: Mount Roberts Trail
hits.description: Mt. Roberts is the westernmost peak in the Castle in the Clouds complex in the Ossipee Mountains. While the summit features strong views to the north, perhaps the most scenic portion is the ledge area along the Mt. Roberts Trail. The Lake Winnipesaukee views from this section are second to none.

hits.name: Winslow and Barlow Trail Loop
hits.description:
Day use reservation required. Mount Kearsarge is a must-do hike for anyone living in the Kearsarge area.

The summit has a fire tower (which is occasionally open to enter). The top is very exposed and offers 360 degree views.

hits.name: Mount Jackson and Mount Webster Trail Loop
hits.description:
A great hike when time is limited.  The views from both peaks are impressive, encompassing Mt. Washington, the southern Presidential Range peaks, and Crawford's Notch.  

The climb is steep in places and strewn with granite boulders, but it is in New Hampshire after all. There is a pleasant waterfall with an enticing pool of water at its base along the Webster Trail.

hits.name: North Kinsman and South Kinsman Trail via Lonesome Lake and Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
Park at Lafayette Place Campground. On weekends, the lot tends to fill up early. Many people suggest you arrive in the lot by 7am to get a parking spot. There is overflow parking nearby, but it will add some mileage. Take the Lonesome Lake Trail north and turn left in the Cascade Brook trail until you reach the Lonesome Lake Hut (Operated by the AMC).  You may want to rest there, and you can grab a snack, juice, or tea for a few bucks.  

This trail will bring you past Lonesome Lake in an old glacial cirque, past Kinsman Pond to the Kinsman Peaks which are the highest in the range. Kinsman is an open summit offering good views but North Kinsman is wooded with some views to the east.  This hike is the quickest and easiest way to get to both peaks in one hike.

Continue up into the Fishing Jimmy trail.  At the four-way intersection you want to continue north (left would take you to the shelter, and right would take you to Cannon Mountain (another popular destination)).

Soon you will reach North Kinsman.  You have to step east a few feet into the view to take pictures of the White Mountains.  Continue the trail to South Kinsman.  The South Kinsman summit has limited views, but if you continue along the trail for another 100m, you will have 360-degree views. Retrace to return to your car.

Some people combine this hike with Cannon Mountain into a longer hike.  You can also do it as a backpack if you stay at the Kinsman shelter. The Mt. Kinsman trail offers an alternate route to these summits.

hits.name: Mount Washington via Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail
hits.description:
The Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail leads to the Lake of the Clouds Hut and onto the summit of Mount Washington. 

Lake of the Clouds Hut is open to the public and is a fun place to stop for some water and a snack on the way up or down.

During winter months, be sure to check conditions and have the proper attire. Hikers suggest crampons and ice axe for certain areas.

hits.name: South Moat Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The South Moat Mountain Trail is a consistent climb to the peak of South Mout Mountain. Hikers will be faced with a steady climb right up until they meet the summit where they will be treated to sweeping views.

Users have reported the parking area fits 20-25 cars, so it is not uncommon for the parking area to be full early in the morning on a nice weekend.

hits.name: Tower Hill Pond Loop Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice, wide trail with lovely views. There is some elevation change and a few rocks and roots in the path, but many of them are clearly marked with spray paint to help you notice them. The lake and trees are beautiful. This route is popular with snowmobilers in the winter. 

Accessibility: Visitors using wheelchairs, mobility equipment, or strollers may need all-terrain tires or adaptive/motorized equipment for the surface type and grade.

Accessible Parking:
Number of designated accessible spaces: unclear;
Parking lot surface: gravel.

Trail Details:
Trail surface: gravel with rocks and roots;
Average trail width: 8
Estimated average grade category: mostly gentle (5% or less).

hits.name: North and Middle Sugarloaf via Sugarloaf Trail
hits.description:
This short yet steep hike rewards hikers with amazing views from the summit. The terrain and incline is pretty consistent throughout the entire hike.

Middle Sugarloaf has a more wide-open summit for taking in the views after the hike to the top.

This is a good introductory White Mountain hike for kids and pets.

hits.name: UNH Trail to Hedgehog Mountain
hits.description:
The incline to the summit of Hedgehog Mountain is consistent with one steeper section leading to the summit. The views are great year-round, but the fall foliage is exceptionally stunning. Mount Washington and the Presidential Range is visible from the top.

Stop at Allen's Ledge for views of Mt. Chocorua and Moat Mountains.

hits.name: Bridal Veil Falls Trail
hits.description:
The trail is a fairly consistent grade for the majority of the route leading to the waterfall. Sections of the trail are rocky, but this is considered to be a great introductory hike for kids in the White Mountains.

This is also a great hike to do on a rainy day when trails above the treeline are too unsafe to hike on.

hits.name: Lockes Hill Trail
hits.description: Parking can be found on the south side of the road across the street from a scenic overlook looking out at Lake Winnipesaukee.

hits.name: Mount Major Boulder Loop Trail (Orange to Blue)
hits.description: In the winter months microspikes are recommended as the trail can be packed and icy.

hits.name: Mount Tripyramid Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail is challenging and strenuous with 45 degree climbs for extended periods but has great rewarding views.

Take Livermore road east until you hit the Tripyramid North Slide Trail. If it is wet you may want to walk a bit longer on the Livermore trail and climb using the Scaur Ridge Trail. Enjoy the views on the way up and on the way down.  

Once you finish climbing the North Ridge, you may want to rest on the North Tripyramid for a while, before continuing to the Middle and South Tripyramids (easy hike there).  Climbing down is through the Tripyramid Trail, South Slide.  The surface here is granular, so it will be easier to climb down via the south than via the north (but it will still take time).  Once you reach the Livermore Rd, walk back to the car.  

You will not forget this hike.

hits.name: Ted's Trail to Carolyn's Trail Loop
hits.description: Ted's Trail features a beautiful stream and cascade after rain. The Cliff Trail offers spectacular views east - a great way to beat the Monadnock crowds. There is a lot of rock scrambling in the last mile.

hits.name: Pemi Loop
hits.description: This trail is subject to flooding. There is a day fee to park at Lincoln Woods. Free parking with annual National parks pass. There is a cash fee per night for developed campsites along the trail.

hits.name: Mount Hale via Hale Brook Trail
hits.description:
Zealand Road closes seasonally in winter, adding distance to this trail if you have to park outside of the gate (about 2.5 additional miles each way).

This peak has a large pile of rocks at the top clearly marking the summit.

The top of this peak has experienced some tree growth which unfortunately has blocked many of the great views. Perhaps if climbing on top of the massive pile of rocks that mark the summit, it may be possible to view more of the surrounding White Mountains. The trail up is steep but enjoyable.

hits.name: Mount Liberty via Liberty Spring Trail
hits.description:
This trail is rated moderate for experienced hikers and hard for beginners. It can be hard, particularly if your knees give you some trouble, but it’s not technical and does make for a good, challenging day hike. The views are worth the effort!

Google Maps can have difficulty locating the trailhead, double check Google's endpoint before departing.

hits.name: Beaver Brook Trail to Mount Moosilauke
hits.description:
Very steep trail with incredible views at the top. This trail can be very tricky if it’s raining, as it would be extremely muddy and slippery. Wear sturdy shoes with grip.

From the trailhead, the trail leads up to the summit of Mount Moosilauke and reaches the Appalachian Trail.

hits.name: Flume Slide Trail to Liberty Spring Trail Loop
Mt. Monadnock via White Dot Trail
Mount Israel via Wentworth Trail
hits.description:
From the summit, there are great views of Mt. Kearsarge and the Sandwich Range.

Along the way, the trail passes by a brook with several cascading sections. This is a great place to cool off on the way back to the car in the summer months!

The trail also involves a few creek crossings, so anticipate potentially getting wet shoes.

hits.name: Mount Moosilauke via Gorge Brook Trail
hits.description:
The Gorge Brook Trail leads to the summit of one of the most popular NH 4Kers, Mt. Moosilauke. The summit has 360 degrees views of the White Mountains and visitors can even see mountains in Vermont on a day with good visibility.

This is the steepest but most direct trail leading to the summit.

hits.name: Mount Cardigan via West Ridge Trail
Purgatory Falls via Purgatory Brook Trail
hits.description:
The first of the three falls is only a 10-minute hike and is great for swimming. The next 2 are an hour plus through a very thin overgrown path. 

The trail is not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

hits.name: Mount Major via Main Trail
hits.description: This route uses the blue blazes to hike up Mount Major.

hits.name: Zealand Summit via Zealand Trail and Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
Zealand Falls and the views that come with this ascent make the wooded summit of this mountain easy to swallow for Northeast Peakbaggers.

Zealand mountain is located on the edge of the Pemigewasset Wilderness. You will pass by a beautiful AMC hut and Zealand Falls on the way to the wooded summit. The falls are definitely worth a stop at on the way up. You will have some views of the Bond Range near the top through the trees.

hits.name: Hermit Lake via Tuckerman Ravine Trail
hits.description:
This is a popular early-season hike as Hermit Lake is often accessible by mid to late May. Users should know bringing microspikes or some sort of traction could still be necessary into late spring.

During this time of the year, skiers can often be seen descending the steep slopes of Tuckerman's Ravine.

hits.name: Mount Moriah via Carter Moriah Trail
hits.description:
This hike features wonderful views of Mount Washington and the White Mountains. 

The terrain starts easy on the first mile of the trail, but quickly becomes moderately to strenuously steep.  When you have hiked almost 2 miles, you will pass through Mount Surprise.  You may want to spend some time on it, as it has great views of the Presidential Range.  Think of it as a preview of what you will see when you reach Mount Moriah.

Continue up the trail, passing some blueberry bushes that bloom in the summertime.  A couple more miles of rocky terrain will bring you to an intersection with a sign for Mt. Moriah.  A few feet more and you will have conquered another North Hampshire 4K peak, and enjoy beautiful views of the Presidential Range.

hits.name: Glen Ellis Falls Trail
hits.description:
Absolutely stunning! Short trek in and down several stairs, but worth every step!

In total, the path is 600 feet long and leads visitors to the 64-foot tall falls. Here, visitors will see the Ellis River beautifully cascade down the cliffside forming Glen Ellis Falls.

hits.name: Baldface Trail
hits.description:
Take this wonderful loop hike over two beautiful bald peaks with fantastic views towards the taller White Mountains.

This is a loop hike with several fun stream crossings and a lot of views at the top of both peaks and along the ridge.  As their name implies, both peaks have bald summits and in some steep places you may find yourself on fun scrambles.  There will be fantastic views on clear days towards the taller White Mountains including Mt. Washington which dominates the horizon.

hits.name: Cathedral Ledge from Echo Lake
hits.description: There is a fee to access this area. Pets are permitted throughout the back trails in the Cathedral and White Horse areas only. You can see more on the pet policy here: https://www.nhstateparks.org/planning/pet-friendly-parks

hits.name: Mount Crawford via Davis Path Trail
Piper Trail
hits.description:
The Piper Trail is a challenging trail that summits Mt. Chocorua (3,500 ft.) in 4.3 miles and 2,700 ft. of elevation gain. 

Camp Penacook Shelter can be reached by following the Piper Trail for 2.8 miles to a marked spur trail leading to the 3-sided lean-to and outhouse.

The trail is named for Joshua Piper who blazed the trail and whose property the trail originally began from.

hits.name: Peaked Mountain Trail
hits.description: This trail will lead you up exposed granite slabs, past intermittent stands of red pine and pitch pine, and to the summit of Peaked Mountain. It offers excellent views of Middle Mountain, Black Cap, Mt. Chocorua, and the Moat Mountain range. The trail is blazed in yellow and blue. This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, skiing and snowshoeing, hunting, and observing wildlife. Camping, fires or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve, and all dogs must be on a leash.

hits.name: Old Bridle Path
hits.description: The trail starts out with an incline and there are a number of stairs to reach the top of the trail, the view is breathtaking, it's a panoramic view of Squam Lake, where On Golden Pond was filmed. Well worth the hike. The trail ends with a slight turn to the left, ending in a large rock ledge.

hits.name: Mount Tom, Avalon, and Field Loop
hits.description:
This is a loop trail with good views towards the southern presidentials.  You'll have really great views from Avalon to Webster Cliffs. Mt. Tom and Field are wooded, but Mt. Tom offers some views through the trees. 

Microspikes are really a must during the wintertime.

hits.name: Monadnock Mountain via Dublin Trail
hits.description:
The trailhead is located on Old Troy Rd, which often closes seasonally in the spring until muddy conditions subside.

There is a parking fee for this trailhead. No pets are allowed in Monadnock State Park.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson via Caps Ridge Trail
hits.description:
This park allows dogs, however, the hike is steep and rocky and you may need to assist your pet up and down rocks.

This is the highest trailhead in the White Mountains at 3,008 feet and also is the shortest with the least amount of elevation gain of any of the Presidentials.  This trailhead is in Jefferson Notch at the highest point in the Notch.   From Rte. 302 near Bretton Woods follow the Base Station Road which heads to the Cog Railroad up Mt. Washington.  Several miles down this road you will come to a 4 way intersection with Mt. Clinton Road to the South.  Take the left onto the Jefferson Notch Road which is closed in the winter and early spring.  Follow this for a couple miles keeping an eye out for the Caps Ridge Trailhead at the highest point in the Notch

hits.name: Mount Washington and Monroe via Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail
hits.description:
• There is a $5 fee per car.

Some scrambling can be required for this trail. Beware of icy conditions.

hits.name: Red Hill Fire Tower Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail is part of the Lakes Region Conservation Trust network of trails. The trail offers a steady climb through a forest setting. The trail is wide and well maintained. There are great views from the fire tower located at the top of Red Hill.

Hikers can find a private rest area at the trail Head of Red Hill Fire Tower and also organic food, drink, bug repellent, dog accessories and Corn Hole Game at the Red Hill Provisions.

hits.name: Sunapee Mountain via Andrew Brook Trail
hits.description: This route also reaches the popular White Cliffs Overlook.

hits.name: Potash Mountain
hits.description:
The trail begins with a stream crossing, depending on the water levels it can be difficult to find a way across without stepping in the brook.

The majority of the trail is a fairly moderate grade before one finally steep section leading to the summit of Potash Mountain.

hits.name: Liberty Trail and Brook Trail Loop to Mount Chocorua
hits.description:
While this loop can be hiked in either direction, users have reported hiking the route clockwise is the most popular direction. Sections of the trail are not well marked so downloading the map and keeping it accessible is helpful.

This route can be very challenging and treacherous in wet conditions, as much of the trail is made up of slick granite. 

Enjoy the 360-degree views from the top!

hits.name: Mount Eisenhower via Edmands Path Trail
Mount Moosilauke via Glencliff Trail and Appalachian Trail
Owl’s Head Path via Lincoln Brook Trail
Lake Massabesic Trail
hits.description: Parking is located at the Audobon Society parking lot.

hits.name: Table Rock Trail
hits.description: Trail is more precisely located in Dixville Notch, near the Balsams Resort.

hits.name: Hi-Cannon and Lonesome Lake Trails Loop
hits.description:
This is a great hike with interesting terrain and views. 

It is pretty consistently steep, and as a shorter trail you gain that elevation quickly. This route takes Hi-Cannon up and Lonesome Lake down. The trails are technically marked, but the markers are very old and worn away. However, don't worry, the trail is easy enough to follow where you shouldn't get lost. There are also signs at every intersection. 

Kinsman Ridge trail is extremely steep going down towards Lonesome Lake trail. You have to use your hands in a lot of places, and it may be difficult if you have a dog with you. The ladder section is fun. You are on the side of the mountain and have spectacular views with a couple pull-offs for breaks/photos. 

There is a look-out tower at the top, and because this is a ski mountain, there is also a lodge that has a snack bar, bar and bathrooms. It is only open seasonally, but if the doors are open you could at least warm up and take a break. There is also a tram that is open during ski season where you can get a one-way ticket down.

There are plenty of spots to enjoy the lake especially if you decide to take the trail around it, adding a little less than a mile.

hits.name: Indian Head Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins from the Indian Head Trailhead off Route 3/Daniel Webster Highway.

The trail climbs to the top of Mount Pemigewasset. The top has many tall granite ledges and has wonderful views of Franconia Notch.

Users have reported the trail can often be very wet following rain, and there is typically water running down the trail.

hits.name: Crystal Cascades
hits.description:
This is a short hike up the Tuckerman Ravine trail to Crystal Cascades. When you hear the word cascade, you think of a gently sloping rapids-like water feature.  Not here!  This waterfall has a total vertical drop of over 90 feet, with the upper falls being in the range of 70 plus feet and the lower falls being over 25 feet. 

The trail crosses the Cutler River below the falls...a nice spot to snap a few photos before seeing the gem on this short hike.  There is a nice viewing area directly opposite the falls so the falls are very easy to photograph.

hits.name: Mount Lafayette via Old Bridle Path
Nashua River Trail
hits.description:
This trail starts at Lincoln Park by the baseball diamonds. It heads east to Mine Falls Park then back southeast by the Mill Pond then back to Lincoln Park. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Coliseum Avenue at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), packed gravel, or natural surface (dirt with rocks and roots), and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a steep (8-12%) uphill section at about 0.1 miles when going south from the first bridge. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Piper, Belknap and Gunstock Loop
hits.description:
The trail can be hard to follow so you may want to download the offline map before you go. Parking is on Carriage Road off Belknap Mountain Road.

Three mountain loop hike in Belknap Mountain State Forest. This route includes Piper, Belknap, and Gunstock peaks.

hits.name: Wapack Trail and Marion Davis Trail
hits.description: Parts of the Marion Davis Trail and Wapack Trail pass through The Nature Conservancy's Joanne Bass Bross Preserve, 501 acres of wilderness conserved in 2001.  It's part of a 2,700-acre swath of contiguous conserved lands, including the Wapack National Fish and Wildlife Refuge on North Pack.

hits.name: Stinson Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This is a gradual climb that is good for beginner hikers in the White Mountains.

It has great views from the summit it can be enjoyed year-round. The trail is open to day use only, overnight camping is not allowed.

hits.name: Mount Cabot via Bunnell Notch Trail
hits.description:
Users have reported that the trails are not marked well and downloading the offline map before you go is recommended to get oriented. 

This wooded summit has some nice views on the way up to make up for it.

The summit is reached via the Bunnell Notch Trail which is more like an old wagon road through the woods and then joins the Kilkenny Ridge Trail to the summit. On the way, you will pass Bunnell Rock with great views to the south. The old Mt. Cabot Trail to the southwest is no longer open to the public so this is the easiest route to the top at just under 8 miles. If you are camping near the summit, the Cabot Cabin on the south end of the summit ridge offers a roof over your head but no heat source. Make sure to stop at the fish hatchery on the way out to check out some big fish in the ponds.

The fish hatchery locks the gate on the road leading to the trailhead from 4PM-8AM daily.

hits.name: Mount Tecumseh Trail via Tripoli Trailhead
hits.description:
One of the easier New Hampshire 4k mountains. 

The trail winds in and out of the woods on the Tecumseh Trail that brings hikers over a couple of brooks and fairly dense forest before reaching the summit with wide-open views.

hits.name: Mount Monroe Trail
hits.description: The view of Mt Washington and of the Southern Presidentials is wonderful. The trail is generally level for the first 2 miles at which time you will arrive at the gem pool. The last mile is very steep. Only the last 3/10ths of a mile is very exposed to the wind but in inclement weather that can be too much. Please remember that this is not a good place to hike in the winter.

hits.name: Mount Morgan Trail
hits.description: Mt. Morgan is a challenging and enjoyable trail located near Squam Lake. Towards the summit, there is a tall, wooden ladder that leads to a trail snaking through a cave. The peak offers great views of Squam Lake. Mount Major is viewable on the horizon.

hits.name: Piper Hammond Loop Trail
hits.description:
Fantastic view of peaked summit and surrounding mountains

The Piper trail is wide and very easy at the start.  It is well traveled and well maintained.  In the fall you will have excellent and exciting views of the summit and of the Carter ledge on your right.  

You need crampons in the winter.  It can be very windy at the top.  You have great views of the White Mountains including Mount Washington.

The Weetamoo rock trail can be a bit of a slog on the way down but there is a huge boulder to look at - hence the name. 

There are several streams on the Piper trail where you can replenish your water supply if you have a filter.

hits.name: Mount Eisenhower via Crawford Path
hits.description: The Crawford Path from Mt Clinton Rd is a decent incline with a mix of rock, tree roots, and soil. There is a $5 parking fee at the lot with envelope. You have to cross Mt Clinton Road and a creek begin the ascent. It can be a little difficult getting up Eisenhower, and there are sections where you will need to rock climb a bit. At the summit of Eisenhower there are amazing 360 views of several peaks of the Presidential Range. Be careful of changing weather as this hike can get very windy. Going down is a little bit harder than going up. Hikers suggest bringing plenty of water.

hits.name: North Pack Monadnock Mountain via Wapack Trail
Mount Whiteface via Blueberry Ledge Trail
hits.description:
Although dogs are allowed on this trail, users have reported it is not a great trail for dogs due to the steep, rocky nature of some sections of the trail.

The summit of Mount Whiteface is wooded and does not have great views, but there are several spots along the trail with openings that provide views of the area.

Hikers should be prepared for some scrambling sections and wear shoes with good traction.

hits.name: Cathedral Ledge via Bryce Path Trail
hits.description: You can also walk down the paved road from the overlook if you'd like.

hits.name: Mount Osceola Trail to Greeley Ponds Trail
hits.description:
Breathtaking vistas of Kancamagus wilderness with a steep incline. This hike will bring you to the highest peaks of the Sandwich Range with good views to the east despite wooded summits

This is a short but steep climb to get the tallest peak in the Sandwich Range and it's sister peak East Osceola.  Although both summits are wooded there are ledges on the way up East and a viewpoint towards the east from Mt. Osceola.  to get there you will take the Greely Pond Trail from the Kancamangus Highway to the Mt. Osceola trail which turns off to the west just before the ponds.

Price for parking on Tripoli Road has changed to $5.

hits.name: Mount Jackson and Mount Pierce via Webster Jackson Trail and Crawford Path
hits.description: This route can be done in either directions clockwise or counter clockwise. If you’re going counter clockwise and starting with Mount Jackson - it starts out with a long scramble up to the summit of Mount Jackson.  You will get awesome views and then a quick climb over to Pierce. The views at Pierce are breathtaking too, it can get very cold/windy when you reach the top so definitely pack layers.

hits.name: Piper Mountain and Old Piper Trail Loop
Mount Monadnock via White Arrow Trail
Mount Washington via Lion Head Trail
hits.description: In winter conditions the Tuckerman Ravine Trail is covered in snow and ice and is more like a winter alpine climb than a hike. Users should be prepared with equipment (ice axes, crampons, appropriate clothing) and skills to be in the mountains during the winter. Due to potential avalanche hazard, along with other objective hazards for the ravine the trail may close at points during the winter months, please check with the national forest or https://mountwashingtonavalanchecenter.org/ for more information.

hits.name: Mount Avalon
hits.description:
The hike begins from the Crawford Station parking area across the street from Saco Lake.

From the summit there are great views of the valley looking down Crawford Notch.

Spikes and trekking pokes are highly recommended during the winter months and into spring.

hits.name: Isinglass and Watson's Way Loop
hits.description:
Just south of Rochester, these short but beautiful trails make for a great family-friendly outing. Hikers will find a small parking area just off Rochester Neck Road. 

The route on this page is actually a combination of the three trails in the recreational area: Isinglass Trail, Locke's Loop, and Watson's Way. The route is only on Locke's Loop for a little bit, so if you'd like to extend your hike you could do the full loop.

If you'd like to hike further you could also continue south on the Isinglass Trail. This trail offers great views of the Isinglass River.

hits.name: Mount Isolation via Glen Boulder Trail
hits.description:
This trail has a bit of everything! Scrambles, views, forested sections, and unique geological features like the Glen Boulder.

The hike is a challenge with nearly constant climbing or descending, there are very few level sections of trail along this route.

hits.name: Oak Hill Tower Trail
hits.description: This trailhead includes parking for approximately ten cars. The trail departs right from the information kiosk. The trail is yellow blazed and easy to follow all the way to the top.  There's a picnic table near the tower to sit at if the flies aren't bad. Fantastic view in three directions when climbing up the tower stairs!

hits.name: Doublehead Ski Trail to North and South Doublehead
hits.description:
This loop begins starting on the ski trail and leads to the old path. From the summit of North Doublehead, head south to the summit of South Doublehead. Back over time north Doublehead and down the ski trail.

From the summit, there are great views of Mt. Washington and the surrounding White Mountains on a clear day.

hits.name: Mount Adams via Air Line Trail
hits.description:
This is a tough trail once you are above treeline and clambering up to Mt Adams proper. 

There are many giant rocks that are hard to traverse, especially on the way down. However, you will be rewarded with gorgeous views and a relatively quiet trail where you can truly connect with nature. 

Some parts can get very windy too so come prepared and enjoy!

hits.name: Lake of the Clouds from Mount Washington Summit via Crawford Path
Cascade Brook Trail to Lonesome Lake
hits.description:
There are several sections where the trail crosses a beautiful cascading brook. Depending on the water levels, hikers may need to step in the brook to safely cross.

In addition to the quiet and pristine Lonesome Lake, the trail also passes The Basin, a remarkable glacially formed waterfall.

hits.name: Manning Trail, Clark Trail, and Holt Trail Loop to Mount Cardigan
Flume and Liberty Loop
hits.description: Great hike up to Mount Liberty and Mount Flume. The first 7/10 are on the Franconia Notch Rail Trail to reach the Liberty Springs Trailhead. The trail Is fairly moderate until the brook crossing. At this point the trail gets fairly steep and It’s a climb from here. Nothing you can’t handle If you take your time. You hike right through the Liberty Springs tent sites that have a spring If you need water. Franconia Ridge Trail was similar to Liberty Springs In that you were climbing but again nothing too drastic. The views on top of Mount Liberty are tremendous; well worth the effort. Steep Initial descent off of Mount Liberty but then the trail moderates and flattens before climbing again to Mount Flume. This section is not as difficult as accessing Mount Liberty. Fine views towards the Kinsmans and Mount Moosilauke.

hits.name: Hi-Cannon Trail to Kinsman Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Great Views of Northern Presidentials.  AMC Hut and mountain lake.  4K Peak.

Park at the Lafayette Campground, and climb Hi-Cannon Tr up (yellow blazed).  It has some exposed rocky overlooks that allow you to appreciate the presidentials even before reaching the summit. 

Just before reaching the top, you will merge with Kinsman Ridge Trail for a very short distance.  At the top, enjoy the views from the observation tower.  There is an old/historic tramway that bring non-hikers to the summit.  

Once you enjoy the possibly crowded summit, return using the Kinsman Ridge in the south direction.  Go past the intersection with the Hi Cannon Tr, and on the next intersection with the Lonesome Lk Trail, turn left into it.

Soon you will discover that as rocky as Hi-Cannon Tr looked, it wasn't as difficult as Lonesome Lk Tr would have been on the way up in this section.  

You will reach the lake.  If you have time, it is worth going around it on a loop trail it has.  You may visit the Lonesome Lk AMC Hut.

hits.name: Uncanoonuc North Peak via White Dot Trail
hits.description: The summit can be accessed in several ways depending on what trail or trail head you choose to use.

hits.name: Mount Kinsman Trail to Bald Peak
hits.description:
Mt. Kinsman Trail to Bald Peak follows a fairly steady incline the entire way up, this is a great introductory White Mountains hike. It is a good option for families visiting the area for the first time who may have more ambitious hikes planned for later in their trip.

There are a few small creek crossings along the way, and the views from the summit are great!

hits.name: Lakes of the Clouds Trail
hits.description:
Lake of Clouds Hut is OPEN 8am-8pm as of 7/6/2020. 

Spectacular scenery and great ravine climb. 

The trail is generally level for the first 2 miles at which time you will arrive at the gem pool.  The last mile is VERY steep.  Only the last 3/10ths of a mile is very exposed to the wind but in inclement weather that can be too much!

Please remember that this is not a good place to hike in the winter and that Mt Washington has claimed over 125 lives.  If you must go, you must know what you are doing and how to save yourself.

hits.name: Mount Osceola via Greeley Pond Trail
hits.description:
This route to the summit of Mt. Osceola is a great option for someone who may be looking for a longer hike or someone who has already summited Osceola via the more popular Mt. Osceola Trail route.

On the route, hikers will summit East Osceola Peak in addition to Mt. Osceola. "The Chimney" is a steep section of the trail that is very rocky, so hikers should be prepared for some scrambling.

hits.name: Mount Cube via Cross Rivendell Trail
Pine Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Horton Center is on private property, owned and operated by the New Hampshire Conference of the United Church of Christ, located on top of Pine Mountain where church youth summer camp is held each summer during the months of June, July, and August. Retreats are also held on the property in the shoulder seasons during May, September and October. When summer camp is in session, hikers are asked not to come on the property (including Chapel Rock summit) in keeping with the safe camp policy and the guidelines of the American Camp Association, of which Horton Center is an accredited member site. 

During the non-summer season hikers are welcome to enjoy the steep climb up to, and stunning views at Chapel Rock, unless the sign is up across bottom of the stairs at the beginning Chapel Rock trail. It is asked that no one goes into the campus (other than hiking up to Chapel Rock) or the buildings at any time of year, unless prior arrangements have been made with the Horton Center’s Executive Director. 

It is asked that visitors please respect the wishes to keep camp private and stay on the designated trails which lead around and not through the campus. Also please respect privacy in the summer camp use of Chapel Rock, a sacred place to those who call Horton Center a spiritual home. 

Thank you for your care as you hike. If you would like to know more about Horton Center and it’s Outdoor Ministry check out the website at www.HortonCenter.org or email Tim Hughes at: thughes@NHCUCC.org

hits.name: Mount Shaw and Black Snout
hits.description: This trail can be made into a loop by traversing Big Ball Mountain (to the east) and then continuing on to Mount Shaw.

hits.name: Mount Lincoln via Little Haystack Mountain
Middle Sugarloaf Trail
hits.description:
This short hike rewards hikers with bigs view of Mt. Washington and the Presidential Range. 

This is a great hike for families or visitors who have not visited the White Mountains before and are looking for a fun warm-up hike.

hits.name: Mount Bond and Mount Guyot via Bondcliff Trail and Lincoln Woods Trail
hits.description:
The first and last 5 miles of this hike is a flat section of trail alongside the Pemigewasset River.

After this, the trail climbs up the Bondcliff Trail eventually reaching the peak of Mount Bond and Mount Guyot.

There are also backcountry campsites along this route with designated platforms to pitch a tent on.

hits.name: Echo Lake Trail
hits.description: Fee: $ 4 per person

hits.name: Lonesome Lake via Cascade Brook and Pemi Trail
Mount Washington Loop via Tuckerman Ravine Trail
hits.description:
Tuckerman Ravine is one of the most notable routes to the summit of Mt. Washington. Tuckerman is truly a beautiful, but steep and exposed path. 

After hiking out of the ravine, hikers will gain the ridge leading to the top of Washington. The final 1/2 mile is very rocky and involves stepping on top of large boulders. 

Since Mt. Washington is home to the world's worst weather, hikers should be prepared for all types of conditions even in the middle of summer.

hits.name: West and East Rattlesnake Mountain via Old Bridle Path
Drakes Brook Trail to Jennings Peak
hits.description:
Counter-clockwise is the way to go if you'd like to get the climbs in and steep parts out early. The descent is more enjoyable and mellow traveling in this direction.

Great views from Noon and Jennings!  This trail is amazing once the leaves have fallen and the views really open up. You can also see Mount Washington off in the distance.

hits.name: Crotched Mountain from Greenfield Road
hits.description:
This trail is generally well marked but the summit is not as well marked. 

This is a gorgeous loop and overall a beautiful trail, well marked with great views. The first and last 2 miles are easy. Follow the trail past a pond with Lily pads, cross a stream with frogs and tadpoles, on your way up pass several perfect spots to sit for a snack to watch the clouds dance across the sky above rolling mountains of green trees swaying in the wind. On a clear day, you could see Boston far away. Perfect in the fall to see the foliage and in the spring to explore the vernal pools.

hits.name: Jennings Peak and Sandwich Mountain Trail Loop
hits.description:
Users have suggested the route is best taken counterclockwise. 

The best views will be from the summit of Jennings Peak, the summit of Sandwich Mountain is mostly wooded with a large cairn marking the summit. 

The trail can remain pretty muddy throughout the summer into fall and there is a creek crossing, so hikers should be prepared to get their feet wet. Overall, this is a great route that crosses three summits and is a good option for those looking for a hike with less traffic than a NH 4K peak.

hits.name: Crawford Notch Trail
hits.description: This is the oldest, continuously used path in North America.

hits.name: Rattlesnake Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The loop begins near a stream and then leads to a short but steep climb to the summit of Rattlesnake Mountain. From the summit, there are great views of the surrounding valley. 

The parking area is small and can be very busy.

hits.name: Jewell Trail
hits.description:
The Cog Railway, which owns the parking area, charges for parking. 

For current rates please visit: https://www.thecog.com/information-for-hikers

hits.name: Greenleaf Hut via Old Bridal Path
North Kinsman Via Mt Kinsman Trail
hits.description:
Parking at the trailhead in winter may be limited, the lot is not regularly plowed.

The first two miles of the hike are relatively flat, with the majority of the elevation gain coming during the third and fourth miles on the ascent. 

Tent sites are located at Kinsman Pond for those who would like to spend a night out enjoying the tranquility of the area. 

For those looking to tick off another 4K peak, South Kinsman is less than a mile past the summit of North Kinsman.

hits.name: North Kinsman, South Peak and Cannon Balls Loop Trail
hits.description:
Complete 3 peaks of the Northeast 111 in a tough & beautiful day-hike loop:
Cannon Mountain 4,100'
North Kinsman Mountain 4,293'
South Kinsman Mountain 4,358'

Start from the trailhead and immediately up the HI-Cannon Trail (featured as a 'Terrifying 25' Club elective trail) until reaching Cannon Mountain tower. Continue back, this time taking the Kinsman Ridge Trail to a 4 corners junction, continuing 'right' on KRT to North Kinsman Mountain. (One large rock outcrop on 'left' for great views). Continue on an out & back mission to South Kinsman Mountain, returning past N. Kinsman and four corners junction. This time, taking the Fishin' Jimmy Trail to Lonesome Lake Trail back to trailhead.

A great loop for any peak-baggers trying to tackle a strenuous day of three. Enjoy!

hits.name: Bondclif Trail to Franconia Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Three days, two nights, 10,000ft of elevation gain, some of the most punishing terrain and.. totally worth it! Make no mistake, this hike is difficult. Can be done in a day for very experienced hikers. As hard as this hike is, it's just as rewarding. Walking along the Franconia Ridge just under the clouds, looking at the landscape is an experience that at times can feel like being transported to Middle Earth. 

Parking at Lincoln Woods is $5 per day, and if you stay at any of the campsites it is $10 for the night. The loop and campsites can be very crowded so if you want a tent platform make sure to get to the sites early. There are two AMC huts along the loop as options to stay for the night, you need a reservation in advance.

hits.name: Mount Willey Trail
hits.description:
A difficult hike up and down this 4,285 foot New Hampshire peak.

This 4,285' peak near Crawford Notch is a fairly easy climb.  It could also be climbed from Crawford Notch State Park along with Tom and Field if so desired in an easy loop but approaching it from the south gives another perspective as well.  The ascent is pretty well maintained and even has a section of wooden steps to assist you in your climb. At the top you'll have great views across the notch to Webster Cliffs and the southern presidentials including Jackson and perhaps Eisenhower.  There is a cairn at the top marking the true summit which is a little beyond the viewpoint over the notch.

hits.name: Mount Sunapee Summit
hits.description: A beautiful view of Lake Solitude!

hits.name: Table Mountain via Attitash Trail
hits.description:
The trail is a steady incline before a few steeper spots approaching the top. At the summit, there are several ledges with views of Mount Chocorua and Mount Passaconaway. 

Users have reported the top of the trail is made of very loose rock that can be tricky to walk on. Shoes with good traction is encouraged.

hits.name: Mount Klem and Mount Mack via Gilford Fire Road and Round Pond Trail
hits.description:
Users report that the directions via Google or Apple Maps are wrong- follow along Bickford Rd until you come to signs that direct you to the trailhead.

There is a limited amount of parking at the trailhead- if it is full, please do not park alongside the road and instead head to another closeby trail.

hits.name: Cathedral Ledge via Cathedral Ledge Road
hits.description: This route is a paved road up to Cathedral Ledge. There are hiking trails up to Cathedral Ledge that can also be found on AllTrails.

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge Trail
hits.description:
You'll have great views of Mt. Washington and the Presidential Range across the valley.

Visitors have reported sections of the trail are often muddy even throughout the summer and fall months. Some sections are quite steep and involve some scrambling.

hits.name: Mount Eisenhower and Mount Pierce
hits.description: Climb to the summit of Mount Eisenhower and then over the presidential ridge to Mount Pierce (formerly Mount Clinton) and back down. Leave a car at each end of the hike or this will turn into 16.2 miles out and back or a return hike via the road.

hits.name: Turtleback Mountain and Brook Walk Trail Loop
hits.description:
Often called "The Little Yosemite of the East" this fantastic short trail provides breathtaking views of five of the most beautiful New Hampshire waterfalls: Song of Fall, Briddle Veil Falls, Roaring Falls, Twin Falls and Whittier Falls. The trail is very well-marked, and most of the trail runs along the water.

Located within the Castle in the Clouds Conservation Area, near Moultonborough. This trail can be combined with the longer Mount Roberts trail. There is a nice parking area with a large map showing all of the surrounding trails. 

This trail is great if you’re a waterfall lover, but not so much if you are looking for mountaintop views. You may want long clothes as there can be a lot of ticks in this area.

hits.name: Mount Cabot Loop
hits.description:
The Bunnell Notch Trail is now the only trail leading directly to the summit of Mount Cabot. This loop adds on some other terrific terrain, users will also be summiting The Horn and passing by Unknown Pond before leading back to the trailhead.

The fish hatchery closes the gate on the road leading to the trailhead from 4 pm-8 am daily.

Users have also reported GPS having issues locating the trailhead, please review the GPS destination before departing.

hits.name: Mount Cube via the Appalachian Trail
Peaked Mountain and Middle Mountain Loop
Mount Shaw, Black Snout and Big Ball Mountain Loop
hits.description: This is an easy trail to lose. There are lots of old logging trails and rogue trails that are in better shape than the official trail. The hike is best if you stay close to the brook on the way up.

hits.name: Black Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The Black Mountain Trail is relatively flat for the first mile before it begins to climb up the ridge towards the summit. The summit is wide open and has great views on a clear day.

The trail can be quite muddy in the spring and after rain.

hits.name: Mount Kearsarge via Rollins and Lincoln Trail
hits.description: This short trail starts from the parking lot at the end of the Rollins State Park auto road and climbs to meet the Lincoln Trail just below the summit of Mount Kearsarge. The Rollins trail is the easiest way to the summit and the total distance from the parking lot to the summit is about 0.6 mile. The trail starts as a crushed gravel path, crossing a few small bridges as it passes through the picnic area. It then ascends via easy to moderate grades as it climbs along the old route of a carriage path. It meets the Lincoln Trail, which ascends 0.1 mile to the open summit over bare ledge.

hits.name: Heads Pond
hits.description: A nice flat rail trail. Takes you to two ponds along the way.

hits.name: Mount Isolation Via Rocky Branch Trail
hits.description:
Users have reported sections of the trail do not drain very well and are oftentimes wet.

For those who would like to do the route in two days/1 night, there is a tent site at the junction of the Rocky Branch and Isolation Trail.

This route is considered to be challenging but has stunning 360-degree views from the summit.

hits.name: Mount Hight to Carter Dome to North Carter Loop
hits.description:
Includes trail info for Middle and South Carter Summits.

If traveling up 19 Mile Brook Trail to Carter Dome Trail to Carter-Moriah Trail, it is an easier grade than going up the Imp Trail to Carter-Moriah Trail and thus can be summited faster.

Going up the first route is easier and unique from other New England trails due to the use of switch backs (zig zagged trails that work up the face of a mountain reducing a steep climb rather than a straight trail up).

hits.name: Zealand Hut Trail
hits.description:
The trail is mostly flat until the last .2 of a mile leading to the hut. The trail can be muddy seasonally with some stream crossings. Zealand Falls Hut is a good place to stop to rest and refuel.

The ponds next to the trail are a great place to spot wildlife. A moose or two has certainly been spotted in this area before!

hits.name: Blueberry Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This route to the summit of Blueberry Mountain begins from the south trailhead.

The peak is semi-wooded, hikers will get the best views from the trail along the way. Mount Moosilauke is the most visible peak along the way. Much of the trail is rocky and exposed granite slabs, and shoes with good traction are encouraged.

hits.name: Liberty Springs Trail
hits.description: From the Whitehouse Trail, 0.8 mi. north of the Flume parking area, the Liberty Spring Trail climbs east as part of the Appalachian Trail to join the Franconia Ridge Trail near the summit of Mt. Liberty.  The trail is 3.5 miles to the top of Mt. Liberty.

hits.name: White Cliff Overlook via Newbury Trail
Mount Whiteface and Mount Passaconaway Loop Trail
hits.description:
Some of the best views will be from the summit of Whiteface and along the ridgeline.

There are some steep, rocky sections leading to the summit of Whiteface that users have reported formerly had a ladder equipped which is no longer there.

Dogs are welcome to use this trail, but some sections are very steep and could be very challenging for dogs.

hits.name: Galehead Mountain via Gale River Trail
hits.description:
Located on the Gale River Road (FR 92) off of Rte. 3 in Twin Mountain. Gale River Road is unplowed in winter. 

There are some brook crossings, so hikers should be prepared to get their feet wet. Stop at the Galehead Hut to rest and enjoy the views!

The first 3.5 miles of the hike are a steady climb before the grade gets steeper pushing towards the summit.

hits.name: B18 Bomber Crash Site Via Walker Brook
Baldface Circle Trail to Emerald Pool
hits.description:
Beautiful trail wandering through the forest with a couple of stream crossings. Emerald Pool is a great swimming hole so don't forget a towel to dry off afterward.

The trailhead is located across the street from the parking lot and up the road and on the left.

hits.name: Windham Rail Trail
hits.description:
This is a great flat, well-paved and maintained trail, that is also shaded all the way. It is a perfect option to go with family or for an easy, long ride. 

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Manning Street at the northwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a  striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are bollards at street crossings along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Stanton Trail
hits.description:
The Mount Stanton Trail is a great trail for those visiting the White Mountains for the first time. The trail is mostly moderate with two sections of climbing. 

There are a few sections to watch out for where the trail is composed of loose rocks/gravel.

From the summit there are wonderful views of the southern Presidential Range.

hits.name: Mount Chocorua and Carter Ledge Loop
hits.description:
It is recommended to go up Carter Ledge Trail versus trying to descend the trail.

There is a very steep and rocky section of trail on Carter Ledge that is extremely challenging to downclimb.

The views from the summit are there to reward hikers after the climb up!

hits.name: North Twin, South Twin, and Galehead Mountain
hits.description:
North Twin Trail is a 8.2 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail that features a river and is sometimes rated as difficult. North Twin Spur adds 1.1 miles to the summit of South Twin. These trails are primarily used for hiking and snowshoeing and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use these trails. 
Begin at the North Twin parking lot at the end of Haystack Road in Bethlehem, NH.
There are 3 river crossings within the first 2 miles of this hike, which could be challenging if water levels are high. 
If preferred to do less water crossings - there is an unmarked side trail that skips the first 2 crossings, that begins at what would be the 1st crossing. Instead of crossing you continue straight at this point, following very close to the left side of the river. It's well-worn, easy to follow, and will allow you to avoid the first two water crossings. The real trail joins it again another 0.5 miles up. At 1.9 miles you have no choice but to make the 3rd river crossing.
The first 2.8 miles of North Twin Trail are easy going, and the last 1.3 are a steeper climb. Don't be fooled by the rocky area with a great view at 3.9 miles, as North Twin's actual peak is marked with a sign and a cairn within the tress further up, and there's an outlook spur offering fantastic views just past that as well.
From North Twin over to South Twin is an easy trek and the 300 feet of elevation and 1.3 miles are worth it, as South Twin's peak is exposed and offers more views of the surrounding area.
To continue over to South Twin Mountain, continue hiking along the same trail, that changes from North Twin Trail to North Twin Spur. You will reach the summit after 1.2 miles. 
To get back to the parking lot, retrace your steps for 5.5 miles.

hits.name: Mount Pierce and Mizpah Hut Loop
Lincoln Woods Trail
Mount Madison via Valley Way Trail
hits.description:
The Valley Way Trail is a direct route to the Madison Spring Hut. Continue past the hut a short distance on the Gulfside Trail to the summit of Mount Madison.

This is a popular day hike, but accommodations can be made ahead of time through the Appalachian Mountain Club to stay at the Madison Spring Hut. Tent sites are available at the Valley Way Campsite.

Even if you're not staying at the hut, it is a good place to rest and refuel before the descent down.

hits.name: Nashua River Rail Trail: Nashua to Ayer
hits.description:
A beautiful, gentle trail through wooded areas, ponds, swamps, farms, and fields. There may be natural debris on the trail after storms.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Glison Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom at the north end of the trail.

hits.name: Mount Moriah via Stony Brook Trail
hits.description:
The first 2 miles of this hike is a fairly flat walk in the woods along a beautiful brook. 

After 2 miles, the terrain steepens and looks more like classic White Mountain terrain by mile 3.
