At the Carter Moriah / AT junction visitors are greeted with a succession of amazing ledge views and lookouts before traveling the last few hundred feet of vertical and traversing the ridge to Moriah summit.

Users have reported the summit spur is easy to miss, so keeping your eyes peeled to your left along the CM / AT is important.

hits.name: Sweet Trail
hits.description:
Four miles long from Longmarsh Road in Durham to the Great Bay Estuary in Newmarket, the Sweet Trail leads hikers by a remarkable array of upland forests, freshwater wetlands and tidal salt marsh. 

The Sweet Trail winds its way from second generation forests to Great Bay,  a unique estuarine ecosystem of local, regional, and national significance.  The estuary provides a rich aquatic habitat that supports more than 150 rare plant and animal species, and 55 exemplary natural communities.

hits.name: Welch Mountain Rock Ledge
hits.description:
This is a great hike for those visiting the White Mountains and who are looking for a relatively short and rewarding hike before trying longer hikes.

The trail leads up to a large ledge of exposed granite with views of the surrounding area. This is a great place to see the famous White Mountain fall foliage.

hits.name: Mount Passaconaway via Dicey's Mill Trail
hits.description:
By New Hampshire 4K peak standards, the Dicey's Mill Trail to the summit of Mt. Passaconaway is considered moderate. The trail is well maintained, but like most peaks in the White Mountains, the last stretch of trail leading to the summit is rocky.

Another 1/4 mile past the summit following the Walden Trail there is a wonderful viewpoint.

hits.name: Bondcliff, Mount Bond, and West Bond
South Uncanoonuc via Summit Trail and Walker Trail
hits.description:
Awesome walk in the woods that takes you up a mountain! The view at the summit  is beautiful but easy to miss, take a left on the way down Incline trail to get there. 

This is a short route but pretty much an incline all the way to the summit, so it might be on the harder side of easy.

hits.name: Mount Percival
hits.description: The last half mile is all rock and ledge which makes it closer to hard than moderate. It is also all uphill - much of it steep. Finally, if you do take the cave option to reach the top please know that it is very difficult to get in and out of the cave and scale the rock to the top.

hits.name: Skatutakee and Thumb Mountains
hits.area_name: Carpenter Marsh State Wildlife Management Area

hits.name: North Mountain and Boulder Trail Loop
Mount Kearsarge via Winslow Trail
hits.description:
When the parking lot is closed, the next nearest parking area is about half a mile away so you will have additional mileage to your trip.

This trail is steep and rocky, but has a 360 view at the top.

hits.name: Cascade Path, Upper Snows Mountain, and Beanbender Loop
hits.description:
This trail winds through the forest and across the ski slopes at Waterville Valley Ski Resort.

The Cascade Trail will lead to Cascade Brook where hikers will come across a waterfall. The Upper Snows Mountain and Beanbender Trail will lead back down the mountain and towards the trailhead.

hits.name: Swope Loop (Blue)
hits.description: The orange trail past the pond is private property.

hits.name: Copple Crown Mountain
hits.description:
To access this trail, you will need to park at Moose Mountain Recreation and hike or snowmobile to the trailhead.

This trail is pretty well marked and maintained.  It's a nice moderate incline for almost the entire hike.

hits.name: Serendipity Loop Trail
hits.description: Trailhead has very limited parking and parking on the road is not permitted.

hits.name: Iron Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Please do NOT use the old trail. It has been closed and brushed in but it may still show up on old maps. 

Please use the new trail that was finished in 2021 and help protect this beautiful environment and trail for years to come.

Users have reported that the road leading to the trailhead can be difficult for 2WD vehicles.

hits.name: Cannon Mountain Loop Trail
hits.description:
Aside From Echo Lake Beach, Franconia Notch is not a "Day Use" area so reservations are not required to access hiking trails.

It is a nice challenging hike without being too long. There is some scrambling to reach the top of the cannon, but the views from the tower are amazing.

hits.name: Mount Garfield Trail
hits.description:
The hike begins with a fairly flat section for the first 3 miles before it begins to climb up. From the summit, there are 360-degree views of the area.

The Appalachian Trail crosses the summit of Mount Garfield, so the summit can be very crowded in the summer months with thru-hikers and section hikers.

Microspikes and poles are recommended during the shoulder seasons when snow and ice could be lingering at higher elevations.

hits.name: Black Mountain via Chippewa Trail
hits.description:
This trail is well marked and VERY steep! There is also a marked side trip along the way (beginning)  you can check out some old Lyme Kilns - hence the name Lyme Kiln Rd where the trail head is located - they are a marked historic sight.

The beginning of the trail is on private property, so hikers should be respectful when crossing through this easement.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson, Adams, and Madison Trail
hits.description:
This trek traverses three massive Presidential Range peaks.

This is the shortest and easiest way to climb all 3 major Northern Presidential Peaks in a day.  The Caps Ridge Trail up Mt. Jefferson is steep, and requires a few scrambles over ledges on the way up that have some exposure so it is not for the feint of heart.  This 2.5 mile trail will put you up onto the top of Jefferson and onto the ridge which you will follow above treeline all the way to Madison and Back.  This entire route is above treeline so make sure the weather is good before continuing.  

You'll reach Mt. Jefferson (5,715'), Mt. Adams (5,798'), and Mt. Madison 5,363').  You will have the option of jogging over to the top of Mt. Quincy Adams if you'd like too as well as the opportunity to check out a famous AMC hut nestled between the peaks.

hits.name: Mount Kearsarge via Barlow Trail
hits.description:
Dates and times are weather dependent and subject to change without notice. For up to date hours, please call the park directly. This park is always open for recreation unless otherwise posted. During off hours and the off-season the park is typically not staffed, comfort stations are not available and gates may be closed. 

Gates Closed Winter Months -  (as of November 15). It will re-open in spring as weather permits.
Operating hours 8am-6pm
Unstaffed 10/21

The off-season poses unique risks inherent when participating in outdoor recreational activities. Please be aware that many State Park areas and trails are not staffed during the off-season, and day-use fees are not collected. Recreationists should possess the necessary knowledge, skill, and equipment to ensure their own safety. Users assume all risk while recreating in State Park lands.

hits.name: Bald Knob and Turtleback Mountain Loop
Moat Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Shortly after leaving the trailhead the Moat Mountain Trail passes the popular swimming spot, Diana's Baths.

Here, visitors will find several deep pool and cascades along Lucy Brook. This is the perfect place to take a dip after hiking!

The trail leads to the top of North Moat Mountain with views of the surrounding area.

Users have reported there is no overflow parking in the area, so if the lot if full please find another hike. The local police will ticket cars parked on West Side Road.

hits.name: Thompson Falls Trail
hits.description:
The Thompson Falls Trail begins to the left of the lodge at Wildcat Ski Resort.

This is a great family and pet-friendly hike perfect for visitors of all ages.

hits.name: Pondicherry Nature Refuge via Presidential Range Rail Trail
hits.description:
Information provided is from the Silvio O. Conte NWR website for the Pondicherry Division:

The Division sits in a basin surrounded by the Kilkenny Range to the north; Presidential Range to the east; Dartmouth/Pliny Range to the South; and, the Dalton Hills to the west. Within the bounds of the Refuge is a complex mix of habitats including boreal forests, forested bogs, northern hardwoods/conifers, riparian communities, an abundance of early succession from recent timber harvests, and open water. This concentration of diverse, high quality habitats acts as a magnet to wildlife, especially birds.

Over the years volunteers and biologists have documented 234 different bird species on the Refuge with 128 confirmed nesters. Breeding songbirds are especially well represented with 22 warbler species, seven sparrows, and six thrushes, among others. In addition, there are fourteen amphibian species, six reptiles, and a number of mammals including black bear, moose, white-tailed deer, beaver, and northern bog lemmings.

Hunting, fishing, wildlife observation and photography, environmental education, and interpretation are priority public uses on national wildlife refuges as defined by Executive Order 12996 (March 25, 1996) and the National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966, as amended by the National Wildlife Refuge System Improvement Act of 1997 (Public Law 105-57). Visitors have an opportunity to experience each of these at the Pondicherry Division.

Refuge-specific hunting regulations will become effective September 1, 2005. Generally speaking, these mirror New Hampshire Fish and Game Department regulations with minor exceptions. During the open seasons people may hunt moose, white-tailed deer, waterfowl (Cherry and Little Cherry ponds, and the posted area between them are all closed to hunting), and small game. Hunters need to be familiar with Refuge regulations before going out into the field. Motorized and mechanized vehicles are not permitted on the Refuge.

Anglers at the Pondicherry Division must comply with the state fishing regulations. Although Pondicherry is not sought out by most anglers, Cherry Pond and the Johns River do offer recreational fishing opportunities, and people may fish on any of the other streams and ponds on the Refuge. Chain pickerel and sunfish are the principal game fish on the Refuge.

Most visitors come to the Refuge because it is well known as a place to see moose, bear, a multitude of breeding birds, and spectacular views of the surrounding mountain ranges. People can hike, ski, or snowshoe anywhere on the Refuge to view and photograph wildlife, flowers, and the scenery. At this time there are two primitive trails on the Refuge. Cherry Pond is linked to Little Cherry Pond by a loop trail that winds through a forested bog community. A series of bog bridges were installed by the Friends of Pondicherry to protect the saturated bog soils. The second trail is a section of the Cohos Regional Trail. It enters the Refuge from the east off Whipple Road, leads to Cherry Pond, then exits near Highway 115 in the southeast corner.

Pondicherry is an unstaffed division of the Conte Refuge, and as such, programs are not typically offered by Refuge employees. However, there is an active Friends Group that hosts several environmental events during the year, including an annual birding trip on International Migratory Bird Day in May. Other groups are encouraged to use the Refuge for environmental education and interpretation purposes, but need to contact the Refuge Manager ahead of time.

Hiking is allowed throughout Pondicherry. Motorized and mechanized vehicles, bicycles, and horses are not permitted on trails within the refuge boundary. All dogs must be accompanied and under control, and not pose a threat or nuisance to Refuge wildlife or visitors. Contact the refuge manager regarding activities not discussed on this page.

hits.name: White Ledge Loop Trail
hits.description:
A moderate hike with nice views at the top. Parking is limited, so get there early. You will be parking at a White Ledge Campground from May - October (November - April parking is available on Route 16 with a short walk through campground to trailhead.). Most spaces are reserved for campers.  

It is recommended that you start your hike counterclockwise. When you finish you'll be glad you did. Bring water, snack and a smile. 

This is a great introductory White Mountain hike for families. Enjoy!

hits.name: Mount Major and Mount Straightback Loop
Caps Ridge Trail
hits.description:
The Caps Ridge Trailhead is the highest elevation trailhead in the White Mountains, beginning at 3,008 ft. 

The Caps Ridge Trail leads into the alpine zone and the summit of Mount Jefferson.

hits.name: Mount Madison and Adams via the Valley Way Trail
hits.description:
Hikers will summit two of the NH 48 on this route, Mount Adams and Madison. This route can also be done as an overnight for those who are looking to camp.

Tent sites are available at the Valley Way Campsite and bunks at the Madison Spring Hut. Reservations for the hut should be made though the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance. 

Hikers should be prepared for all conditions, even in summer months!

hits.name: Dam Road to Tupelo and Old City Trail
hits.description: Beaver Brook offers 35 miles of trails accessed by 10 different trailheads. There are trails near rivers, ponds, streams, and small waterfalls. There are trails that range from easy to moderate as the elevation gain is not great on any of the trails. There are trails for hiking, snowshoeing

hits.name: Gunstock Mountain Trail (Orange)
hits.description: This trail ranges between a high moderate and low difficult.

hits.name: Zealand Bonds Traverse
hits.description:
An absolutely stunning traverse across the summit of Mt. Zealand, Guyot, and the Bonds.

This hike is often done as an overnight backpacking trip or in one big push in a day. 

Day hikers can stop at Zealand Falls hut for water and there's often food available for purchase.

hits.name: Mount Tripyramid via Pine Bend Brook Trail
hits.description:
Great views into Waterville Valley and south to east.

The Pine Bend Brook Trail is nearly flat for the first two miles with six stream crossings, then becomes quite steep through an area with nice views through hardwood forest.  It continues to be steep up to the junction with Scaur Ridge Trail.  There is a nice ridge walk for a bit, then up again to the north peak with nice views to the south.  Middle peak has the better views, extending from west, south & east.

Climbing back up to the north peak required sidestepping, as it was too steep to walk straight down. The last two miles are flat.

hits.name: Tin Mountain Trail
hits.description: Conservation land that is dog friendly. Includes Tin Mine.

hits.name: Catamount Hill Trail and One Mile Trail Loop
Mount Lafayette, Little Haystack Mountain, Mount Liberty, and Mount Flume Loop
Belknap Fire Tower (Red/Green Loop) Trail
hits.description: Belknap Fire Tower offers a great view of the surrounding area. There is also a plane crash site just down the back side of the mountain from the fire tower. The crash is a little hard to get to, but very cool.

hits.name: Straightback Mountain and Mount Anna via Main Trail (Blue) and Anna-Goat (Red)
Kancamagus Highway Scenic Drive
hits.description:
A nice paved highway with many scenic overlooks, hiking trails and swimming spots in the river. The road has a generous shoulder for many sections.

This scenic drive goes from Lincoln, NH to Conway, NH through the heart of the White Mountains. 

Notable sites along the road include the Pemigewasset River, Swift River, and Forest Service camgrounds including Jigger Johnson and Passaconaway Campground.

hits.name: Mount Moosilauke via Gorge Brook Trail - Winter Route
hits.description:
This is the best route to the summit of Mount Moosilauke during the winter months when Ravine Road is closed. The road is closed as early as November some years and can remain closed until late April/early May.

From the summit of Moosilauke there are amazing views of surrounding lakes and mountains.

hits.name: Wapack and Cliff Trail
hits.description: The trails are very well marked with steep inclines in certain areas but enough plateaus for you to catch your breath. Beautiful views along the entire hike, with multiple viewing offshoots. The Cliffs are a great place to stop and have lunch.

hits.name: Mount Pierce, Jackson, and Webster Loop
hits.description:
A climb up the two southernmost peaks of the Presidential Range

This is a great loop trail that will take you up Mt. Webster and along the mountain's cliffs on the way up, then head over the partially bare summit of Mt. Jackson, past the AMC Mitzpah Hut and then to the top of semi-wooded Mt. Pierce.  You'll return via the southern end of the Crawford Path back down to Crawford Notch.

hits.name: Mount Success via Appalachian Trail
hits.description: Awesome but challenging hike, especially on a wet day!  There is a plane crash site about a mile away from the summit.  Follow the trail past the summit to the orange blazes...look carefully so you don't miss them.

hits.name: Mount Major
hits.description:
The primary hiking access and parking for Mount Major is located on NH Route 11 in Alton which serves as the trailhead for the Brook Trail Loop and the Southern Loop Trail (Orange to Blue).

You can find the Brook Trail Loop here:
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/mount-major-and-brook-trail-loop 
You can find the Southern Loop Trail (Orange to Blue) here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/mount-major-southern-loop-trail

hits.name: Square Ledge in Pinkham Notch
hits.description:
The Square Ledge Trail takes about 30 mins to reach the summit.  About half way there is the weird "hangover" rock cave.  

The summit is at an elevation of 2300 feet.  The views of Mt. Washington and the Presidential Range are superb from the top of the ledge.

hits.name: Magalloway Mountain
hits.description: A short little hike with incredible views! The actual fire tower is quite stable to climb and provides the best view point. Follow the side trail to the left of the tower to get an additional view. Go to Garfield Falls for a great swimming spot for the kids.

hits.name: North Twin Trail
hits.description:
The hike begins with two miles of relatively flat hiking along a creek before climbing to the summit of North Twin Mountain over the third and fourth mile. 

The hike begins along a river which is a great place to cool off during the summer months!

There are a few stream crossings, so visitors should anticipate getting their feet wet.

hits.name: Big Ball Mountain Trail
hits.description: Starts in an unmarked parking lot and follows the Shaw Mt Trail until just after the start of the river.  The trail breaks off and heads to the right and is marked with green and red or blue and red blazes.

hits.name: Mount Franklin and Mount Eisenhower via Edmands Path
hits.description:
Hikers will begin in the woods before reaching the White Mountain's famous alpine zone. Hikers should be prepared for all types of weather year-round in the alpine zone.

Once the trail reaches the ridge line and Crawford Path it will lead first to the summit of Mt. Eisenhower and then backtrack and continue on the ridge towards Mt. Franklin.

hits.name: Smarts Mountain via Appalachian and Ranger Trail
hits.description: Leaving from the trailhead on Dorchester Road, hikers will climb up the Appalachian Trail to the summit of Smarts Mountain. After enjoying the views from the top head back down the Appalachian Trail for a short distance before meeting the Smarts Ranger Trail. Follow the Ranger Trail back down to the triailhead.

hits.name: Mount Shannon Trail
hits.description: Mt. Shannon, located south of the bulk of the Belknap Range, features views in multiple directions from near its summit.

hits.name: Tucker and French Mill Pond Loop
Lost Pond Trail
hits.description:
This trail is short and gentle and Lost Pond is enchanting.

This is a great trail for visitors of all ages and pets.

hits.name: Blodgett Hill and Rocky Trail Loop
Upper Greeley Ponds via Kancamagus Highway
hits.description:
The trail to Greeley Ponds is very well cared for, but can be muddy seasonally or after it rains. Greeley Ponds is a great place to have a family picnic and do some fishing. There are a few small stream crossings along the trail. 

Camping or campfires are not permitted within a 1/4 mile of Greeley Ponds.

hits.name: U.N.H. Trail
hits.description:
The U.N.H. Trail is a great White Mountains moderate hike. As is typical for the area, hikers can expect some steep climbs, rocks, roots, and some wonderful views of the surrounding mountains!

The hike begins just off the Kancamagus Highway and the trail will lead users over the top of Hedgehog Mountain.

hits.name: South and Middle Moat Mountain
hits.description:
Visitors can expect 360-degree views from the summit of both South and Middle Moat Mountain. 

The first 1 1/2 miles is relatively flat before another 1 1/2 mile climb up the Moats. 

Much of the trail is made of exposed granite which can be very slippery. It is not recommended to hike to the summit following any rain.

hits.name: Imp Trail
hits.description: This route is a leisurely brookside stroll for about 3/4 of a mile then becomes steeper and rockier.  The views of the presidentials are spectacular. There are multiple water crossings along the way that may not be possible for small dogs.

hits.name: Mount Washington Summit Loop Trail
hits.description:
An excellent hike if you want to see lots of mount Washington without spending much time in the trees.  The views are spectacular, the terrain is rugged.

Mt. Washington has some of the worst recorded weather on the planet.  It can change very quickly so be prepared.  Tuckerman's ravine is always impressive.  If you are scared of heights then do not attempt to drive up the auto road.  It is narrow.

hits.name: Mount Crawford, Stairs Mountain and Mount Resolution
Blueberry Mountain via Stone House Trail
hits.description:
Downloading the offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

This trailhead begins near Shell Pond and climbs up the south ridge of Blueberry Mountain via the Stone House Trail.

hits.name: Carter Notch Hut, Dome, and 19 Mile Brook Trail
hits.description:
Great day hike! Carter Notch is especially beautiful in the fall and Mount Hight has amazing 360 views of the Presidentials.

Carter Notch Hut is a good place to stop and rest by the lake. For visitors who would like to spend a night at the hut, accommodations must be made in advance through the Appalachian Mountain Club.

hits.name: Mount Tremont Trail
hits.description:
There is parking available on the side of the road to access the trailhead. 

Most of the trail is shaded in the summer months. The trail hikes alongside a creek for the first half of the climb up. The last mile of the trail is steep but there are several switchbacks to make the grade easier to climb.

hits.name: Kingman Farm Nature Trail
hits.description: The parking lot for this trail is at Madbury Town Hall.

hits.name: Wantastiquet Natural Area Summit Trail
hits.description: Follows a former quarry road with steady uphill climb.

hits.name: Middle Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This trail climbs 1200 feet to the summit of Middle Mountain. The narrow ridge-like summit includes a beautiful stand of red pine, and amazing views to the Mount Washington Valley, south to Conway Lake, and east into Maine. The trail is blazed in red. 

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, skiing and snowshoeing, hunting, and observing wildlife. Camping, fires or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve, and all dogs must be on a leash.

hits.name: North Twin and South Twin Mountain via North Twin Trail
hits.description: Begin at the North Twin parking lot at the end of Haystack Road. Hike up the North Twin Trail for 4.2 miles where you will reach the summit. There are 3 river crossings within the first 2 miles of this hike and they are difficult to cross if the water level is high. Continue over to South Twin Mountain along the same trail that changes from North Twin Trail to North Twin Spur. You will reach the summit after 1.2 miles. To get back to the parking lot, retrace your steps for 5.5 miles.

hits.name: Blue Job Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This is an easy family hike through Blue Job Mountain State Forest with a variety of terrain including granite, blueberry fields, pine and hardwood forestlands with good examples of plant succession. 

This park is a carry in-carry out area (no trash facilities). Please do not leave bagged dog doo or trash behind! Use increases on weekends.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Beaver Brook to South Peak
hits.description:
Visitors will cross over the summit of Mount Moosilauke and South Peak and hike along a wide open ridge with sweeping views during this hike.

Mount Moosilauke is the first NH 4K peak AT thru-hikers cross heading north from Georgia to Maine.

hits.name: Mount Major and Mount Anna Trail
Webster Jackson and Elephant Head Spur
Mount Washington via Tuckerman’s Ravine, Huntington Ravine and Nelson Crag
hits.description:
The head wall section of the trail is very steep with some sections of fourth class terrain. It should also be noted that the head wall should never be attempted when wet or if the weather looks threatening.

Due to the steepness of this route, doing an out-and-back and going back down the trail can be very difficult. Many hikers choose to do the route shown on this page: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/mount-washington-via-huntington-ravine-and-lion-head-trail

hits.name: Bridesmaid Falls
hits.description:
Bridesmaid Falls is a pair of waterfalls dropping about 50 feet and join to become a stream called Tucker Brook. Over the next ridge to the west is the Coppermine Trail and Brook, which leads to Bridal Veil Falls. 

This hike starts at the small parking area on Alpen Hill Rd. at Mittersill. It winds mostly horizontal across the mountain, following green blazes and eventually yellow ribbons. This trail also leads to an interesting series of cascades. The challenging part is to find the galvanized sign marking Bridesmaid Falls, and the steep descent to the falls.

hits.name: Mount Monadnock via White Dot Trail to Pumpelly Trail to Cascade Link Loop
Yudicky Farm Conservation Loop
hits.description: Although hikers and runners are allowed, this trail is primarily meant for mountain bikers.

hits.name: Gonic Falls via Isinglass Trail and Watson's Way
Northern Rail Trail
hits.description:
The Northern Rail Trail follows the route of the Boston & Maine Railroad as it winds its way along the Mascoma River.

The Northern Rail-Trail is one of the most family friendly trails in New Hampshire. The trail starts in Lebanon and is a pleasant jaunt to Danbury. While many rail-trails follow rivers along their course, the Northern gives riders a chance to get up close and personal with the Mascoma River as the trail crosses the river seven times within the first four miles.

The trail starts at the Witherell Recreation Center in Lebanon and is obviously a family favorite. Tagalongs, tandems, trailers, and training wheels dominate the first couple miles of the trail as children and their parents enjoy this beautiful stretch of the trail that takes full advantage of old railroad bridges to cross the river about every half mile or so. Gradually the trail population begins to thin out.

hits.name: Wantastiquet to Ann Stokes Loop and Madame Sherri's Castle
Ferry Way Trail Loop
hits.description: The hike starts with a stroll past an old secure military area with a sign stating 'Former Weapons Storage Facility'.  It then follows an old path down into a lovely broad field and eventually reaches Great Bay.  There you will find an observation platform for view the bay.  The road is well maintained.  It can be slightly muddy after a rain.

hits.name: Liberty and Franconia Ridge Loop
hits.description: A tough overnight hike that takes you over a number of peaks including Lafayette and Liberty. The idea is to stay the night at Liberty Spring Tentsite.

hits.name: Cotton Valley Rail-Trail
hits.description: This is an awesome trail to walk or bike on. It has beautiful views of Lake Winnipesaukee and Lake Wentworth as well as many wooded miles. The Path is well maintained.

hits.name: Flume Slide Trail
hits.description:
The upper section of the trail has a steep ledge that can be wet and dangerous at times. The descent of this route can also be challenging and is recommended for experienced hikers only.

For a more relaxed hike, try the Flume Slide Trail to Liberty Spring Trail Loop here - https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/flume-slide-trail-to-liberty-spring-trail-loop

hits.name: Peaked Hill Pond Trail
hits.description:
Visitors have reported the first stretch of trail is not well maintained and has been affected by flooding, but the remainder of the trail is in good shape.

Peaked Hill Pond is a great hike for families and visitors of all ages. 

It is recommended to wear bug spray during the spring and summer months.

hits.name: Stonehouse Pond Overlook, Ledges, and Locke Loop
hits.description: This loop offers spectacular views of Stonehouse Pond.

hits.name: Mount Parker via Mount Langdon and Mount Parker Trail
hits.description:
A nice hike that included some time on a logging road, some good rolling hills and a nice view at the top. 

Mount Washington may be visible or shrouded in clouds but there is usually good view over to the Baldfaces and over to the hills in Franconia Notch.

Visitors have reported the trail is not well marked so downloading the map is helpful.

hits.name: South, Middle, and North Moat Mountains
hits.description:
The first mile of the trail is a nice soft surface before it turns into more typical White Mountain terrain with rocks and roots. 

Eventually, the trail turns to granite slabs marked by cairns and yellow blazes. From the summits hikers will find 360-degree views. 

This is a hike that should only be done in dry conditions, the slabs and ledges can be very difficult to walk on when wet.

hits.name: Derry Rail Trail
hits.description:
A nice long, wide, well-maintained paved trail for walking, biking and running. The Derry Rail Trail connects to the Windham and Londonderry Rail-Trails to the south and north respectively. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of Rollins Street at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with an access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with edge barriers and railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Welch and Dickey Mountains
hits.description:
This trail leads to the summits of Welch and Dickey Mountains which have great views of the surrounding area.

Approaching the summit of Welch Mountain there are a number of rocky ledges that can be challenging. These ledges are extremely dangerous after it has rained or if any ice is present. Hikers should be extra careful in this section.

hits.name: Wapack Trail
hits.description: Camping is permitted at only two primitive shelters at the Windblown Cross-Country Ski Area.

hits.name: The Pinnacle
hits.description:
This is a short hike with great views at the end. Users note that the trails are not well-marked, so to bring a copy of the trail map with you or download the map. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Pinnacle Street at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, leaves, roots, rocks). It is typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections from about 0.5-0.9 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: White Dot, Cascade Link, and Pumpelly Trail Loop
Piper and Whiteface Mountains Trail
hits.description: This trail segment begins from the parking lot on upper carriage road on Belknap Mountain. Please note that Carriage Road occasionally closes when muddy. Walk back down the carriage road approx. 0.15 miles and transfer to the white blazed trail on the left. Follow signs to Piper and Whiteface. Blazes change colors from white to orange, green and finally blue.

hits.name: View Loop to Purgatory Brook Trail
Lost River Gorge Trail
hits.description: There is a fee to enter this area.

hits.name: Bald Mountain Loop via Tudor and Tamposi Trails
hits.description: This goes along the shore of Willard Pond where you can hear Loons. The trail will take you up Bald Mountain.

hits.name: Black Cap and Cranmore Mountain via Black Cap Trail
Edmand and Crawford Path
hits.description: Relatively Easy NH 4Ks, Great views of Mount Washington Climb Edmunds Path - one of the easiest paths into a NH 4 thousand footer. Some rough spots close to reaching the intersection with the Eisenhower Loop - you find great views of Mt Washington on that area. Just upon reaching the intersection, turn left to zigzag climb Mt. Eisenhower. Caution, it is mostly exposed terrain (no trees) from here to Mt. Pierce (Clinton): could be cold and windy. Upon reaching Eisenhower, enjoy the spectacular, specially the presidential range mountains. Then continue south through the AT / Crawford Path. You will find an intersection towards Mt. Pierce (Clinton). Climb it for 0.1 mi, bag another NH 4K peak, and then return to the Crawford Path, and climb down to the parking lot. About half a mile before reaching the parking lot there is a beautiful waterfall you may want to enjoy.

hits.name: Carter Dome Trail
hits.description:
The route climbs the Wildcat River Trail to the Carter-Moriah Trail to the summit before descending the Rainbow Trail.

The Rainbow Trail is not as well maintained as the Wildcat River Trail but offers an easier descent. Users wanting to stay on a more highly trafficked trail can retrace their steps back down the Carter-Moriah and Wildcat River Trails.

Hikers who are up for an additional challenge can continue on the Carter-Moriah Trail to the summit of Mt. High.

hits.name: Kinsman Pond via Lonesome Lake and Fishing Jimmy Trail
hits.description:
Moderate to Difficult climb in sections but rewards are views and wildlife.

It is advisable to come in through the Lonesome Lake Trail from the Laffayette Campground parking lot so you pass by the Lonesome Lake Hut.

Great way to bag both N. and S. Kinsman peaks.

hits.name: Mizpah Springs Hut Trail
hits.description:
The hike up to Mitzpah Spring Hut is a steady and continuous climb the whole way. 

The hut is operated by the Appalachian Mountain Club and has bunks for overnight guests and typically has snacks available for purchase for day hikers.

If you're feeling up for it, continue past the hut to the summit of Mt. Pierce.

hits.name: Mount Liberty, Mount Flume, Mount Lincoln, and Mount Lafayette
Harris Cabin to South Moose Mountain Trail via Appalachian Trail
Mount Hale and Mount Zealand Loop via Hale Brook to Zealand Trail
hits.description:
This Trailhead is located at the southern terminus of Zealand Road.  Zealand Road remains unplowed in winter.

A long, but fun journey that allows you to bag two NH 4000 footers. The climb up the Hale Brook Trail is very short but steep. Descend Mount Hale via the Lend-A-Hand Trail and feel like you are in nature's isolation. The Zealand Falls Hut is located at the junction of the Twinway Trail/AT so you can refill and refuel on the way up or down from Mount Zealand. Follow the AT up to Zealand's summit, and make sure to take the Zeacliff Pond Spur Trail or one of two incredible viewing areas to make up for Zealand and Hale's wooded summits. The Zealand Trail on the way down is quite easy and flat. This trail can easily be done as a loop with one car as long as you don't mind a short extra walk along Zealand Road.

hits.name: Yellow Jacket XTC Trail
hits.description:
This easy loop is popular with families and pets. The hike is wooded and can be a great place to be surrounded by colorful fall foliage. The trail can be enjoyed year round whether it is snowshoeing or hiking.

There is a nice swimming hole on the Mad River across the street from the trailhead to cool off at in the summer months.

hits.name: Straightback Mountain and Mount Anna via Main Trail (Blue) and Old Stage Road
Boott Spur Trail
hits.description:
From the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center, the Boott Spur Trail leads up to the Davis Path which heads towards the summit of Mount Washington.

The Boott Spur route is a great option for those who have taken more traditional routes up Mt. Washington such as Tuckerman Ravine or Lion's Head and are looking for a new challenge.

hits.name: South Uncanoonuc via Link Trail and Summit Trail
East Osceola via Greeley Ponds Trail
hits.description:
This trailhead is a great way to access Osceola and East Osceola from the Lincoln/Kancamagus Highway side of the mountain. 

The first 1.5 miles of the hike is relatively flat before the climbing begins towards East Osceola.

hits.name: Tuckermans, Lion Head Trail, Davis Path and Boott Spur Trail Loop
hits.description:
There is a shuttle bus available to bring you back to the Pinkman Notch parking lot if you don’t want to trek back down for $31/person or $51/person after 4 PM. Restrooms halfway through the trail, just past the intersection of Tuckerman’s and Lion’s Head summer route (on Tuckerman’s). 

After passing the hut and restrooms, the terrain begins to get much steeper and more challenging. The final leg leading to the summit of Mt. Washington is very rocky and requires walking on top of large boulders.

hits.name: Shannon's, Summit West and Lower Link Trail
hits.description:
You will take the logging road from the parking lot to get to Shannon's Trail. This is a relatively easy hike that is open all year round. However, during winter snowshoes are recommended and in April the trail can get very muddy. Though the summit has only very limited views, the surrounding ledges have breathtaking views off to the south, southwest and west of Mt. Manadanock and North and Pack Manadanock. Please be aware that dogs are not allowed on Gregg's Trail (east of this route but from the same trailhead).

The best bet for determining mountain conditions is to contact the Crotched Mountain Rehabilitation Center at (603) 547-3311.

hits.name: The Raymond Trail
hits.description:
From Old Mountain Road to the peak of Pack Monadnock.

Overall a good trail with sections in some swampy areas so be aware during the wet months that this will be a wet trail.  Trail is well marked with WHITE '' on trees and is fairly easy to follow.  There is are also two scrambles up some rocks so use caution.

hits.name: Mount Whiteface via Dicey's Mill to Blueberry Ledge Loop
hits.description:
Although dogs are permitted on this trail, visitors have warned the trail is not well suited for most dogs. The Blueberry Ledge section involves a steep scramble that is not possible for most dogs unless they can be picked up.

Visitors have also mentioned the Tom Wiggins Trail is not well maintained and requires a river crossing.

hits.name: Mount Tom Spur
hits.description: The most direct route to Mount Tom

hits.name: Mount Washington via Ammonoosuc Ravine to Crawford Path
Avalon Trail to Wiley Range Trail
Holt Trail and Manning Trail Loop to Mount Cardigan
hits.description: This is a loop starting from the AMC Cardigan Lodge. This route takes the Holt Trail to Mount Cardigan and continues to Firescrew Mountain via Mowglis Trail, and finally returns to the AMC Cardigan Lodge via Manning Trail. The Holt Trail to Mt Cardigan's peak is considered one of the most difficult and dangerous hikes in New Hampshire, requiring significant effort to gain nearly 1000 feet of elevation in less than 0.8 miles by climbing over large boulders and, at the end, climbing up an exposed rock face with a very dangerous drop. This trail in particular is only recommended for experienced hikers and those comfortable with heights. This hiking course offers plenty of opportunity to take in the beautiful views in the region and is almost entirely exposed to the elements. Take extreme caution in rain and icy conditions, and be humble in measuring your hiking ability.

hits.name: Red Ridge and Moat Mountain Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop begins by passing the popular swimming area Diana's Baths. This is a great place to stop and cool off on the way back to the trailhead.

The approach up Red Ridge is steeper than the approach up to Moat Mountain, so hikers can choose which direction they travel on the loop to ascend or descend Red Ridge. 

There are some creek crossings on the trail too, so hikers should be prepared to potentially get their feet wet.

hits.name: Rockingham Recreational Rail Trail to Clark Pond
Mount Monadnock via Parker Trail and Cliff Walk
Mount Tecumseh to Waterville Valley Trail
Bald Knob Cut-Off Trail
hits.description:
Please check with the park page for more information.

Begin at Shannon Brook Trailhead. Follow red diamonds blazed for Shannon Brook .7 miles until you see a sign for Bald Knob Cutoff. Bald Knob cut off is 1 mile and intersects the Bald Knob trail about .3 miles below the summit.

The first half of the cut off is a a steady incline that is very well marked. Pay attention the trail has many small turns. Once you reach your first view of the lake it will mostly level out until the intersection with the main trail. Less than a quarter mile before the intersection there is a way point with a sign for hexagonal shaped rocks formed from volcanic activity. Behind the sign there is a small rock outcropping with these rocks. You will also see them on the ground on trail near the waypoint.  These same rock formations are found at Devils Postpile in California.

hits.name: Kenard Trail to Martin Trail
hits.description:
A short trail with parking at the trailhead that leads into the Pulpit Rock Preserve trail system.

Great all year hiking (snowshoes or spikes recommended in ice/snow weather).  Mellow for kids.  End of trail features Pulpit Rock, an amazing mini canyon/waterfall feature that is smack dab in the middle of this wildlife preserve.  Wildlife includes birds (including various raptors, turkeys, woodpeckers), deer, beavers, groundhogs, porcupines, beavers, and even the occasional weasel if you know where to look.

This trail leads to the center of the Pulpit Rock nature preserve and features many different short trails that allow you to piggy back through the system and even all the way to Joppa Hill Farm.

hits.name: Hillzilla Trail and Red Loop
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Windham Rail Trail from Main Street
Foss Mountain
hits.description:
Foss Mountain features a long, open ridge that is home to a low bush blueberry farm. It features two summits. The northern summit, which has the better views, and the southern summit, which is taller and more wooded. Depending on the time of year, there are blueberries in the area. Please check the trailhead kiosk to see where you are able to pick them.

The summer trailhead will likely not be accessible in the winter months, alternative parking is available in the winter following the directions below:

From route 153 in Eaton, NH – on the north shore of Crystal Lake, turn east onto Brownfield Road. Turn right in 1.6 miles onto Bull Pasture Road. Turn right onto Stewart Road in 1 mile. In .3 miles , bear left at the next intersection onto Foss Mountain Road.  Continue approximately .5 to winter trailhead parking on right.

Foss Mountain Road is NOT maintained in winter. There is NO parking past the winter parking lot.

hits.name: Mount Liberty and Mount Flume via Whitehouse, Liberty Springs, and Franconia Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Out and back of Mount Liberty and Flume using Liberty Spring and Franconia Ridge trails. 

This trail is rocky and very steep but has such incredible views from the top of the surrounding area including Cannon Cliff.

hits.name: Thorne Pond Trail
hits.description:
The Thorne Pond Trail is a flat, level loop around the pond and along the banks of the Saco River.

The water levels in the river can fluctuate seasonally, in the spring the river can be wide and flowing fast. By mid-summer and into fall visitors can walk along the rocky shores when the river has receded.

hits.name: Big Pine Natural Area- Betty Steele and Peg King Spur Trails
Cascade Brook Loop to Cascade Basin
Mount Chocorua via Hammond Trail and Liberty Trail
hits.description:
The top of Mount Chocorua has a spectacular summit with 360 degree views of the White Mountains. Be sure to stop by the Liberty Jim Cabin to rest along the way.

Sections of the trail involve some scrambling towards the top. Shoes with good traction are recommended.

hits.name: Pickering Ponds Loop
hits.description:
Good parking and a nice natural surface trail that goes around a lake.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the parking lot off of Pickering Road at the southeast end of the trail. It is unclear if there are designated accessible parking spaces within 1 mile of the southeast end of the route. 

The trail surface is gravel or a natural (dirt/grass) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There is a double track along most of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest section is at about 0.1 miles when going clockwise. Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Cardigan via Holt and Clark Trail
hits.description: Climbing up the Holt Trail involves some scrambling up granite slabs. This route should not be attempted with children or in wet conditions.

hits.name: Rockingham Recreational Rail Trail
hits.description:
From Massabesic Lake to Great Bay, this trail offers pretty ponds, beautiful bridges and a shady ride in the New Hampshire forests.

Due to its proximity to Manchester and the Manchester airport, this trail is one of most accessible of the wonderful New Hampshire Rail Trails. If you are flying to New Hampshire, you may very well fly into Manchester.

This trail is popular year-round with biking, hiking, and running in the summer and snowmobiling in the winter. Rockingham Recreation Trail is also one of the most dog-friendly trails there is... year round. You see, in the winter, in addition to hosting nordic skiers and snowmobilers, it also is home to mushers, also known as dog sledders.

In the summer, a combination of shade-filled forests and sea breezes help to make it one of the cooler trails around. In the fall, the colorful foliage can't be beat. With something to see and do the entire length of the trail, you and your family will probably visit this trail again and again.

hits.name: Mount Washington via Crawford Path Trail
Ridge, Lower Path, Brook, Forest and Beech Trail Loop
Mount Galehead and Mount Garfield Trail
hits.description:
This long loop hike will bag you two more 4,000 foot peaks in the New Hampshire White Mountains.

This is a long loop hike that brings you to a very cool AMC hut nestled between peaks.  Mount Garfield has the best views over the Pemigewasset wilderness to the Franconia Ridge peaks and the Bond Range.

hits.name: Three Ponds Trail
hits.description:
Visitors have reported some sections of the trail are not well marked. Downloading the map ahead of time is helpful with navigating. 

Some sections of the trail can be wet due to beaver activity in the area.

There is a shelter by the pond for those wanting to spend the night in this peaceful place.

hits.name: Liberty Spring and Flume Slide Trail
Mount Zealand and The Bonds via Zealand Trail
South Mountain via Mountain and Woronoco Loop
Wildcat D via Wildcat Ridge Trail
hits.description:
The climb up to Wildcat D is steep and packs a lot of elevation gain into a less than 2 mile ascent.

The hike involves some exposed rocky sections and narrow stairs built into the rocky trail.

Once you gain the ridge there are views across the valley towards Mount Washington and the Presidentials.

hits.name: Eliza Adams Gorge Trail via Monadnock-Sunapee Greenway
hits.description:
This trail has a good amount of variety and opportunities to extend your hike farther than the 4 miles shown by traveling on more of the M-S Greenway Trail system.

The initial part of the trail isn’t very scenic, as it’s a logging road with lots of fallen trees and limbs.  Once you get closer to the water and dam, the trail becomes more scenic.  After you’ve crossed the river just ahead of the dam, take a left off the M-S Greenway Trail and follow the Gorge Trail to the end.

There is a shelter to picnic in as well as a bench near the water's edge close to the end of the Gorge Trail.

hits.name: Red Hill via Eagle Cliff Trail
Madison Cascade
hits.description: This is an easy/moderate trail that has some steep hills. The last 0.3mi of this hike walks you along a ridgeline of the valley and shows you that you are 50-80ft up from the base. The trail ends at a brook/river that has some amazing character and huge stones that are very photogenic.

hits.name: Lonesome Lake and North Kinsman
hits.description:
Reservations for day use are required. Please consult the park website.
https://www.nhstateparks.org/covid-19 

Lafayette Campground up to Lonesome Lake Hut and then over to North Kinsman.

hits.name: Betty Mack Trail and Overlook Trail Loop
Sawyer Pond Trail
hits.description:
The hike is pretty easy. Not too steep, almost entirely in the shade. However, the trail suffers from large amounts of runoff. In some areas at some times of year the trail is a creek with water running right down it. Be prepared for mud! And bugs!

The pond is gorgeous and inviting for fishing and a swim. 

The camping platforms are in good condition and each has a fire pit. The shelter is also in good condition with a great view of the lake. There is also an outhouse near the shelter, uphill. It is in relatively good condition...but watch out for spiders under the toilet lid.

hits.name: Glen Boulder Trail
hits.description:
Pretty intense uphill and can be slippery if there has been any condensation or rain  - make sure you wear the right shoes. 

The view is great once you make it to the first waypoint about 2 miles in. You will have to scramble to get right up to the Glen Boulder.

The views of Pinkham Notch are stellar from the ridgeline.

hits.name: Bald Ledge
hits.description: Please use caution when proceeding, as this trail is located inside an active logging area. Users report that logging occurs in the first third of this trail.

hits.name: Potanipo Hill Southway Trail Loop
hits.description: Downloading an off line map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked.

hits.name: Shannon Brook, Pond Trail, Bridle Path, and Bald Knob Trails
Franconia Notch Path
hits.description: Accessibility: This trail is paved, typically at least five feet wide, and mostly flat with some steep sections with an estimated max grade of 7%. Wheelchair and stroller users may need assistance if too steep.

hits.name: Monte Rosa and Mount Monadnock via Old Halfway House Trail
hits.description: Hit two summits in one hike. Rosa has a decent view and a good rest point before heading onto Monadnock. This trail takes a more gradual approach to the summit making it a slightly easier climb.

hits.name: Chesterfield Gorge
hits.area_name: Chesterfield Gorge Natural Area/Chesterfield Gorge State Wayside

hits.name: Great Brook Trail
hits.description: This trail is for foot traffic only and travels along easements. The area is wooded and along a brook for over half of the distance and passes a couple of beaver ponds, one is quite large with an overlook. There is plenty of wildlife and bird viewing opportunities.

hits.name: Campbell and Tufts Trail Loop via Gage's Mill Trail
Page Pond and Forest
hits.description: Nice easy walk through the woods with a few viewpoints for the area ponds.

hits.name: Beaver Brook Wildlife, Hidden Ponds, Jeff Smith Loop
West Rattlesnake via Col Trail and Ridge Trail
hits.description: Solid short hike with phenomenal views from the top. Start on Pinehurst Road and follow the Col Trail (Blue trail) to the Ridge trail (Green trail) and turn west.

hits.name: French's Ledges Trail
hits.description:
Frenches ledges is one of several interconnected trails in this area.  They are well marked.  Mountain biking is good on well maintained trails and you can climb to the ledges for a 360 degree view.

The route on this page starts at the middle trailhead. You may also choose to start at the northern or southern trailheads, which can also be found on AllTrails.

This route can be made into a loop by returning via the yellow marked trail.

This trail is located on a conservation easement managed by the Upper Valley Land Trust.

hits.name: Doe Farm and Moat Island Trails
hits.description:
From the parking lot, a woods road leads past a metal gate, to a clearing that also serves as a log landing during forest management operations. Doe Farm is tucked between Bennett Road to the north and the Lamprey River to the south. It offers a network of beautiful 3+ mile network of woodland trails that lead to the Lamprey River and its backwaters. The property’s 3,000 feet of shoreline helps protect the water quality of the Wild & Scenic Lamprey River.

Doe Farm is an upland forest with a mix of red oak, white pine, red pine and Norway spruce plantations. Small streams and seepages drain in a southeasterly direction toward the Lamprey River. Pockets of shrub wetlands and floodplain forest are found along the stream drainages and along the Lamprey River. Periodic timber harvests and invasive plant control help maintain a healthy forest.

Olinthus N. Doe bequeathed Doe Farm to the Town of Durham upon his death in 1909. The Doe family burial ground and cellar hole of the family homestead are located just beyond the forest clearing.

hits.name: Dover Community Trail
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: North Twin, South Twin, Guyot, West Bond, Bond, Bondcliff, Zealand, and Hale Loop
hits.description:
Start on North Twin Trail, ascend North Twin, South Twin, and Guyot. 

A great way to do this as a backpacking trip is to set up camp at the Guyot campsite and ascend West Bond, Mt. Bond, and Bondcliff, then hike back to the campsite. 

In the morning hike back to Guyot instead of heading back down the path with the Twins, ascend Zealand then Mt. Hale. At the top of Mt. Hale take the abandoned fire wardens trail back to North Twin Trail and walk back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Pisgah Ridge and Kilburn Loop
hits.description: Begin from the Kilburn Trailhead off Chesterfield Rd/NH Route 63.

hits.name: White Lake State Park Loop Trail
hits.description: Fee: $5/person

hits.name: Kidder Mountain
hits.description: Very rocky, lots of exposed tree roots, steep, great view on top of the mountain.

hits.name: Little Boar’s Head Scenic Walk
hits.description:
This paved trail starts from North Hampton State Park and heads north paralleling the coast and Ocean Boulevard/1A. There are large mansions to the west and the ocean to the east, and some benches along the way for resting.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Ocean Boulevard at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for one steep (8 - 12%) uphill section at about 0.4 miles when going northbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Les Clark Nature Trail
hits.description: There are three choices at the trailhead. The trail in the center leads to a bench by the marsh. From there you can view birds and blue heron.

hits.name: Mount Bond and The Cliffs via Lincoln Woods Trail
Monadnock-Sunapee Greenway Trail
hits.description: Most of the trail is dog friendly however, please keep your dogs on a leash.

hits.name: Mountain Trail to South Ridge Trail Loop
hits.description: Great trail and well marked with white blazes and map signs.

hits.name: Skookumchuck Trail
hits.description: A scenic and less crowded route to the summit of Mt. Lafayette. The trail starts from the parking lot that serves the north end of the Franconia Notch bike path. After following a brook, it climbs steeply on stone steps then the grade eases as the trail climbs to meet the Garfield Ridge Trail.

hits.name: North Peak Trail via Main Junction
hits.description: Outstanding hike- the trail is very well maintained, in great shape, and has some very pretty views.

hits.name: Middle Sister Trail
hits.description:
The Middle Sister Trail is one of the less-trafficked trails leading to the ridge heading to the summit of Middle Sister and continuing on to Mount Chocorua.

This is a great trail for anyone looking to avoid the crowds!

Microspikes and poles are suggested for hiking in the shoulder seasons when there is ice and snow on the trail.

hits.name: Grater Woods Millepede Loop
hits.description: This trail network is big and not every trail junction is well signed. Having the map downloaded ahead of time is helpful for navigation.

hits.name: Lowe's Bald Spot Trail
hits.description:
Begin from the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center and take the Old Jackson Road Trail towards the Mt. Washington Auto Road.

After crossing the road, take the Madison Gulf Trail up to Low's Bald Spot. This is a scenic viewpoint on the flanks of Mt. Washington.

hits.name: Powerline, Whitaker Lane and Vista Trail
Galehead and South Twin Via Gale River Trail
hits.description:
The stretch of trail leading to Galehead Hut is moderate with gradual elevation gain. The trail to South Twin Peak from Galehead Hut is extremely steep and rocky. 

The Galehead Hut is a great place to stop and rest before pushing to the summit of South Twin Peak. Reservations can be made in advance through the Appalachian Mountain Club to stay at the hut overnight.

hits.name: Mount Washington via Huntington Ravine and Lion Head Trail
hits.description: Hard, dangerous, but beautiful. Don't attempt if it's wet and rainy.

hits.name: Willand Pond Trail
hits.description:
This trail is wide and great for both biking and hiking. There are some different workout stations along the way if you like that kind of thing. The trail is pretty shady the whole way and there are some great spots to look at the 66-acre Walland Pond. This is a nice little spot to get away quickly in Somersworth. Dogs have to be leashed.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of High Street at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is a boardwalk (with partial edge barriers), gravel, or a natural (dirt and root) surface. It is typically 3 to 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces.
There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: East Pond and Little East Pond Trail Loop
hits.description:
Along this route hikers will visit two ponds, this is a great place to bring dogs and let them cool off in the summer months while getting a hike in.

The trail can be very muddy from spring through summer, so be prepared for wet feet.

Visitors have recommended taking the road in from highway 93 versus the road from Waterville. The road from 93 is better maintained.

hits.name: Cannon Mountain Trail
hits.description: Lovely hike overall. There is a pretty tricky rock scramble about 2/3s of the way up, but there are some unbelievable views at the top.

hits.name: Mountain Pond Trail
hits.description:
Mountain Pond is a beautiful water body. There is a shelter along the pond that is a great place to go for a first-time backpacking trip. 

The trail is rocky in places and there is a stream crossing, so using trekking poles is helpful. After a storm, the trail can be very wet and flowing with water.

hits.name: Blueberry Pasture to Purple Loop
hits.description: The Purple Trail is not maintained well and is very steep at times. It can be very slippery even when dry.

hits.name: Tucker and French Family Forest Loop
Cherry Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This trail offers a peaceful and quiet walk through the north woods. 

Users have reported the summit of Cherry Mountain is wooded and does not offer any view points.

Hikers looking for a more open view should trek towards the summit of Mt. Martha and Owl's Head.

hits.name: Ann Stokes Loop and Daniels Mountain Loop
White Dot Trail to North Uncanoonuc Mountain
College Woods Natural Area Loop
hits.description: Be advised, the parking lot where this trail begins is restricted to UNH staff Monday-Friday. The lot is enforced.

hits.name: Gap Mountain North Trail
hits.description:
This is a a well maintained trail, a wonderful nature walk through a variety of habitats with great views from the top! It's dog friendly and not too busy. 
$5 fee

hits.name: Old Halfway House Trail to White Arrow Trail Loop
hits.description: little varaition of going straight up the arrow. little less direct and a great view at 2500 off Rosa

hits.name: Plummer's Ridge Trail
hits.description: Almost seven miles of trails meander through 400 managed acres of forests and fields and along the Branch River, connecting the adjacent Plummers Ridge lands of Branch Hill Farm, McKenzie’s Farm, and the New Hampshire Farm Museum.

hits.name: Zealand Trail, Twinway, Bondcliff and Guyot Shelter
hits.description:
Lakes, huts, shelters, views, this trail has something for everyone!

For those looking to backpack, the Guyot Shelter is for tent camping, and the Zealand Hut offers bunk spaces. Reservations for the hut must be made through the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance.

Please note, this is a point-to-point route. The mileage will be doubled if you're returning back to the car versus setting a shuttle further down trail.

hits.name: Carter Range Loop
hits.description:
During this hike, users will cross Middle Carter, South Carter, Carter Dome, and Mount Hight. The views from the ridgeline are spectacular.

The Nineteen Mile Brook Trail will take you to the source of the brook passing several fun water holes on the way.  Two miles up the trail it will split with you heading to climbers left up to Zeta Pass where you can access the Carter-Moriah Trail to reach both South and Middle Carter before returning to the pass and then up Mount Hight to Carter Dome.

hits.name: Londonderry Rail Trail
hits.description:
Come stretch your legs on the beautiful Londonderry Rail Trail. This route is actually a part of the longer Granite State Rail Trail. Making use of former railroad beds, multiple towns are combining efforts to create one continuous long trail.

This particular route was paved in 2016. If you'd like to extend your trip, continue south onto the paved Derry Rail Trail.

Only the first ~3 miles of this route are paved and wheelchair accessible. At Route 28/Manchester Road, the trail is not completed, and has a dirt tread as of 2020. Careful crossing at Route 28, the road is very busy! Visitors can basically access this trail from any place that it crosses a road, you just might not be able to find parking everywhere.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot in the southwest corner of the intersection of Sanborn Rd. and Rockingham Rd. at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved or natural surface (rocky dirt/grass). It is typically at least 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 3.0 miles heading southeast, along the paved and mostly gentle sections. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for one steep (8-12%) downhill section at about 4.0 miles when going southeast. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steepest section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type after the 3.0 mile mark. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: North Moat Mountain Trail
hits.description:
North Moat begins by passing Diana's Bath, a popular swimming hole with a series of waterfalls.

The ascent up to North Moat is steep so be prepared! Many users will hike back towards the original trailhead after summiting North Moat, but you can continue towards Passaconaway Rd passing over Middle and South Moat. 

Set a shuttle at the southern trailhead to make it back to the northern trailhead.

hits.name: Henderson-Swasey Town Forest: Red Loop Trail
WOW and Winni Trail
hits.description:
The Winni Trail is very well kept, making its way along the water and through woods that are a combination of public and private lands.  The walkway paving is new, as are fencing, picnic areas, and benches up to the trail mid-point at the Leslie Roberts Beach and Rec area.  If you only have time for half the total trail, the best half is on the Winni trail (between the Rec area and the Winni trail entrance). The WOW trail goes through a combination of home, industrial, and lake views in Laconia.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Elm Street at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.0 through 0.5, 1.5, 3.0, and 4.2 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Caesar Trail
hits.description: A short hike up an old logging road to the top of Mount Caesar to look out over Southwest New Hampshire and views of Monadnock. The start of the trail is off of Simeneau Lane at the cemetary.

hits.name: Clifton, Phoebe Rock and Pond View Loop
Haystack Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The route up Haystack Mountain has beautiful cascading brooks and wonderful summit views. The final sections of the trail towards the summit are rocky and can be very slippery when wet. This trail is not advised following a rainstorm. 

Users have reported this trail is not well maintained in places and can be muddy.

hits.name: Weetamoo Trail Via Piper Trail
hits.description:
The Piper Trail follows a nice creek as it climbs up towards the Wetamoo Trail. This is a great spot for dogs to cool off during the warm summer months. 

The trail is mostly wooded with a large boulder towards the top of the Weetamoo Trail that offers a view from the top. Careful, the boulder is not an easy scramble!

Continue on the Hammond Trail towards Bald Mountain for some better view points.

hits.name: Hale Brook Trail and Zealand Trail Loop
hits.description:
The hike begins with a steady climb up to Mount Hale, a NH 4K peak. The summit of Mount Hale is wooded so there are is not a great viewpoint from here. 

Descend down to Zealand Hut. When the hut is open seasonally there is typically baked goods available for purchase by the Hut Croo. 

After descending past the hut the trail is mostly flat leading back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Nineteen Mile Brook Trail to Carter Notch
hits.description:
So many brooks along this route! 

The views of Carter Dome and Wildcat are stunning. Carter Notch Hut is a great place to stop and refuel before hiking back.

hits.name: Mount Monadnock via White Dot and Lost Farm Trail Loop
North and South Twin Mountain, Mount Guyot, Mount Zealand and Mount Hale
hits.description:
This loop is done most popularly as a backpacking loop. For those wishing to stay at an Appalachian Mountain Club Hut, reservations must be made through the AMC in advance. 

This is a great way to check of several NH 4K peaks on one trip. Hikers will summit Mt. Hale, Zealand, Guyot, South, and North Twin.

hits.name: Galehead Mountain, North Twin, and South Twin via Gale River Trail
hits.description:
This route is a difficult one, but rewards hikers with the summits of Galehead, South  Twin, and North Twin Mountain.

Be sure to stop at the Galehead Hut to rest and refuel. Reservations can be made through the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance to stay at the shelter.

hits.name: South Piper Mountain
hits.description: Trail head is at end of Belknap Mt. road, small parking area. Walk up road 200 yds. look left small sign says hiking trail. Don't be fooled you walk between two houses' backyards only for a short bit. This trail is marked green.

hits.name: Mount Meader Trail
hits.description:
Hikers should be prepared for typical White Mountain trail conditions, some mud seasonally, and plenty of rocks and roots. The best views will be just below the summit of Mount Meader. 

The first mile of the trail is easy before the trail begins to climb with a steep section just below the top. Users have reported there is no cell service at the trailhead, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

hits.name: Burton and Holt Peaks via Wapack Trail
East Osceola and Greeley Ponds
hits.description:
The first 2 1/2 miles of the trail on the way towards the East Osceola summit is fairly level and easy climbing before the trail really begins to steepen and climb towards the summit.

The last 1/2 mile to the summit is very steep and rocky, visitors should be prepared for this section and have shoes with good traction. If you're not feeling up for the steep climb, Greeley Pond is a wonderful place to visit before returning to the trailhead.

hits.name: Mount Tom, Mount Field, and Mount Willey "T" Route
hits.description: This varies from the more typical four peak route that includes a hike over Mt. Avalon to also bag one of the 52 With a View. This route avoids the really steep and tough descent from Avalon and instead descends via the A-Z trail, bypassing Mt. Avalon. A-Z has some nice rock steps built in to make it a much easier descent. Views are limited but there are a few nice ones - especially the view north to the Mt. Washington Hotel from the summit of Field. The trail between Field and Willey looks easy on the map but don't be fooled. It's narrow, rocky and rooty and has a few tricky spots. Once you get to the Willey summit area keep going a bit, then down a short section to the left turn on the trail and the actual summit is just a bit beyond that up another left turn.

hits.name: Champney Falls - Bolles Chocurua Loop
hits.description:
Mt. Chocorua is one of the most popular summits in the White Mountains. 

This loop is a good option for someone who has already been to the top of Chocorua on a more traditional route and is looking for some adventure!

The Bolles Trail is not well maintained and requires some route finding to stay on course. The trail crosses a creek several times.

hits.name: Big Sugarloaf via Elwell, Blue and White Trail Loop
hits.description: During the wintertime (with heavy snowfall), snowshoes are necessary for this hike.

hits.name: Mount Chocorua via Carter Ledge Trail
hits.description:
This route to the summit of Mt. Chocorua is perfect for someone looking to avoid crowds or who has already hiked to the summit via another trail.

Sections of the Carter Ledge Trail are very steep and involve scrambling. It is recommended to descend down the Middle Sister Trail for users who are not comfortable with the rocky descent.

hits.name: Crotched Mountain Lookout via Shannon's Trail
Holt Peak and Burton Peak via Wapack Trail
Irene's Path to the Scaur
hits.description:
This trail is well marked and leads to wonderful views from the summit of The Scaur. 

Seasonally the trail can be wet and remain boggy for some time. Don't forget the bug spray in spring through summer!

hits.name: Bear Brook, Cascade, Sentinel PIne, Hayes Farm, Big Bear Loop
Faraway Mountain and Mount Roberts Loop
North Uncanoonuc Mountain via Blue and Red Loop
Mount Lafayette, North Lincoln, and Little Haystack Loop
Holt Trail
hits.description: The trail starts off easy but quickly gains 1000+ feet in less than .8 miles.  If you are afraid of heights, do not attempt. Many people choose to take alternative ways back to avoid the scrambles going down, check out the Clark Trail on AllTrails for an easier way down.

hits.name: Bog Mountain
hits.description: Please note you have to cross the road by foot once you park to find the trail head.

hits.name: Bear Claw Trail to Loon Summit
hits.description:
This route starts at Picked Rock and transitions to Bear Claw on route to Loon Summit. It's a great hike if you want to visit Loon mountain during the summer season. Although the trail is primarily a mountain maintenance road with little change in terrain it is a great way to stay in shape for more serious endeavors. The ability to grab a beer or bite to eat at the summit lounge is a huge plus. You can take the gondola down free of charge back to the base if you don't feel like walking back down. 

During the ski season, you do need an Uphill Access pass and definitely need to stay on the designated trails as this route is shared by skiers and boarders. You cannot hike down and must take the Loon Gondola back to the trailhead. Hikers recommend getting on the slopes before opening hours for a less crowded experience.

hits.name: North Sugarloaf
hits.description:
This short out and back trail leads to a ledge with amazing 270-degree views of the surrounding area.

This is an amazing place to see the fall foliage that the White Mountains are famous for. 

This is a great trail to do at the beginning of a trip to the Whites to get ready for longer hikes in the area.

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge Trail to Nineteen Mile Brook Trail
hits.description:
The point-to-point crosses the summit of Wildcat D, C, B, and Wildcat Mountain before descending down towards Carter Notch Hut and Nineteen Mile Brook.

After joining the Nineteen Mile Brook Trail, users will follow the trail alongside the brook to the trailhead just off NH 16.

hits.name: The Rapids via Purgatory Brook Trail
West Ridge to Mowglis to Clarks to South Ridge Loop
Mount Washington via Tuckermans Ravine and Boott Spur Trail
hits.description:
This route is Tuckerman's Ravine up, and Crawford Path, Davis Path, and Boot Spur down. 

Alternately, you can take The Crossover to Tuckermans to take Tuckermans Ravine back down for a more direct, but steeper descent down the mountain.

hits.name: Wildcat Ski Slope to Wildcat Mountain
hits.description: The hike up to wildcat takes place mostly on a dirt road.  At about 1.7 miles you do hike up the slope but then you are quickly back on the road.

hits.name: French South Trail and Patten Island Trail
The Northern Presidentials via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
From the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center, climb up the Appalachian Trail into the infamous White Mountain Alpine Zone.

Hikers should be prepared for any type of weather, even in the summer months!

The route will pass over Mount Adams and Mount Madison. The Madison Spring Hut is a great place to stop for a snack and fill up on water.

hits.name: Boulder Trail to North Mountain Trail Loop
Goodrich Rock Trail via Greeley Ponds Trail
hits.description:
The hike begins on Livermore Road and continues onto Greeley Ponds Trail is fairly level for just over a mile before reaching the junction for Goodrich Rock Trail.

The Goodrich Rock Trail climbs up to the namesake boulder along with several other large boulders. There is a ladder in place to climb up and down the boulder safely.

hits.name: Mraz North to Byrne to Otis Hill to Neil Mill Loop
hits.description: Beautiful trails and class 6 roads.

hits.name: Imp Ledges Trail
hits.description:
This route follows the Imp Trail up to the Imp Ledges which provide users with great views.

From the ledges visitors will look back across the valley towards Mount Madison and Mount Jefferson.

There is one stream crossing on the trail, so hikers should be prepared to potentially get wet depending on water levels.

hits.name: South Uncanoonuc Summit Trail to Lake
Pulpit Brook and Joppa Hill Farms Loop Trail
hits.description: Pulpit Trail -Joppa Hill farm Trail

hits.name: Swift River Lower Falls
hits.description:
This flat path follows alongside the Swift River and crosses over the historic Albany Covered Bridge. 

There are some good spots to cool off in the river alongside the path in the summer months. There is a fun trail for dogs and visitors of all ages.

hits.name: Kettle Ridge, Cranmore, and Red Tail Trails Loop
Londonderry Rail Trail: Little Cohas Segment
hits.description:
Come stretch your legs on the newest portion of the Londonderry Rail Trail. This section was paved in October 2019. The Londonderry Rail Trail is actually a part of the longer Granite State Rail Trail. Multiple municipalities in the area are combining efforts to make one long trail. Making use of former railroad beds, these trails wind through beautiful New Hampshire forests.

If you'd like to continue north, you'll need to take a detour on surface streets around the east side of the airport. Once past the airport, you'll be able to pick up the South Manchester Trail.

If you'd like to continue past the trailhead on the southern side, the Londonderry Rail Trail continues (paved, then unpaved) for several miles, before reaching the Derry Rail Trail.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Mammoth Road at the east end of the trail.
