There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings which reduces the width temporarily. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Adams via Short Line Trail Loop
hits.description:
Although dogs are permitted on this trail, users have suggested it is not a great trail for dogs due to the rocky and steep nature of the trail. 

This loop has some relentless climbing, so hikers should bring shoes with good traction and trekking poles if they find them helpful. 

The Valley Way Tentsite is a good place to stop for those who would like to camp out on the way to or from the summit.

hits.name: Big Rock Cave Trail
hits.description:
The Big Rock Cave Trail takes hikers into the Sandwich Range Wilderness area and towards the rocky outcroppings from which the trail gets its name. 

The Big Rock Cave is a series of big boulders near Whitin Brook.

hits.name: Ragged Mountain from New Canada Road
hits.description: The trail gradually climbs over logging roads until narrowing to a trail and reaching the ridge line 1.4 miles in. The trail proceeds over the ridge line towards the summit climbing gradually overall but with frequent ups and downs until reaching the final summit cone of Ragged Mountain and ascending adjacent to ski trails.

hits.name: Isolation via Davis, Glen Boulder, and Rocky Branch
hits.description:
Glen Boulder Trail is a fantastic ascent to Isolation, featuring an exposed ridge line with views of the Presidential Range and of course the famous Glen Boulder.  An easier descent than returning down Glen Boulder Trail is to take the Isolation Trail to Rocky Branch.  

This is a great hike in the summer and winter, but be warned - there are a number of river crossings, and the trail does follow a stream bed for a while.  In the shoulder seasons when there isn't yet sufficient ice on the streams but there is snow around, it can be slow going to find good footing.

hits.name: Tripyramids via Livermore Trail, Scaur Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Hikers looking to check off NH 4K peaks will love this route. The route will take you over the summit of South Peak, Middle Tripyramid, and North Trypyramid. 

The descent off South Peak can be technical and challenging. Hikers uncomfortable with scrambling might prefer to backtrack down the route they came up versus descending The Slide.

hits.name: Black Pond Trail Via Lincoln Woods Trail
hits.description: Use this when Lincoln Brook is high, especially winter months. Allows you to bypass a couple of difficult crossings. Difficult to follow at times.

hits.name: Mount Adams via King's Ravine Trail
hits.description:
The summit of Mount Adams provides spectacular views of the Presidential Range and the surrounding wilderness area.

Sections of the trail can be very steep and made of large boulders. Good footwear with traction is recommended. Lower sections of the trail can be muddy seasonally.

hits.name: Mount Lethe and Carter Mountain Loop
hits.description:
This hike will treat users to some wonderful views while crossing over the Carters. 

Users have said the trail can be very muddy and slippery following any rainfall. Sections of trail can become very boggy and take weeks to dry out.

This loop can also be done in the shoulders seasons and winter, but snowshoes or a traction device are recommended.

hits.name: Baldface and Slippery Brook Loop
hits.description:
This loop is filled with incredible 360-degree views!

Some sections of trail involve some steep rocky scrambles, so users should be prepared for these obstacles and have footwear with good traction.

On the way back be sure to stop at Emerald Pool, it is the perfect place to cool off on your way to the trailhead.

hits.name: Monadnock Mountain via Cliff Walk and Halfway House Loop
hits.description: Parked at Old Toll Road trailhead, and hike the road to Parker Trail. Take Parker Trail through The Notch, then climb the Cliff Walk through the Amphitheater to the White Arrow Trail to the summit.  Return via Smith Summit Trail past Monte Rosa descending via Fairy Spring Trail, then to Old Halfway House Trail back to gate.

hits.name: North and South Twin, Guyot, Bond, West Bond, and Bondcliff Trails
hits.description:
This very long day hike and you will climb 5 peaks in New Hampshire.  You'll start off on the North Twin Trail to get both Twins (North 4,761' and South 4,902') then join the Bondcliff Trail over the ridge to get Mt. Guyot, 4,526' West Bond, 4,698' Bond, and 4,265' Bondcliff then return the same way you came. 

Tent sites are also available along the way for hikers who would like to break the route up over multiple days.  

The trail up the Twins is well maintained and so is the trail over the ridge to the various peaks which remains above the treeline for almost the entire trip.

hits.name: Greeley Ponds Trail via Kancamagus Highway
hits.description:
Hardwood forest trail leads to two pristine mountain ponds

Trail is rocky and muddy in places and there are several stream crossings.  The second stream crossing can be difficult when the water is high (Spring) but is generally easy other times of year.  The ponds are very pretty and there are many protected plants growing in the boggy section of the second pond.  The shelter does not exist anymore but there are good places to relax by the water and even to swim.  

This is a good year round hike.  You can turn around at any point you decide to.  There are some nice water spills below the lower pond.

Upper Greeley Pond, with its dark aqua-green color, is a beautiful spot, surrounded by old growth timber and towering cliffs. By contrast, Lower Greeley Pond is shallow and more typical of a beaver pond. Both ponds offer trout fishing and an enjoyable place to have a picnic lunch.

hits.name: Saco River Trail
hits.description: This is a winding, level path by the Saco River in Bartlett across from Attitash/Bear Mountain.

hits.name: Kilborn Pond and John Summers Trail
Clifton, Phoebe Rock and Charles Jack Path
Doublehead Trail
hits.description:
The summit of Doublehead Mountain will reward hikers with amazing views of Squam Lake in the distance. 

Although relatively short, this hike has a lot of climbing so visitors should be prepared for the steep sections of trail.

hits.name: One Mile, Sentennial Pine, Bobcat Loop Trail
Gordon, Salroc and Tama Falls via Brookbank and Fallsway Trail
hits.description:
A great 1.5-mile waterfall loop featuring the fast-running Tama Falls. The trail offers a great picnic area. 

Complete as a loop by taking Brookbank to Fallsway and pass Gordon Falls, Salroc Falls, and Tama Falls. The base of Tama Falls and parts of Snyder Brook offers a great spot to wade in the water.

hits.name: Western Belknap Range Loop
hits.description:
Tour of the Western peaks in the "Belknap 12" list - Rowe/Gunstock/Belknap/Piper/Whiteface

Park in the main lot at Gunstock resort. Walk "through" the main cluster of buildings; the trail begins on a dirt road that goes under the mountain coaster (see pictures). Loop returns you back to the Gunstock parking lot near the base of the "Panorama" chair lift.

This loop is great for quickly bagging the "Belknap 12" or a training hike for something bigger.

hits.name: Round Pond Trail To South Ridge Trail
Temple Mountain
hits.description: Nice hike. Mostly in the woods on the ridge. There few view points. Many bugs, but bearable.

hits.name: Burnt Mountain via Westline Trail
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: Wagon Hill - Cove and Border Trails
Valley Way, The Brookside, Airline Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop brings hikers up past Salroc and Tama Falls following Snyder brook up the flanks of Mt. Madison. 

The Brookside eventually passes Salmacis Fall where this route ends and heads back down the mountain.

hits.name: North Uncanoonuc Mountain via White Dot and Red Dot Trail
hits.description: Visitors have reported that the trails are not well-marked so you may want to download the offline map for directions.

hits.name: Nancy Cascades
hits.description:
The path is a steady incline, it is not especially steep in any one spot but does not level out. There is also a creek crossing, so be prepared to potentially get your feet wet.

Visitors have mentioned the trail is not well marked/blazed, so downloading the map before visiting is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: Monadnock Mountain via Parker, White Arrow, Pumpelly, Cascade and White Dot Loop
Pine Flat to Tritown XC Trail
hits.description:
The trail has some wonderful cascading brooks that are great for kids and dogs to play in during the warm summer months. 

While the trail is mostly wooded and does not have any views, it is a great place to walk around in all seasons. It is a wonderful walk through the woods to take in fall foliage.

hits.name: Monadnock Summit Loop via Cascade Link, Red Spot, Pumpelly, and White Cross Trails
Mt Madison to Mt Adams to Mt Jefferson Loop
hits.description: This is a great route if you do not have access to 2 cars and you want to begin your path to completing the presidential range.

hits.name: Wildcat Mountain Range to Carter Notch
hits.description:
Wildcat will be sure to wake you up first thing in the morning! Steep scrambles all the way up to the ridgeline. On a clear day, users will have views across the valley to Mount Washington and the Presidential Range. 

Carter Notch Hut typically has water available and some food for purchase during the summer operating season.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson Trail
hits.description:
Strenuous hike with great views

A very difficult hike over the caps.  It is steep at times, the rocks are rugged and the trail is demanding.  There are places where trekking poles are of no use mostly because of the steepness or the numerous holes between the boulders.  It could be a great winter trip if there were access to the trailhead.

hits.name: Rockingham Recreational Rail Trail: Newfields to Manchester
Great Gulf Trail
hits.description:
This trail experiences blow down regularly so may have partial obstructions along the path.

A beautiful challenging trail with wonderful waterfalls.

hits.name: Mount Monadnock via White Cross and Lost Farm Trail Loop
Moosilauke Carriage Road
hits.description:
This route up Mount Moosilauke is a popular trail for backcountry skiers to get up and down the mountain. 

The top has 360-degree views of the surrounding area and will tick another summit off the list of those looking to do the NH 48.

hits.name: Mt. Carrigan via Nancy and Norcross Pond Loop
hits.description:
This route is a popular backpacking loop with wonderful views of this corner of White Mountain National Forest.

Along the route hikers will be welcomed by panoramic views, peaceful woodlands, and flowing rivers and streams.

hits.name: Bailey Brook and Kulish Ledge Loop
Turtleback Mountain Trail
hits.description: The map is mislabeled. This trail takes you to the summit of Turtleback (however on the map it says Bald Knob). In order to go to the actual Bald Knob, use the Bald Knob trail or check out this trail on AllTrails: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/bald-knob-and-turtleback-mountain-loop

hits.name: Algonquin Trail
hits.description:
Visitors should be aware the parking area for the Algonquin Trail is small and can not accommodate many cars.

The trail enters the Sandwich Range Wilderness Area. The trail leads to the summit of the 3,950 ft Sandwich Dome, also known as Black Mountain.

hits.name: Mount Crag Loop
hits.description: From the Austin Brook Trail trailhead, up to the Yellow Trail, up to the summit of Mt. Crag, down to Gates Brook Trail to the North Road, and a short road walk back to the truck.

hits.name: Lincoln, Bondcliff, Twin, and Franconia Loop
hits.description: Three day, two night smaller version of the Pemi loop.

hits.name: Moat Mountain High School Loop
hits.description:
A fun and relatively easy hike with some nice wooded sections and beaver ponds. 

This area is very popular with mountain bikers, so be observant of other users on the trail.

hits.name: Lower and Upper Snows Mountain Loop
South Doublehead via New Path, Old Path, Doublehead Ski Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice wide trail that parallels a brook at points. Sections of the trail have been reported to have some loose rocks, so good footwear is encouraged. 

The views from the summit of the surrounding mountains are great and it is a short detour to North Doublehead where visitors will find an old cabin.

hits.name: Devil’s Den Trail
hits.description: This hike is up to cavernous ledges, not for those who are afraid of small spaces! Bring a headlamp to explore the caves.

hits.name: Turkey Pond, Forest Floor, Old Orchard, and St Paul's School Loop
Great Glen Trails
hits.description:
All trails are clearly marked and well cared for. Visitors will find a variety of hard-packed trails as well as wooded trails. A trail map is provided when you purchase your day pass. Also some fun trail stuff for the kids and awesome views.

For current rates please visit: https://greatglentrails.com/

hits.name: Three Brothers Trail
hits.description: Starting at the parking lot on Rt 26 in Dixville Notch State Park, take the Huntington Falls trail on Cascade Brook. This turns into the Three Brothers Trail which goes to Table Rock directly above the notch. This is a moderate trail that is not heavily used. It is well marked with yellow trail markers. Use caution in several areas due to cliffs and steep dropoffs.

hits.name: Semi Pemi Loop
hits.description:
The "Semi Pemi" is a shortened version of the popular Pemi Loop Trail in New Hampshire's White Mountain National Forest. This version uses the Franconia Brook Trail to bypass the Bonds, Twins, and Guyot. 

This backpacking loop is challenging and rewarding, spending miles above the treeline in the famous Alpine Zone. Visitors should be prepared for a variety of weather conditions even in the summer months.

hits.name: Ladd Mountain Trail
hits.description: When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.  No camping or campfires without written landowner permission.  No motorized vehicles allowed.

hits.name: Mount Rand and West Quarry Mountain Peaks
Ashuelot Rail Trail
hits.description:
The Ashuelot Rail-Trail, located near Keene, New Hampshire is a 23-mile, four-season trail with something for everyone. This trail is good for biking and hiking from late spring well into fall. During the winter, it is open for Nordic skiing and snowmobiling. Snowshoeing is another winter option, but the trail is usually pretty well packed from the skiers and snowmobilers.

If you enjoyed "The Bridges of Madison County," you'll love the covered bridges of the Ashuelot Rail Trail. The Monadnock Region is famous for its beautiful covered bridges of varying types, and the trail is a perfect way to visit the bridges.

The best starting spot for your trail tour is in Keene, New Hampshire. It is a fun place to grab some supplies and maybe a hot or cold beverage before you hit the trail which starts near the intersection of Emerald Street and Ralston Street, not too far from the center of town. Use the map that comes with this guide to help you get started.

Although it can get pretty warm during the summer, the Ashuelot Rail Trail has lots of shade. It's still advisable to do your most strenuous activities in the early morning during the midst of summer. Autumn is a great time to visit for many reasons outlined below, but one big reason is the cemeteries. They make a great fall/Halloween backdrop whether you are a fan of the macabre or just a history buff. They are fascinating, educational, interesting, and sometimes spooky.

The trail follows the Ashuelot River the whole way, so it is dotted w/ the remnants of old mills, quaint villages, and abandoned railroad memorabilia.
Be sure to glance through the waypoints in this guide either before you leave or while you're on the trail. The Ashuelot Rail Trail has many fascinating side trips to explore from the covered bridges to the local festivals. In the process of getting some great exercise, you will also be educated, entertained, and exhilarated.

ACCESSIBILITY: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Emerald Street at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), gravel, or a natural (dirt) surface. It is typically at least 4 to 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 3.8, 9.1, and 18.5 miles when going southwest. 

Hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mount Cardigan and Back 80 Loop Trail
hits.description: Offline map recommended. Users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

hits.name: Ethan Pond Trail
hits.description:
The Ethan Pond trail climbs to a wonderful pond beneath Mount Willey.

The first half-mile of the trail is a steep climb before leveling out and remaining relatively moderate as you approach the pond.

The Ethan Pond Trail is also the Appalachian Trail, so this section can be busy in the summer months with weekend backpackers and thru-hikers passing through the area.

hits.name: Nickerson Ledge via Piper Trail
hits.description:
Follow the Piper Trail to an overlook on Nickerson Ledge. The trail is named after Joshua Piper who originally blazed the trail. The property once was home to fruit orchards, a barn, a farmhouse, and a sawmill. 

The trailhead be be busy especially on the weekend with hikers looking to summit Mt. Chocorua.

There is a parking fee for the Piper Trailhead.

hits.name: Nineteen Mile Brook, Carter Moriah, and Imp Trails Loop
hits.description:
This beautiful loop takes the hiker to the peaks of Carter Dome, Carter Mountain, and Mount Hight. A great hike for those looking to hike all of the NH 4K peaks. 

Visitors looking to stay at an Appalachian Mountain Club Hut should make reservations through the AMC in advance. The huts are open to day hikers to stop by and get water and purchase food.

hits.name: Ammonoosuc Lake Trail
hits.description:
From the Crawford Station, this level trail passes by the Highland Center Lodge and then circles around the scenic Ammonoosuc Lake. From the lake, there are great views of the surrounding mountains and Crawford Notch Area. This is a particularly wonderful sight with the fall foliage. 

This is a great trail for pets and visitors of all ages.

hits.name: North Pack Monadnock Loop
hits.description:
Road to top of Pat Momadnock opens at 9am so
Check the website.  Great to start a trail from the top and then to North Pack Monadnock.  There was a nice cliff loop. That added to the hike.

hits.name: Thirteen Falls and Owl’s Head Loop
hits.description: Super wet & tough water crossings

hits.name: Kennard Trail to Campbell and Ravine Trail Loop
Smarts Brook and Drakes Brook Trail
hits.description:
This is a great hike with spectacular views. The trail and features a cascading brook that parallels the trail all the way down to the highway. 

Microspikes and poles are recommend in the shoulder seasons when the trail is often icy and packed with snow.

hits.name: Brook Trail to Mount Major to Beaver Brook Loop
Paradise Point Trail
hits.area_name: Paradise Point Nature Center & Wildlife Sanctuary

hits.name: Parker Mountain via Spencer Smith and Neil Mooers Trail
Black Mountain via East Pasture Trail
hits.description:
Short, somewhat steep hike with stunning views of Mount Washington from the hut/cabin. This trail has the best views during the fall-spring seasons when there are fewer leaves on the trees obstructing views. 

The trail is well-maintained with few rocks and no scrambles. 

Visitors have reported the trail can be very buggy in the spring-summer, so bringing bug spray is recommended.

hits.name: Nancy Brook Trail
hits.description:
The first 1.5 miles of the trail is fairly flat before the trail begins to climb towards Nancy and Norcross Ponds.

After the ponds the trail is not well maintained, so hikers should be prepared for some bushwhacking to the summit of Mount Nancy.

hits.name: Crawford Cliff and Gibbs Falls via Crawford Connector Path
hits.description:
This trail has a moderate climb alongside the brook up towards Gibbs Falls. The Crawford Cliff Trail leads to a ledge with a view of Crawford Notch.

There is a pool beneath the falls that is big enough to swim in if you do not mind the cold water. This is a fun place for pets and kids to play and cool off during the warm summer months.

hits.name: Carter Dome (Winter Route)
hits.description:
Users will begin on the Nineteen Mile Brook Trail before reaching the junction for the Carter Dome Trail. 

Climb up Carter Dome to Zeta Pass and follow the ridge line to Carter Dome.

The summit of Mount Hight is a short reroute for anyone looking to add another summit to the trip. 

Anyone attempting this route in the winter should be prepared for the extreme weather conditions commonly found in the Whites.

hits.name: Piper Mountain, Swett Mountain and Whiteface Mountain
Mount Cardigan, Mount Gilman, & Crane Mountain Loop
Barringer's Cliffs and Collins Point
hits.description: Up Fire Rd #54, right onto single-track at top of hill, across cliffs, follow single track to Fire Rd. Follow Fire Rd to Collins Point.

hits.name: Pine Bend Brook Trail to Sabbaday Brook Trail Loop
hits.description:
Depending on the direction users chose to travel, there is about a 1-mile road walk on the Kancamagus Highway to begin or end the hike. If you would like to to do road walk first, parking at the Sabbaday Falls Parking Area just east of the Pine Brook Trailhead.

Sections of the trail are quite rocky and can have flowing water after a rain storm.

The summit of Middle Tripyramid is partially wooded but still offers some nice views.

hits.name: Dunklee Pond and Parker Pond Loop Trail
hits.description: This is a scenic area with easy hiking trails that take you past a scenic pond (Dunklee Pond), several wetlands, and a few moderate hills, depending on the route you take.  Locals walk their horses on some of the trails.  Great Blue Heron nest in one of the wetland areas.

hits.name: Wiley Brook to Saco Lake via Mount Field
hits.description:
This popular trail is normally completed as a point-to-point route accessible from highway 302. 

Another option is an out-and-back trail, the Mount Avalon and Mount Tom via Wiley Range. https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/mount-avalon-and-mount-tom-via-willey-range-trail

hits.name: Cascade Link Trail
hits.description: This trail will connect you from the White Dot Trail to the Red Spot Trail, Spellman Trail, and the Pumpelly trail.

hits.name: Alpine Garden Trail
hits.description:
Users should be aware this trail is entirely about treeline and very exposed. The area is often very windy and can have low visibility.

On clear days there are spectacular views and rare alpine vegetation to observe, remember to tread lightly!

This trail is accessed off the Mt. Washington Auto Road which has a fee, for current rates please visit: https://mt-washington.com/rates

hits.name: Mount Mack, Mount Klem and Mount Rand Loop
Gap Mountain Trail to Metacommet - Monadnock Trail
hits.description: This short out and back connects to the Metacommet - Monadnock Trail and heads back to the starting point.

hits.name: Ellis River Ski Trail
hits.description: This is a cross-country ski trail ONLY. Hiking is not permitted. Jackson Ski Touring has permission from landowners to use the trail during the winter months. The trail is fee-based. Please refer to Jackson Ski Touring for more information- https://www.jacksonxc.org/

hits.name: Mount Washington via Tuckerman Ravine, Davis Path, and Boott Spur Trail
hits.description:
This route tackles the steep Tuckerman Ravine on the way up, and the more gradual Boott Spur Trail on the way down. This is a great option for those who want to avoid the steep and exposed descent of Tuckerman Ravine.

After leaving the trailhead, users will reach the tree line after about 2 miles. It is here where windier conditions are often found. It's encouraged to bring a rain jacket and warm layer even in the middle of the summer when hiking Mt. Washington.

hits.name: Mount Madison and Mount Adams via Valley Way, Star Lake, and Airline Trail
hits.description:
Steady climb to Madison Spring Hut then to Mt. Madison. Star Lake Trail takes hikers along the east face of Mt. Adams followed by a steep climb straight to the summit. 

The decent down Airline Trail follows a ridge with great views above treeline down into King Ravine on the hiker's left.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson via Castle Trail
hits.description:
The Castle Trail follows the ridgeline above Castle Ravine to the summit of Mt. Jefferson providing amazing views of the surrounding area. 

Users should be aware sections of this trail are exposed.

hits.name: Mount Tripyramid, Mount Whiteface to Passaconaway and Oliverian Brook Trail
hits.description:
This route is a beautiful and challenging trek through the White Mountains. Hikers will cross over the summit of four New Hampshire 4K peaks with the option to tag on some slightly shorter peaks as well. 

This loop can be done in a day but is often done as a single overnight backpacking trip. 

Since this is a point-to-point, hikers will need to set a shuttle or road walk back to the starting trailhead.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Franconia Notch State Park to Zealand Notch
hits.description:
This stretch of the Appalachian Trail is filled with incredible views and challenging climbs.

The hike begins from Franconia Notch and begins to climb up towards the Greenleaf Hut and Eagle Lake. 

Along the rest of the route hikers will cross over the summit of several more 4K and 5K foot peaks while spending time in the famous White Mountain alpine zone.

hits.name: Mount Chocorua via Liberty Trail to Bee Line Trail to Bolles Trail
hits.description:
Great 360-degree views from the summit of the surrounding area!

This route to the summit of Mount Chocorua is not the most popular, so it is a good option for visitors who are looking to get away from the crowds a bit. This is a good choice especially on a weekend when the trails will be the busiest.

hits.name: South Branch of the Ashuelot River: Troy to Route 12
Mount Jackson, Mount Pierce, and Mount Eisenhower
hits.description:
A fun route bringing hikers to three souther Presidential Range Peaks. 

Hikers will be treated to wide open 360 degree views once above tree line and in the alpine zone. 

Mizpah Spring Hut is a great place to stop, even if you're not spending the night, to rest up and get some water before continuing.

hits.name: Basin Cascade Trail
hits.description:
This short out-and-back highlights some some beautiful waterfalls. Begin by passing The Basin, a small waterfall flowing into a picturesque pool showing the power of erosion.

Swimming is not permitted in the pool below The Basin.

The trail then passes Kinsman Falls and follows Cascade Brook up to a junction with the Cascade Brook Trail.

hits.name: Whiteface Mountain Trail
hits.description: Short easy hike that gradually wraps around a small mountain. The top is wooded but there’s a lookout just beyond. Some sections of the trail are not well signed, so having the map downloaded ahead of time is helpful.

hits.name: Madison Spring Hut to Lake of the Clouds Hut via Gulfside Trail
Baldface North and South Summits via Slippery Brook Trail
hits.description:
Hikers will pass the tranquil Emerald Pool on the way in and out of doing this loop. It is a perfect place to stop and take a dip in the warmer summer months. 

The ridge line betwen the Baldface peaks is a great place to catch stunning New Hampshire fall foliage.  Some of the best views in the Whites!

hits.name: Winant Park White, Orange, and Blue Trail
Mount Moosilauke Loop via Asquam Ridge Trail to Gorge Brook Trail
hits.description:
Beautiful views on the top of Mount Moosilauke on a clear day! 

Hikers will find that the trail is a little muddy at times seasonally but it is still typically always passable.

This route is a very popular winter route as well for snowshoeing or skiing as it passes over the summit of multiple NH 4K peaks.

hits.name: Dome Rock
hits.description:
This is a truly spectacular trail with amazing views of White Mountain National Forest beneath Mount Madison. The trail parallels the pretty Snyder Brook.

Dome Rock is typically accessible year round, but hikers will need snowshoes or traction devices of some sort in the shoulder seasons and winter months.

hits.name: Flat Mountain Pond Trail
hits.description:
From the parking area, the trail climbs up around the base of Flat Mountain towards Flat Mountain Pond.

The trail has a few stream crossings, so hikers should be prepared to get their feet wet and bring a pair of dry socks to change into. The stream crossings can be challenging or impossible after heavy rains.

Visitors should wear bright orange during the fall hunting season.

hits.name: Giant Falls via Peabody Brook Trail
Wonalancet Ranger Trail
hits.description:
Wonalancet Ranger Trail travels to the summit of Mount Wonalancet through a nice stretch of pine forest. 

The trail is relatively level for the first 2/3 of the hike towards the summit with most of the elevation gain coming in the last 1/3 of the route.

The summit is mostly wooded but there are some viewpoints on the way to the top.

hits.name: Hall’s Ledge from Carter Notch Road
hits.description:
Much of the trail follows the former path of an old logging grade, the trail is steep but does not have many rocks or roots. A nice change of pace for the White Mountains!

From Halls Ledge there are great views of the Mount Washington summit and the Presidential Range.

The trail is only open to ski traffic in the winter months when it is groomed and maintained for skiers.

hits.name: Rose Mountain, Lyndeborough Mountain and The Pinnacle
Lost Pond Loop and Wildcat Mountain
hits.description:
Users will climb up the Wildcat Ridge Trail and across the top of the ski resort on the way to Wildcat Mountain.

After retracing the route back to Wildcat D, descend down back towards NH Route 16. At this point, there is about a 1-mile road walk before meeting a trail again and passing Lost Pond on the way back to the trailhead.

hits.name: North Mountain Loop and Pawtuckaway Lookout
Lynx and Beaver Pond Trail Loop
Mount Tom, Mount Field, and Mount Willey via Avalon, A-Z, Mt. Tom Spur, and Willey Range Trail
hits.description:
This varies from the more typical four-peak route that includes a hike over Mt. Avalon to also bag one of the "52 With a View" hikes. 

A-Z has some nice rock steps built in to make it a much easier descent. Views are limited but there are a few nice ones - especially the view north to the Mt. Washington Hotel from the summit of Field. The trail between Field and Willey looks easy on the map but don't be fooled! It's narrow, rocky and rooty and has a few tricky spots.

hits.name: Morse Trail to Pine Mountain
hits.description: Loop trail with easy climb up to summit with extensive views. The loop trail down starts out fairly level and then drops through narrow trail back to the Morse Trail.  Another loop to the left through some more narrow trail and then to a large field where the trail is very indistinct.  Nice easy Hike.

hits.name: The Loon Center at the Markus Wildlife Sanctuary
Owl's Head Trail to Martha's Mile
hits.description:
Visitors have reported sections of the trail can be difficult to follow. Downloading the map ahead of time to help with navigation is helpful. 

The trail is mostly wooded until the final stretch before the summit. The summit has a great viewpoint of the surrounding area including the Presidential Range.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson and Mount Clay Loop via Caps Ridge Trail
hits.description:
This hike begins from the Caps Ridge Trailhead, the highest elevation trailhead in the White Mountains at over 3,000 feet. 

This route is great for anyone who enjoys the exposure and views that come with walking along ridge lines. Along the way, visitors will tag the summit of Mount Jefferson and Mount Clay, both over 5,000 feet.

hits.name: Peverly Pond Loop
hits.description:
This boardwalk trail, which is also mobility equipment and stroller accessible, begins at the southeast corner of the parking lot. After passing through a beautiful forested area, the trail continues to a wildlife observation blind at the edge of Upper Peverly Pond. From there, the trail loops back to the parking lot after meandering by several (seasonally wet) vernal pools.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Merrimac Drive at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers and partial railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt/grass) surface. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved section. There are benches along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the west end of the trail.

hits.name: Fundy to South Ridge Summit Trail
Seacoast Science Center and Founder's Monument
hits.description:
This park features stunning ocean and tide pool views, woodland trails, a 1942 bunker, and an ocean jetty. Odiorne Point is also home to the Seacoast Science Center.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Ocean Boulevard at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or natural (grass, dirt, fallen leaf) surfaces. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with wider passing spaces).

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.3 miles heading counterclockwise along pavement. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the east end of the trail. The science center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Stone Post Viewpoint and and Indian Pond Lookout
Timber Camp Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins with an easy grade for the first mile before it begins to climb the second half of the way out. 

The trail is mostly wooded and the terminus is a clearing with a fire ring. 

There is a large mound just before the clearing that hikers can stand on top of for the best views of the area.

hits.name: White Dot, Cascade Link, Spellman, Pumpelly, White Arrow, Parker Loop
Mt. Washington loop via John Sherburne Ski Trail to Huntington Ravine to Lion Head
hits.description:
You start out at Pinkham Notch trailhead. 
If the bridge is out, start on the Sherburne ski trail to Tuckerman Ravine then on to Huntington Ravine. Up on top you can switch over to Nelson Crag to do the last push to the summit. 

Coming down, you can take Tuckerman to Lion Head, to Tuckerman and then the ski trail out. 

Huntington Ravine lives up to its dangerous reputation and is not suggested for first-timers unless you go with experienced hikers. It is considered the most difficult trail in the White Mountains.

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge via Nineteen Mile Brook Trail
hits.description:
The climb up 19-Mile Brook is a steady climb up towards Carter Notch and the Carter Notch Hut. 

The hut is a great place to stop and rest before the final climb up to the ridge. The final climb up to Wildcat Mountain is steep and rocky, so shoes with good traction are necessary. From the ridgeline there are great views across the valley to Mount Washington.

hits.name: Forest Discovery Trail
hits.description:
The Forest Discovery Trail is a family and pet-friendly trail made from crushed gravel starting just off the Kancamagus Highway near the Big Rock Campground. Throughout the loop, visitors will find informational signage highlighting the history and ecology of the area. A creek also runs alongside the trail at one point.

According to Accessible Nature (https://www.accessiblenature.info/?page_id=157#federal): This trail is wheelchair-accessible with assistance in areas. There are great views and opportunities to see wildlife. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Kancamagus Highway at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is gravel or a natural surface (dirt, rocks).  It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.2-0.3, 0.6-0.8, and 1.1-1.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. According to the park website, there are wheelchair-accessible restrooms and benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Signal Ridge Trail, Desolation Trail, and Carrigain Notch Trail Loop
hits.description:
This trail will treat hikers to steep climbs and stunning views. 

The Signal Ridge Trail is recommend to take to the summit to Mount Carrigain. It is a more gentle grade than the Desolation Trail. 

After descending the Desolation Trail join the Carrigain Notch Trail which is a welcome relief after the climb up and down the peak.

hits.name: Mount Jackson via Webster Cliffs Loop
hits.description: An alternate way up to Mount Webster and Mount Jackson taking in the wonderful views of Crawford Notch. Park at the Crawford Depot and head south down the Crawford Notch Road to the Willey House. This allows for excellent views of the Webster ridge, 2,500' above!  Enter woods at Willey Pond Trail and work your way over to the Webster Cliff Trail via Sam Willey. Walk the Webster ridge to Webster summit with many vista opportunities of the Notch. Continue over to Mt Jackson then descend via the Webster-Jackson Trail back to the parking area.

hits.name: Sandwich Mountain via Bennett Street Trail
Red Diamond Trail Loop
hits.description: This is a beautifully maintained, well marked, well travelled trail. The entire Horatio Colony Preserve has lots of connecting trails. There is a steep incline on both sides of  this loop, but it is a relatively smooth path. Near the 19th century house built by colonists there is a view. You can see foundation stones, an old stove and even old bed frames. This loop is a very pleasant short walk that gives you great exercise. The further you get into the woods the less you hear the traffic.

hits.name: Skyview to Gumpus Hill Loop
hits.description: Skyview Trail Loop is located in the Cutler-Spalding Conservation Area.  There is a parking lot for about 10 cars off of Aspen Drive. The hike is a moderated wooded hike.  The trails are well-groomed and parts of it are logging roads.  It is peaceful and very beautiful.  Great walk if you want solitude.

hits.name: Epsom Town Forest and Mill Pond Loop
Mizpah Cutoff To Lakes Of The Clouds Hut via Crawford Path
hits.description: This trailhead is accessed by Mizpah Cutoff, Webster Cliff, or Mount Clinton Trail and is a continuation hike to Lakes of the Clouds. There is no parking or road access to this starting location and is often a separate day hike for a backpacking trip.

hits.name: Mount Bartlett via Kearsarge North Trail
hits.description: Access to Bartlett Mount is from Kearsarge North Trail. Parking is not permitted on Mt. Surprise Road or at Eagle Ridge condos. You can park on Hurricane Mt. Road and hike up from there.

hits.name: Tuckerman and Huntington Ravine Trails to Boott Spur Trail
hits.description:
This route has a great perspective of Mt. Washington while passing through the two most notable ravines on the mountain, Tuckerman, and Huntington.

This is a great trail for someone who would like to spend time in the alpine environment of Mt. Washington without the commitment of hiking to the summit.

hits.name: Bald Knob and Mount Crosby Loop
Mineral Site
hits.description:
The Mineral Site Trail leads to an active rockhounding site. A permit is required to harvest any rocks and is available free of charge at the trailhead. A permit should be filled out during each visit.

The trail winds through the woods and along a brook. It is also a great place to walk dogs and take a quiet walk.

hits.name: Elkins and Smith Road to French Meadow Cutoff and Maple Hill Ridge Trail
Mount Willey via Kedron Flume Trail
Hamilton's and Great Hill Loop
hits.description: Hamilton Path to Walters Way to Great Hill Loop, down Glacial Erratic Trail, then return via Snowmobile Trail.

hits.name: Ted's Trail To North Pack Mountain and Wapack Trail
Unknown Pond, the Horn, and Mount Cabot
Bald Rock and Monadnock Mountain Loop
Sandwich Traverse: Whiteface, Passaconway, Sleepers, & Tripyramid
hits.description:
This route will provide hikers an adventure through the heart of the Sandwich Range Wilderness. This route can be done overnight or as a big day hike summiting four NH 4K peaks. 

Anyone attempting this route in a day should be prepared for a long day on trail, bringing a water filter and extra food.

hits.name: Edmands Path to Crawford Path
hits.description:
Three peaks in the middle of the presidential Range including the highest Peak in all of New England in an epic day hike.

This is a great climb over two peaks to get to the highest point in New England.  You will ascend Edmand's Path to the intersection with the Crawford Path over the Southern Presidential Ridge.  On the way up you will have sweeping views to the north and may even see the train on the Cog Railway steaming up the mountain.  Once on the ridge you'll jog over to get to the summit of Eisenhower at 4,761 feet and then continue on over Monroe at 5,385' past a very cool alpine lake and AMC hut to your final destination, Mt. Washington at 6,288 feet!  

Because Mt. Washington has a scenic highway to the top you have several options.  You can arrange for friends/family to pick you up at the top and drive you down saving your knees.  On the other hand, if you are out to include these mountains in your peak bagging lists and want to join any of the climbing clubs and check these off you need to hike yourself back down for the climb to be considered legit.

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge Trail to Carter Moriah Trail
hits.description:
This point-to-point is commonly done in one big day, or more comfortably in one night and two days. Users will be faced with steep, rocky terrain, and few water sources. If you're feeling tired, just look up and soak in the amazing views!

The trail can be muddy even into the late summer months. Since this is a point-to-point, users will need to organize a shuttle back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Howker Ridge Trail
hits.description:
The trailhead begins at a dirt parking lot on Pinkham B road (Dolly Cop), see "getting there" for more info. The trail has several waterfalls, Coosauk falls, Stair falls and Hitchcock falls and a steep ravine view called Devils Kitchen. Hitchcock falls has a river crossing leading to a steep section and a small cave off trial called Bear Pit before Blueberry Ridge.

The trail is named after the Howker family who lived at the base of this trail. The four mini peak-let summits on trail are called Howks and will have you ascending and descending several times and are exposed on the tops. The trail intersects onto Gulfside trail leading to the summit of Madison.

hits.name: Mount Shannon and Goat Hill Pasture
Little Bear, Bobcat, and Broken Boulder Loop Trail
hits.description: Easy MTB trail for the novice. Nothing very technical, just a nice easy ride. A good warm up and fast ride for advanced level riders.

hits.name: Gunstock Mountain Trail to Carriage Road Loop
Mizpah Hut to Mount Washington
hits.description:
Users should be aware this a point-to-point route beginning in the middle of the southern Presidential Range. The starting point is not from a trailhead, but from the Mizpah Spring Hut operated by the Appalachian Mountain Club.

The route climbs over Mt. Pierce, Eisenhower, Franklin, and Monroe ending at the summit of Mount Washington.

hits.name: Colby Marsh and Langmaid Farm Trails
hits.description: These trails explore the Colby Marsh and Landmaid Farm area of the Longmarsh Preserve. The lower loop explores a portion of the much longer Sweet Trail.

hits.name: Carter Ridge and Wildcat Loop
hits.description:
This loop is a great two day/one night backpacking trip where hikers can choose to tent camp or make reservations for the Carter Notch Hut in advance. 

Along the route there are some steep climbs as you cross over the summit of several NH 4K peaks.

hits.name: Mount Jefferson, Adams, and Madison
hits.description:
This route will take hikers through the beautiful alpine zone the White Mountains are famous for while traversing over the northern Presidentials. 

Begin or end at Caps Ridge Trailhead on the Mount Jefferson side or Appalachia Trailhead on the Mount Madison side. 

In the summer time the AMC huts are good places to stop and refuel and get water.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: White Mountain National Forest
hits.description:
The Appalachian Trail is 2,190 miles in length and White Mountain National Forest is home to some of the most formidable terrain on the entire trail.

Hikers headed north from Georgia to Maine will be tested by these mountains as they hike through the second to last state they will pass through on their multi-month trek. 

Hikers will spend dozens of miles above treeline in the alpine zone enjoying some of the trail's most famous views and summit Mt. Washington along this route.

hits.name: Clark Trail to Manning Trail Loop
Cove, Tow, Yellow and Red Trail Loop
Huckins Orchard, Western Extension and Meadow Lake Trail
Cascade Brook, Lonesome Lake, North Kinsman and South Kinsman Mountain Loop
Red Diamond and Ridgeline Trails
hits.description:
The first, most travelled shorter section is the Red Diamond Trail (https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-hampshire/red-diamond-trail-loop?u=m), which ascends and descends in a loop.  On the ascent at the Top House the site of Horatio Colony's 19th century retreat house, there is a view. 

The Ridgeline trail, (white rectangles) followed by the Bailey Brook trail, (yellow rectangles) traverse rolling woodlands with varied types of forest, large rock ledges, some very large mature trees, streams (though all were dry today) and a scenic boggy, mossy section.  It is a pleasant hike, and well traveled to the end of the Ridgeline trail.  The Bailey Brook trail is less well traveled, but nonetheless maintained, and whenever the trail becomes hard to discern, especially with fall leaves covering the ground, the next blaze is always easily found. 

Once you get past the red diamond loop, the walk is very quiet and peaceful with no road noise.  The woods are scrubbier and less pretty toward the end of the Bailey Brook trail, which ends at Forest Ave, which is a very rugged dirt road at that point. The trail end has no parking and cannot be accessed which is why that part of the trail is less traveled. 

There is a narrated nature trail along the entire length of the Preserve has an accompanying guide with interesting info about the history and natural features of the Preserve.

hits.name: Cannon, North and South Kinsman via Kinsman Ridge Trail
Porcupine Ridge, Heron, Litchfield Forest, and Overlook Trails Loop
Wildlife Pond, Smith, Wood Duck Pond and Rocky Ridge Loop Trail
North Twin to Gale River Trail
hits.description:
This hike is best done with two cars, one parked at the North Twin Trailhead and the other left at the Gale River Trailhead. 

Along the route hikers will cross the summit of Galehead, South Twin, and North Twin Mountains.

Galehead Hut is a fun place to stop and rest along the route before summiting Galehead and finishing the descent.

hits.name: Parker Mountain via Elm Street Trail
hits.description:
Elm Street is part of the Parker Mountain Trails which is a 22 mile network of hand-built community-driven mountain bike, hiking, skiing, and running trails in Littleton, New Hampshire. While the primary use of the trail network is mountain biking, it is designed and operated in a way that welcomes all types of uses, including trail running, hiking, skiing, snowmobiling, and hunting.  The total current mileage as of 2018 is 23 miles with a total system acreage of over 1,000 acres.
Parking lot and trailhead located at the end of School St. Littleton NH.

hits.name: FOMBA Trails- Lady Slipper, Deer Run, Moose Tracks, and Fisher Cat Loop Trails
hits.description: The FOMBA trails may be closed during extreme weather conditions or when the trails may be damaged by continued use. This trail may be subjected to intermittent logging. Please check with FOMBA for more information.

hits.name: Ann Stokes to Stone Post Viewpoint
The Direttissma Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins from the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center and lead towards the base of Gulf Peak and along the New River. The trail is rocky in many spots.

This trail is often used to access the Glen Boulder Trail or the Avalanche Brook Ski Trail.

This is a nice walk during the fall when the leaves are changing.

hits.name: Manning Trail to Cardigan South Peak and Cardigan Rimrock
Northern Presidential Loop
hits.description:
This loop is a very challenging day hike, or a much more manageable overnight backpacking trip. 

The route spends many miles in the alpine zone, hikers should be prepared for any type of weather year round while traveling through this area.

The Mt. Washington summit and Madison Spring Hut are good places to stop and refuel on food and water along the route.

hits.name: Presidential Traverse: Highland Center Lodge to Randolph
Hibbard Mountain and Mount Wonalancet
hits.description:
Though there are few viewpoints along this hike, the few are excellent and the hike is nice. Fairly moderate going up the Old Mast Road, but it gets steeper once you turn on to the Walden Trail. 

Don't miss the short side trail to the viewpoint near the summit of the horn, before the intersection with the Wonalancet Range Trail. Pretty buggy throughout during the summer, especially at lower elevations, but nothing out of the ordinary.

hits.name: Mount Mexico via Cabin, Whitin Brook, and Big Rock Cave Trail Loop
hits.description:
Visitors will travel alongside a clear and swift running brook and past some caves formed by large boulders in addition to crossing over the summit of Mount Mexico.

The summit of Mount Mexico is wooded, so the best views on this route are during the late fall-early spring seasons when the leaves are not yet on the trees.

hits.name: Mount Jim and Mount Waternomee Ridge Trail
hits.description: Start at the Ravine motel and take Gorge Brook Trail up to the top of Moosilauke. From there work the Appalachian Trail along to Mount Blue. After this, descend slightly to Beaver Brook campsite.  Return back along the Asquam Ridge Trail.

hits.name: Square Ledge via Oliverian Brook Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins fairly level and is next to a brook for the first 3 miles before it begins to climb up towards Square Ledge. 

The brook does cross the trail at one point and the water level can be high during the spring runoff. 

Users have reported there are some steep rocky sections towards the top that could be difficult for dogs to get up.

hits.name: Rattle River Trail
hits.description:
The Rattle River Trail begins 3 1/2 miles east of Gorham and will bring users past the Rattle River Shelter.

This is a great trail to access the 4,000 footers in the Carter-Moriah Range.

hits.name: Cow Lane to Eastman Meadow Trail
Mount Jefferson and Jefferson Ravine Bluffside Trail
hits.description:
Park at the Jefferson Notch Road parking area and Caps Ridge Trailhead. There are plenty of spots between the lot and the road.  The Caps Ridge Trailhead is the highest elevation trailhead in the White Mountains at over 3,000 feet.

Start up the Caps Ridge Trail to the summit.  Continue off the opposite side of Mt. Jefferson on the Jefferson Loop Trail down to the Gulfside Trail (AT).  Take an excursion down Six Husbands Trail to a short bushwack to the edge of Jefferson Ravine for some fantastic views.  

Return to the AT then right at The Cornice back to the Caps trail down.  A wonderful trek!

hits.name: Ripley Falls and Frankenstein Cliffs Loop
Mount Livermore and Cotton Mountain Trail
Mount Jim, Mount Blue, Mount Moosilauke, and South Peak
hits.description:
This loop brings hikers through a spectacular section of trail above tree line with 360-degree views in all directions. 

These trails are busy but are well marked and are typically in good condition thanks to a hard working local trail crew.

Parking can be competitive in the summer months, so getting an early start is recommended.

hits.name: Midstate Trail (NH/MA/RI)
hits.description: This is the Massachusetts MidState Trail from NH through central MA ending in RI. The northern trailhead is at Windblown XCountry Ski area along RT 124 with parking (across street). This section is part of the Wapack Trail. Alternatively you can start at the Mt. Watatic trailhead along Rt 119 that also has parking. Southern terminus is at RT 100 with no parking.There are a few shelters along the way that are noted on map. The trail is connected by roads mostly in the southern half. Additional info at: https://www.midstatetrail.org/

hits.name: Mount Hale via Fire Warden Trail
hits.description:
The trail starts out at end of Haystack Rd. The trail may be unmarked, and an offline map is recommended. Haystack Road closes in the winter, so winter hikers will need to factor in the added mileage to their trip.

The summit of Mount Hale is mostly wooded but has a small clearing marked with a cairn.

Winter variation: Haystack Road is closed in winter. Visitors can park at Seven Dwarves Motel on Little River Road. Leave envelope with $10 in their mailbox. Do NOT park at end of road. 

Walk up the road, turn right and go over two bridges. Do NOT enter trail immediately after bridges. Instead keep walking past the old chimney/foundation uphill to height of the land then find the trail on left with GREEN sign

hits.name: Mount Moriah and Carter Mountains Traverse
hits.description:
This trail traverses the Stony Brook Trail, Carter-Moriah Trail, and Nineteen Mile Brook Trail.

This hike could be done in a day, but is often done as an overnight backpacking trip. 

The trail spends huge stretches in the alpine zone crossing the summit of Mt. Moriah, Imp Mountain, North Carter Mountain, Middle Carter Mountain, South Carter Mountain, Mount Hight, and Carter Dome.

hits.name: Mount Paugus via Cabin and Big Rock Cave Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail can also be done as an out-and-back by going up the western side of this loop, and then turning around once at Mount Paugus.

hits.name: Eastman Mountain
hits.description:
Hikers will pass Charles Brook and Emerald Pool on the trail leading up to Eastman. This is a good spot to rest in the warmer summer months. 

The trail is well marked with good views from the summit. 

The last third of the ascent is the steepest and most challenging bit of the hike to the summit.

hits.name: Woodland Loop Trail
hits.description:
This central trail winds through a mid-successional forest of white pine, red oak, and yellow birch. You will encounter several boulders, which are large glacial erratics that speak to the glacial history of the area. 

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, hunting, observing wildlife, and skiing. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Mount Agassiz
hits.description: When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

hits.name: Lovewell Mountain via Monadnock Sunapee Trail
hits.description: Lovewell Mountain is 2473ft, is part of the Sunapee Ridge and located in Pillsbury State Park.  This hike approaches from the south and follows a section the Monadnock-Sunapee Greenway. The route starts at a class 6 road then turns on to a trail after about 1 mile.  From there its a generally modest grade to the top.  White blazes mark the trail.

hits.name: Sheldrick Forest Trail
hits.description: This preserve contains trees that reach diameters of 30 inches and have escaped logging for close to 200 years. It is home to 150-foot high white pines, hemlocks, and oak trees. Sheldrick Forest has nearly 4 miles of easy to moderate trails that you can explore. This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking and observing wildlife. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Ann Stokes Trail to Indian Pond
Hamberger Hill and 50/50 Trail
hits.description: Great hike, easy-moderate skill level. Lots of paths to choose.

hits.name: Silver Mountain Trail
hits.description: Trailhead is off of South Road in Lempster. If your car doesn’t have four-wheel drive and/or high clearance, you may want to park a little before the trailhead, as the road can be somewhat rough. It depends on the weather and time of year too, so use your judgment. The trail, marked with yellow blazes, begins to the left of a boarded up cabin. It ascends on a wide old road at easy to moderate grades for around a quarter of a mile before bearing off to the right, still following the yellow blazes. After another few minutes, the yellow blazes branch off to the left, on a moderate ascent. After flattening out briefly, the trail continues on its climb. Not long after this, bits of open ledge become visible, and you start seeing signs of the summit. Eventually the trail emerges onto open rock with views to the south and east. The trail goes through a less open section before reaching the summit. The summit has a near 360-degree vista, with the exception of the view north. Much of the Green Mountains (and many ski mountains) in Vermont are visible, as well as Mount Ascutney. You can also see a good portion of the Monadnock region, including Mount Monadnock itself. Lovewell Mountain is visible to the east/northeast. When you are done admiring the view, hike back down the way you came.

hits.name: Kendall Pond Yellow and Blue Trails
Carter Dome, South Carter, Middle Carter
hits.description: Follow Nineteen Mile Brook Trail up to Carter Notch. Stop by Carter Notch Hut and rest by the pond after the climb and before setting off on the next climb. Summit three Carters along the Carter-Moriah Trail before retracing steps back to the Carter Dome Trail which will lead back to Nineteen Mile Brook and the trailhead.

hits.name: Carr Mountain Trail
hits.description:
About 3/4 of a mile into the hike there is a stream crossing. Depending on the season and recent rainfall, hikers should expect to get their feet wet. 

This is a great hike for someone looking for a lightly trafficked trail. The summit of Carr Mountain is wooded with evidence of an old fire tower at the top.

hits.name: Monadnock Recreational Rail Trail
Arethusa Falls Via Bemis Brook and Arethusa Falls Trails [CLOSED]
Lee Town Forest Trail Loop
hits.description:
Easy loop trail through the town forest. Icy conditions managed with micro spikes. Great with snowshoes after a heavy snowfall!

The route can be accessed by the trailhead shown on this page, or between the library and historical society.

hits.name: Mount Shaw and Black Snout Loop
Turtleback Mountain Trail and Oak Ridge Trail Loop
Summit East and Summit West Loop Trail
Beauty Knob and Beauty Ledge Trail
Mount Washington Auto Road
hits.description: Every year the Mt Washington Road Race brings many of the world's best uphill runners to NH for the classic run up the rock, about 4,600 vertical feet over 7.6 miles. The road is a toll road the rest of the year, except for bike and car races. Many other trails can get you to summit. Count on the wildest weather on earth, no kidding! The strongest winds ever recorded, 234mph, were seen on Washington.

hits.name: Bald Mountain via Tamposi Trail Loop
White Dot Trail to Monadnock Mountain, Plumpelly Trail, Birchtoft Trail to Pond Loop, Hinkley and Harling Trail
Round Pond Trail to Fundy Trail
Rhododendron Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail branches off the Woodland Loop, passing through a damp hemlock forest with mossy rocks and thickets of giant rhododendron, a plant with large clusters of pale flowers and evergreen leaves. 

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, hunting, observing wildlife, and skiing. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Elkins Road to Eastman Meadow and Maple Ridge Trail
Kilkenny Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Users have reported this trail is oftentimes overgrown and can be difficult to follow in places. Downloading the map is recommended. 

The route is often times down as a backpacking trip, since this is a point-to-point, users will need to set shuttle to get back to the starting point.

hits.name: Mount Moriah and Shelburne-Moriah via Rattle River
Fundy Trail via State Park Road
Guinea Trail to Mt. Israel
hits.description:
The route follows the Guinea Pond Trail which is an old road grade before meeting the Mead Trail. The Mead Trail is a steady but not particularly steep climb to Mt. Israel.

Visitors have suggested this is a good shoulder season hike due to the number of ticks in the area and is best avoided in the heart of the summer months.

hits.name: Old Piggery Trail to Lamprey River Trail
Smarts Mountain
hits.description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail leaves Dorchester Road and climbs to the summit of Smarts Mountain. There is a kiosk at the trailhead where the Forest Service will post important information.

Visitors have mentioned the trail can be very wet and sometimes flooded in the spring. There are bog boards in place which the water can still rise over.

hits.name: Yellow Lower and Blue Upper Loop
Mount Madison Via Madison Gulf Trail
hits.description:
There is a 5$ fee at the trailhead that must be paid in cash. 

It is not recommended users descend the Madison Gulf Trail due to the rocky and steep nature of the trail. The Osgood Trail is a better option for descending Mt. Madison and heading back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Pine Mountain Trail From Gorham
hits.description: This trail traverses private property of the Horton Center, which runs a camp from June 1 - August 31 each year. During this time, hikers cannot visit Chapel Rock. When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

hits.name: Passaconaway Cutoff Trail
hits.description:
The trail is relatively flat for the first 1 1/2 miles before it begins to climb towards the summit of Mount Passaconaway.

The climb is a consistent grade and not particularly steep at any point.

Visitors have reported the trail is not well marked in places, so downloading the map ahead of time to help with navigating is helpful.

hits.name: Mizpah Hut via Webster Jackson Trail
hits.description:
Beginning from Crawford Notch, climb up the Webster-Jackson Trail where after just half a mile there will be views from Bugle Cliff.

Hikers will then cross over the summit of Mount Jackson before heading down to the Mizpah Spring Hut.

Reservations must be made through the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance to stay at the hut, but day hikers are welcome to stop by.

hits.name: Mt. Jefferson via Caps Ridge, The Link, and Castle Trail
hits.description:
Please note that dogs are allowed on this trail, however, there are some sections that may be unsafe for them.

Users have reported The Link trail is not well maintained. Sections of the trail are overgrown, narrow, and exposed with steep drop-offs.  

This route down is not the standard descent down Mount Jefferson. It is probably best for someone who has already climbed the peak via a more conventional route and is looking for a more adventurous route down.

hits.name: Hedgehog Ledge to Bear Hill Summit
Garfield to Galehead to South and North Twin Mountains Loop
hits.description:
This loop is done as an overnight backpacking trip or as a big day hike summiting numerous NH 4K peaks. 

Reservations to stay at Galehead Hut must be made through the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance. The hut is open seasonally for visitors though and is a great place to stop and fill up on water and get a snack.

hits.name: Lo Flo and Holbrook Trail
hits.description:
This is a wildlife sanctuary with two hiking trails maintained by the Piscataquog Land Conservancy. Trails are closed to  mountain biking during mud season. 

The trailhead kiosk on Joppa Hill Road in Goffstown has the official trail map as well as rules/regulations.  This information is also available on the conservancy's website:  PLCNH.ORG.

hits.name: Goffstown Rail Trail: Manchester to Goffstown
Heritage and Piscataquog Trail
Mount Tecumseh Peaks and Sosman Trail
hits.description:
Visitors have reported there is not great cell service, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

The sections of the map to the lesser peaks on Tecumseh are off-trail, so hikers should be prepared for some bushwhacking and some time spent off the main established Sosman Trail. The main trail will lead to the summit of Tecumseh with views of the Waterville Valley.

hits.name: Carter Notch Trail
hits.description:
As of August 2020, a gate is locked making the original trailhead inaccessible by car. Hikers will now need to park on the other side of a gate and walk on the road before reaching the trail.

The climbing on the route is fairly consistent with a few sections where it gets steep for a moment.

Accommodations can be made ahead of time through the Appalachian Mountain Club to stay at the Carter Notch Hut. Day hikers can visit the hut which typically also sells snacks and has water available.

hits.name: Wapack Trail: Mountain Road to Miller State Park
hits.description:
This section of the Wapack Trail begins from the northern terminus of the trail and heads south to Miller State Park/Route 101.

Users will head over the summits of North Pack Monadnock and Pack Monadnock along the route. There are great views of the southern New Hampshire region.

hits.name: One Mile Trail and Bear Brook Lower
Percy Peaks Loop
hits.description: Loop trail with two peaks and wonderful views. The trail up to South Percy Peak leads through a lush moss forest with very nice but somewhat obstructed views including a very nice view of North Percy Peak. The trail up to North Percy Peak includes some scrambling over open rock face, but nothing too serious. You are rewarded with breathtaking 360 views including Mount Washington to the south, Old Speck in Maine to the east, some lesser Vermont peaks to the west and Sugarloaf to the north. Recommend going counterclockwise. The trail past the Percy Loop Tentsite is much easier to go down.

hits.name: Mount Shaw via Cold Spring Trail
Lowes Path Trail
hits.description:
The Lowes Path is the oldest trail in the Randolph Valley area, cut between 1875 and 1876. 

This is the easiest path to the summit of Mount Adams, where weather permitting, users will be treated to great views.

The rocks and roots found on the trail can be very slippery so shoes with good traction are highly recommended for this hike.

hits.name: Dam Road to Jeff Smith, Tulepo, Old City and Wildlife Pond Trail Loop
South Ridge from North Mountain Trail
Thoreau Falls Trail
hits.description:
The Thoreau Falls is a mostly level path with wonderful scenery along the way. Hikers will pass by ponds, through the forests, and take in views of the surrounding mountains. 

The Zealand Falls Hut is a short detour off the route. Reservations can be made through the Appalachian Mountain Club in advance for those wanting to stay overnight. The hut typically has water and snacks available for day hikers to purchase.

hits.name: Cheshire Rail Trail
hits.description:
Follow this incredible trail starting near Keene, NH and ending at the Massachusetts state line.

The Cheshire Rail Trail is said to be the second longest rail trail in New Hampshire. It's up to you whether you ride the whole trail or just parts of it. Either way, there are plenty of diversions for hikers, bikers, nordic skiers, snowmobilers, and horseback riders.

Since this trail is not paved, it is best to enjoy it when it's fairly dry or extremely snowy.Even on relatively hot days, this is a pretty good recreational trail because it has ample shade and lots of water for soaking your feet.

Some highlights of the trail include the Stone Arch Bridge, near the Keene trailhead, the historic railroad remnants throughout the trail, and the numerous water features along the way.

If you are biking the trail, the best way to ride it is to start in Keene, New Hampshire and ride to the New Hampshire/Massachusetts state line. Unlike many of the other New Hampshire rail trails, the Cheshire trail has some good stopping spots for restocking your food and beverages. There are stores in Troy, Fitzwilliams, and at the state line. However, like most country stores, they have limited hours, so make sure to have a back-up supply of snacks and drinks.

Try not to rush this trail. It has numerous spots for relaxation and tranquility. In the past, this area was visited by the likes of Henry David Thoreau and Ralph Waldo Emerson.  These were well known nature buffs and contemplators. Once you spend some time on the Cheshire Rail Trail, you'll see why they chose this region for their sojourns.

hits.name: North Piper Mountain via White Face Trail
Wales Loop Trail
hits.description:
Between the rushing sounds of the river, the deep hemlock forest and banks of ferns and wildflowers, a 1.4 mile trail follows along the banks of the scenic Gridley River. You will pass several cascades and small waterfalls on this easy nature-walk. 

The Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy and is an excellent place for walking and observing wildlife. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Bridle Path to Turtleback Mountain Trail Loop
Mast Yard State Forest to Rattlesnake Hill
hits.description: Mountain Biking on a fun double track trail through pine forest along the Contoocook River to a single track climbing trail up rattlesnake Hill. Decent downhill run coming back on Rattlesnake.

hits.name: Goose Pond Trail
hits.description: This is a serene and laid back trail. The loop is pretty easy after one steep climb at the beginning. It's a peaceful trail, mostly used by locals. For a more challenging loop, you can add on Little Sugarloaf, Sugarloaf and Bear Mountain (and beyond!) Nice Newfound Lake views are accessible from these points.

hits.name: French's Ledges from Plainfield Elementary School
Russell Pond Loop
hits.description:
Visitors have mentioned the trail around the pond can be hard to follow at times. Downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating. 

The views across the pond are wonderful and this is a great place to see many different bird species including loons!

Anglers should be familiar with NH state fishing regulations.

hits.name: Elkins and Smith Road to French Meadow Cutoff and Maple Hill Ridge Trail
hits.description:
There are a lot of trails crisscrossing so it's easy to get off-trail. Download the map prior to your hike to have the route handy. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the unpaved parking lot off of Proctor Hill Road at the north end of the trail. There are two designated van-accessible parking spots in the paved lot marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is natural surfaces (dirt, grass, rock) or gravel, and typically at least 3 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.5 miles when heading counterclockwise. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections after about a half-mile when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mill Pond Trail and Gum Tree Trail Loop
Wiley Pond and Saco River Loop
Crotched Mountain from Mountain Road
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not well marked, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: East Pond Trail
hits.description:
East Pond is accessible from Tripoli Road to the south, or a northern trailhead off of the Kancamagus Highway.

The pond is stunning and is nestled between the flanks of West Peak and Scar Ridge East Peak. 

Visitors have reported the area can be very buggy spring-summer, so don't forget to pack bug spray.

hits.name: Winnipesaukee Trail
Henderson-Swasey Red, Green, and Yellow Loop
Cooks Pond and Cooks River Loop
hits.description:
This trail explores unique pitch pine forests and red oak woodlands in the northern part of the Ossipee Pine Barrens Preserve. The trails offer views to the lovely and remote Cooks Pond, and follow unique esker systems. Eskers are deposits of sand and gravel that were formed in massive cracks in the continental glaciers that once covered the area.  

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, fishing, observing wildlife, and snowmobiling. Camping, fires or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve, and all dogs must be on a leash.

https://www.wildlife.state.nh.us/maps/bathymetry/cooks_madison.pdf

hits.name: Ammonoosuc Rail Trail
hits.description:
This mellow trail starts near a modern covered bridge in Littleton & ends near a historic covered bridge in Woodsville.

Dogsledding is just one of the many activities allowed on the Ammonoosuc Rail Trail.Yet with a multitude of trail uses, the Ammonoosuc is surprisingly uncrowded and, in spots, even tranquil.With frequent views of the river, trail users are in for a constant feast of sights and sounds. 

One of the unique and wonderful aspects of this particular trail is that it starts near a modern covered bridge and ends near a historical covered bridge. As with some of the other New Hampshire trails such as the Ashuelot Rail Trail, covered bridges are some of the main attractions on the trail. Of course that's in addition to New England scenery, friendly towns, and a consistently level trail. In addition to the contemporary covered bridge in Littleton and the historical covered bridge in Woodsville, there is also another historical covered bridge, near the trail, in Bath, New Hampshire.

Although the trail has a fairly level grade, it can get rough at times with occasional larger chunks of ballast along the way. It is recommended that you take the trail at a leisurely pace. You may even want to explore some of the towns as you journey down the trail and stay overnight at one of the nearby campgrounds or bed & breakfasts. There are accommodations in both Littleton and Woodsville as well as a few places, a ways off the trail, along the route. It is always a good idea to plan ahead and check for availability before you start your trail trip. Make sure to get good directions to any lodging before you depart.

hits.name: Arethusa Falls and Frankenstein Cliff Loop [CLOSED]
hits.description:
The Arethusa Falls and Frankenstein Cliff Loop is a great hike to the highest falls in New Hampshire. The trailhead is off Crawford Notch Road (route 302) and the falls are visible from the parking area. The trail begins directly from the parking lot and heads up until you reach the old Conway railroad tracks. From the tracks, you will know you are heading in the right direction along Frankenstein Cliffs Trail.

Enjoy the views and different falls as you connect to the Arethusa Ripley Falls trail, Arethusa Falls Trail and Bemis Brook Trail. Other notable falls along the route are the Bemis Falls and Coliseum Falls.

hits.name: Basin and Hermit Falls Trail
hits.description:
Hermit Falls is tucked a mile northwest of the Basin Campground, which is operated by the U.S. Forest Service. A seasonal waterfall, the best time to visit this waterfall is between mid-May and early July, or after a substantial rainstorm. 

In high water conditions, Hermit Falls is a pretty 30-foot horsetail within a remote, moss-surrounded ravine. In low water, the falls turns into a powerless slide down dark wet rock.

hits.name: Al Merrill Loop Trail
hits.description: The Loop is made up of the Ridge Trail and the Al Merrill cross-country ski trail.  For hiking, it is easier to ascend on the Ridge Trail and descend on the Al Merrill Trail since the Ridge Trail is rougher and rockier.  The Ridge Trail follows an attractive stream, and the Al Merrill Trail is lightly used in the summer and passes through a pleasant open woodland.

hits.name: Burton Peak and Holt Peak Thru-Hike
