hits.description: This is a point-to-point hiking spanning Temple Mountain from south to north. Hikers either need to leave a car or get a ride from the endpoint.

hits.name: Mount Willey, Mount Field and Mount Tom via Ethan Pond Trail
Mt Adams via Lowe's Path and King Ravine
hits.description:
Hikers will enjoy 360-degree views from the summit of Mount Adams of the surrounding Presidential Range peaks.

On the way up the King Ravine Trail the trail passes the Crag Camp Appalachian Mountain Club Hut. Accommodations must be made in advance through the AMC for anyone looking to stay at the hut.

hits.name: Mount Paugus via Kelley Trail and Old Mast Road
hits.description:
Trail starts at the Ferncroft Road parking lot. This hike does not go to the true summit of Mount Paugus, but the ledges just below the summit. The true summit requires a bushwhack. 

The trail is mostly wooded and is a great place to surround yourself with colorful foliage during the fall leaf season.

hits.name: Esther Currier Wildlife Management Trail
hits.description:
This is an absolute gem of a place. The hike is nice with minimal incline. The beaver pond is absolutely stunning. It was so fun to watch the tadpoles race through the water and the birds fly all around. You can start the trail from either end. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Mountain Road at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is gravel or a natural surface (dirt, leaves). It is typically at least 5 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: Baldface Trail and Slippery Brook Loop
Phillips Exeter Academy Red Trail
hits.area_name: Phillips Exeter Academy Woods Trail Network

hits.name: Webster Slide Mountain via Wachipauka Pond Trail
hits.description:
The Wachipauaka Trail is a section of the Appalachian Trail leading past Wachipauka Pond on the way to the summit of Webster Slide Mountain. 

The pond is a great place for dogs to swim around and cool off in the summer months.

Visitors have mentioned the trail can be quite muddy in the spring and summer months.

hits.name: Burton Peak via Wapack Trail
hits.description: Moderately steep for the first third of the hike, and towards the end, but it’s fairly gentle in between. The Roger Myrick Outlook provides the first views after about 0.5 miles, and there is another overlook not long after. The summit has a nice vista towards Mount Monadnock.

hits.name: Greeley Ponds Trail
hits.description:
This is a pleasant hike to Greeley Ponds that gently climbs from Livermore Road. Good footing, glimpses of the Osceolas, and a tumbling river make this a nice walk in the woods.

The area is also popular in the wintertime with backcountry skiers and snowshoers. 

Camping is not allowed within 1/4 mile of the pond.

hits.name: Daniel Webster Trail
hits.description:
The Daniel Webster Trail begins from the Dolly Copp Campground and leads to the summit of Mt. Madison. Hikers can continue over to the Madison Spring Hut which typically has food available for purchase and water available in the summer months.

Users will begin in the forest and move into the exposed, fragile, and beautiful alpine zone.

hits.name: Fox State Forest Ridge Trail Loop
Beaver Brook Trail, Eastman Meadow Trail, and Maple Hill Ridge Loop
Mount Whiteface via McCrillis Trail
hits.description: Yellow blazes mark the beginning of this trail.  The trail is hard to find shortly after the trailhead- Users suggest downloading the route beforehand to navigate.  There is a river crossing and the bridge is long gone, with just a support column in the middle of the river.  You can cross about 20m downriver of the bridge, where there are sufficient rocks in the river to serve as steps.  About 500m before the summit, there are some exposed rock faces, and then you reach a rocky spot with spectacular views.  The actual summit is about 100m further along.

hits.name: Little Bear and Big Bear Loop Trail
Monadnock Mountain via Birchtoft to Hinkley Loop
hits.description: There is a fee to enter the park.

hits.name: Bobcat Broken Boulder, and Salt Lick Loop
hits.description:
Started the Saltlick Trail at Campground Road and proceeded to do a loop with Bobcat, Broken Boulder, and Pitchpine Trails with a side trip to
Spring Pond

hits.name: Cider Mill Trail
hits.description: The offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that there may be poor cell reception in this area, in addition to poorly marked trails.

hits.name: East and West Monson Road Loop
Round Pond, North Mountain and Shaw Trail Loop
Shelburne Moriah Mountain via Shelburne and Kenduskeag Trail
hits.description:
This trail begins from the North Shelburne Trailhead just outside Shelburne, NH.

The hike enters the Wild River Wilderness and eventually, the summit of Shelburne Moriah Mountain after the Shelburne Trail meets the Kenduskeag Trail.

The summit has wide-open views of the surrounding area.

hits.name: Carter Moriah Trail to Stony Brook Trail
hits.description:
A series of ascending hills leads to the final push on Mount Moriah.  

There are several excellent views to the North, West, and South on this hike and the constant views are energizing on the climbs. The series of hills are just breathtaking!

hits.name: Robert Frost Historic Site Loop Trail
Goose Eye Mountain via Appalachian Trail
Jeff's Hill Trail
hits.description:
A short loop off-shooting from the Sweet Trail, Jeff's Hill takes you past the old stone walls and foundations of when this land was a pasture.  

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy, and is an excellent place for walking and observing wildlife. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Mount Flagg via Dave Green, Canaan Mountain and Gorilla Trail
Overlook, White, Heron, and Deer Trails Loop
Wind Mill Hill Trail and Parker Pond Loop
Spruce Knoll via Bald Face Circle Trail
hits.description:
This is a steep section of the Baldface Circle Trail leading up to Spruce Knoll.

There are some exposed rocky ledges with good viewpoints. These ledges can be extremely slippery, so hikers should use caution if it has recently rained or there could be ice.

The trail also passes Emerald Pool which is a nice swimming hole.

hits.name: Sawyer River Trail
hits.description:
The Sawyer River Trail is a wide dirt trail frequented by hikers, runners, and cyclists. 

The trail passes by rivers, creeks, and through peaceful forests.

hits.name: Round Pond Trail to Brook Trail Loop
hits.description: There is one nice view on the orange trail, besides that the top of the gunstock is the only view.

hits.name: Rockingham Recreational Trail: Fremont to Derry
Carter Mountain and Wildcat Mountain Loop
hits.description:
Loop to complete five of the NH 4,000 footers (in suggested order) - Carter South, Carter Middle, Carter Dome, Wildcat D, and Wildcat A. Easy to drop the Wildcats if the legs/weather don't cooperate.

Good hike to prep/test yourself for other big objectives like Garfield/Galeheald/Twins, Lafayette/Lincoln/Liberty/Flume, or the Presidential Traverse.

hits.name: Hancock Notch Trail
hits.description:
The Hancock Notch Trail starts from Route 112 and runs between Mount Huntington and Juno Peak. 

At points the trail closely follows the Sawer River. Eventually there is a river crossing which differs in difficult depending on the season.

In the spring and early summer the river can be a challenge to cross, expect to get your feet wet. By late summer and fall the river is typically pretty low and hikers can hop across rocks without getting wet.

hits.name: Lincoln Woods Trail to Franconia Brook Trail Loop
hits.description: Set up as a 2 night/3 day backpacking trip, this route will take you into the heart of the Pemigewassett Wilderness as you hike towards Owl's Head.  The climb to Owl's Head features a steep slide with impressive views.  13 Falls tentsite, the intended destination for night 1, has some gorgeous waterfalls!  As you ascend the following morning, Galehead Hut is a great spot to recharge with snacks.  If you time it right, you'll make it to West Bond for sunset, with spectacular 360° views, including Bondcliff.  The third day will take you over the Bonds and out to where you started from.

hits.name: Shumway and Lemon Squeezer
hits.description:
This trail network is popular with a number of user groups, but is probably most popular with mountain bikers in the summer months. 

There are trails here for every ability level mountain biker. 

Overall, a great place to walk dogs and spend a few hours enjoying the quiet and peaceful woods of the White Mountains.

hits.name: Moose Bog
hits.description:
There are benches and wonderful views at the boardwalk overlook.

Accessibility: This packed gravel and wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers) trail is estimated to be 3 feet wide. The slope is typically gentle (3% grade or less) except for two steep (8 to 12% grade) sections at about the 0.5 and 0.7 mile marks where mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance. It is unclear if there are any designated wheelchair-accessible parking spots at the start of the route (south end).

hits.name: Cedar Loop Trail
hits.description:
This short trail leads off the main loop to a small cove of a much larger cedar swamp, full of Atlantic white cedar and red maple, along with giant rhododendron and winterberry.

This Preserve is managed by The Nature Conservancy in New Hampshire, and is an excellent place for walking, hunting, observing wildlife, and skiing. Camping, fires, pets, or wheeled vehicles are not permitted on the preserve.

hits.name: Heron Point Sactuary Loop Trail
hits.description: You may try to park in the municipal lot on Bay Road and walk to the Heron Point Estates Cooperative.

hits.name: Bear Brook, Carr Ridge and Hayes Farm Loop
hits.description: Mid-spring hike in the park. Did several trails including Bear Brook Trail, parts of Cascade, Little Bear and others.

hits.name: Madison Gulf Trail via Mt. Washington Auto Road
hits.description: From the Mt. Washington Auto Rd follow the Madison Gulf Trail to the summit of Mt. Madison.

hits.name: Proteus Falls, Erebus Falls, and Evans Falls via Townline Brook Trail
hits.description:
A sketchy path, but lovely falls. The trail is very short and you get to see 3 waterfalls - each with their own unique characteristics. It is a very narrow path (under 2 feet wide) and meanders along the vertical drop off to the brook.  The Townline Brook ravine is deep so slipping off the trail would result in very serious injury. 

The first falls to be seen are Proteus Falls, then Erebus Falls and at the top; Evans Falls. Proteus is an early sea-god, one of several beings whom Homer calls the "The Old Man in the Sea" - Erebus is also greek - Erebus is used to refer to a region of the underworld where the dead had to pass immediately after dying. The falls are slightly different from each other.  Proteus is a 25 foot drop, as is Erebus and Evans is a small 12 foot drop.

hits.name: Mount Katherine via Pasture Path and Red Path Loop
hits.description:
Begin with a short walk on Ferncroft Road, crossing the Wonalancet River and joining the Pasture Path.

The Pasture Path will lead to the summit of Mount Katherine, retrace the Pasture Path for about half a mile to the Red Path.

The Red Path leads back to Ferncroft Road, walk on the road back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Spalding Town Forest Northeast Loop via Walker Trailhead
Ethan Pond to Zealand Falls via Thoreau Falls
Knight’s Pond Loop
hits.description: Beautiful spring hike. Easy hike with little grade apart from the initial road walk.

hits.name: Cottontail Lane, Gumpus Hill and Whitetail Trail
hits.description: Great hike in the Gumpus Pond Conservation area. The trails are clear and well marked. There is a public parking lot on Hinds Lane by Gumpus Pond for easy access.

hits.name: Lower Nanamocomuck Trail
hits.description:
The Lower Nanamocomuck Trail follows the Swift River from Bear Notch Rd down to Passaconaway Road. Hikers will see the historic Albany Covered Bridge at the end of the trail.

The trail has access to a number of great swimming holes on the Swift River that are fun for kids in the heat of summer time.

hits.name: Kimball Pond Loop
hits.description: Full Loop can only be made during winter months or extreme draught.

hits.name: Carter and Wildcat Peaks
hits.description:
Hikers will begin at Wildcat Mountain and climb up the Polecat ski trail towards the ridge. The Polecast trail is a great place to see wildflowers in the summer months.

Once on top of the ridge hikers will cross the Wildcats, dip down to Carter Notch and climb up and over the Carters. Since this is a point-to-point, users will need to set a shuttle or walk on the road back to the original trailhead.

hits.name: Crawford Ridgepole Trail to Doublehead Mountain
Bondcliff, Mt. Bond, West Bond, Mt Guyot and Zealand Loop
Gage's Mill to Tufts to Scouting Way to Campbell Loop
Snow's Mountain Trail Loop
hits.description:
Visitors have mentioned the trail is not well marked in spots, so having the map downloaded ahead of time to navigate is helpful.

Overall, this hike is moderate but visitors should expect some steep sections approaching the summit. The trail also has sections where there are plenty of rocks and roots to hike over.

hits.name: Province Pond via Province Brook Trail
hits.description:
A wonderful walk through the pristine forest. There are many small streams, interesting trees, rocks, and a lovely pond with wildlife. There is a backcountry shelter for camping at the pond.

Directions by coming over Hurricane Mtn road aren't clear. Simply turn left onto 303 north and a bit less than a mile up, look for a small trail sign on the left. This puts you on a fine dirt road and it will be about 2.5 miles until you reach the trailhead, where the road ends.

hits.name: Honey Hill
hits.description: The access to this trail is located on private property- please be respectful to property owners and stay on the trail.

hits.name: Hedgehog Ridge Trail and Woods Road Loop
hits.description: Hike starts in the parking lot off Hedgehog Mountain Road. Walk approximately 0.2 miles down the dirt road to the pick-up the trail.

hits.name: Crawford and Franconia Notches Scenic Drive: Glen to Lincoln
Great Bay Discovery Center Trail
hits.area_name: Great Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve
hits.description: Located at the south end of Great Bay, Sandy Point offers mixed habitats and wide open views of the Bay. The site includes a 1,700 foot universally accessible boardwalk and is well known for spotting neotropical migrant birds as they pass through to their wintering or nesting areas.

hits.name: Harrington Pond Via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
This section of the Appalachian Trail begins from Lost River Road/Rt 112 and passes over Mount Wolf en route to Harrington Pond. 

The summit of Mount Wolf is wooded with no viewpoints. 

After crossing under the power lines hikers will find the Eliza Brook Shelter, which has a shelter, tent sites, and a privy.

hits.name: Great Gully Trail
hits.description:
The Great Gully is a very steep and rocky climb to Thunderstorm Junction in the saddle between Mount Sam Adams and Mount Quincy Adams.

To join the Great Gully Trail, begin on the Airline Trail and then to the Short Line Trail, Randolph Path, and King Ravine Trail before meeting the Great Gully and starting the climb.

hits.name: Dearborn Forest Loop via Onway Lake
Neville Peak and Nottingham Mountain via Neville Peak and Neville Ridge Scout Foot Trail Loop
hits.description: This hike provides users will great views from the summit of Nottingham Mountain while crossing the top of Neville Peak along the way. This trail is a great place to bring your pets to exercise!

hits.name: Presidential Traverse via Daniel Webster Trail
hits.description:
Hikers will set a shuttle at Dolly Copp Campground and the parking area near Saco Lake at Crawford Notch to complete this traverse. 

 This is a challenging route spending miles in the alpine zone and crossing over the summit of Mount Washington. 

Some of the AMC huts along the route are good places to stop and refill on water.

hits.name: Mount Monroe, Eisenhower, Pierce and Jackson via Marshfield Station
hits.description:
Start up the Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail to the summit of Monroe.  Lots of waterfalls, beautiful scenery, and fairly steep.

From here, hikers will make their way over to Eisenhower.  Continued over to Pierce, past the Mizpah Hut and on to Jackson.    

Take the Webster Jackson trail down to 302. For those with some energy left, Mt. Webster can be tacked on after Mt. Jackson.

hits.name: Goose Eye Mountain and Mount Carlo Loop
hits.description:
This loop begins in New Hampshire then crosses into Maine and Grafton Notch State Park.

The route passes over Mount Carlo and Goose Eye Mountain with great panoramic views of the surrounding area. Keep an eye out for moose and bears in this area.

Hikers will find some steep sections of trail that require climbing ladders.

hits.name: Mount Wolf and Kinsman Ridge via Appalachian Trail
Nelson Crag Trail
hits.description:
Beginning from the Mt. Washington Auto Road, the Nelson Crag Trail climbs to the summit of Mt. Washington.

The route is above treeline and very exposed to the elements. Users should be prepared for extreme winds, rain, or snow depending on the season. This is a great trail for someone who would like to experience the wonders of the alpine environment at Mt. Washington without starting their hike from the base.

hits.name: Carr Mountain via Carr Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Hikers will find views of Mount Washington and Mount Moosilauke off in the distance on a clear day from the summit of Carr Mountain. The site of an old fire tower will provide the best views at the top.

Visitors have mentioned the trail is very buggy in the spring/summer time, so bug spray is nice to have.

hits.name: Mount Monroe, Mount Franklin, and Mount Eisenhower via Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail
hits.description:
The hike begins with a pretty steep climb up to Lake of the Clouds via Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail with a waterfall/pool on the way up.

From Lake of the Clouds, it is a fairly easy ridge walk over to Monroe, Franklin, and Eisenhower. Amazing views of the Whites especially walking south on the presidential range. Great variety of high elevation plants as well!

hits.name: Mount Adams via Great Gulf, Madison Gulf, and Buttress Trails
hits.description:
This route is a challenging way to gain the summit of Mount Adams. It is best for someone who has already climbed Adams on a more popular route or someone who is looking for a real challenge. 

The Madison Gulf Trail is very steep and rocky, the trail has few switchbacks and can feel relentless.

Hikers can make a short detour to the Madison Spring Hut for water and will pass the beautiful Star Lake.

hits.name: Mizpah Hut via Webster Cliff Trail
hits.description:
Incredible views with some real scrambles up Mount Webster! The overlook points on Webster are stunning and beautiful gray jays are abound on Mount Jackson. 

Without a doubt, this is the best way to get to the Mizpah Spring Hut. Reservations must be made in advance through the Appalachian Mountain Club to stay at the hut, but day hikers can stop by.

hits.name: Hiroshi Loop Trail
hits.description:
The Hiroshi Loop, Trail is 1.9 miles long and features relatively easy hiking over flat terrain marked by orange rectangles. Trail begins at the former site for Hiroshi’s Monadnock School for Natural Cooking and Philosophy, the foundations of which are on your left as you enter the parking area.

It’s a 128 acre tract of protected Woodland that includes a lovely old field, as well as 9 acres of open wetland and 0.6 mile of Shoreline along Nubanusit Brook. It’s contiguous with 1384 acres of conserved land in Peterborough and with a 7142 acre conservation corridor between Nubanusit Lake and MacDowell reservoir.

hits.name: Stonedam Island Long Loop Trail
hits.description:
Please note that using the "Directions" button on this page will not bring you to a boat launch. The route on this page requires that you kayak or boat to the island.

A secluded uninhabited island with well maintained and marked hiking trails thanks to the LRCT.  Access only by boat.  2 mile loop trail with a single small summit.  Due to the dock only being big enough for 2 boats it almost guarantees you will be the only people on the island.

hits.name: Mount Livermore via Old Mountain Road to Crawford-Ridgepole Trail
Yudicky Farm Swamp Loop
hits.description:
Yudicky Farm is a very popular mountain bike area with many technical features like rock drops and wooden bridges.

Be sure to wear orange or bring a bell from late September to early December as hunters are often seen in the area.
